Technoparkstrasse 1 Zurich 8005 Switzerland This paper proposes an industrial-friendly approach based on physics-informed Bayesian machine learning for probabilistic inference and refinement of stability predictions in milling. The knowledge from physics principles and theoretical models is gathered into a substructure-based framework and enables dedicated updating and exchange of models on a substructure level. The Bayesian learning algorithm utilizes this framework as a basis to simultaneously interact with multiple machine and process configurations that share substructures, leading to federated and transfer learning over a network of machine tools on a production site. Moreover, the paper further elaborates on the Bayesian perspective to anticipate the potential usefulness of given experimental data in improving the model accuracy by quantifying information gain for two primary purposes: Firstly, recursive online learning can manage computational resources by processing only the most informative data points that may be collected during arbitrary cuts. Secondly, active learning leverages the information gain to dynamically adapt a sequential data collection, leading to accelerated learning with minimal labeled data. The experimental validations confirm that the proposed approaches lead to effective learning and reliable predictions of milling stability, outperforming traditional deterministic methods. Keywords Chatter stability Physics-informed Bayesian learning Active learning Transfer learning Federated learning Recursive online learning Introduction Despite self-excited chatter vibrations having been the subject of extensive research by scholars for many years, it continues to be one of the main factors limiting the productivity of milling operations in industrial environments. While predicting chatter allows recognizing chatter-free process conditions for a boost in production rate, their blind selection can be followed by undesirable consequences such as poor surface quality, accelerated tool wear, and even machine failure. Stability Lobe Diagrams (SLDs) are a recognized tool to distinguish between stable and unstable cutting depths as a function of spindle speed. Nevertheless, there is often a notable difference between the theoretical and experimental limits of stability presenting a significant barrier to practical application in industry. Although theoretical models of milling dynamics are not exact replications of the actual machining process, the primary reason for this discrepancy is attributed to the input parameters used in these models, which may be imprecise or altered during operation. The literature extensively discussed the modeling of milling dynamics, which involves understanding the interaction between the milling tool and the workpiece. This interaction is governed by a time delay between the current vibrations of the cutting edge and the vibration marks left on the workpiece by the previous cutting edge being the excitation of vibrations. This time-delayed feedback in the milling process generates a closed-loop self-exciting effect, which can cause process instability under specific conditions. Since the first study on this topic by Tlusty and Polacek [1] in 1963, various methods have been introduced in the time and frequency domains to analyze the regenerative effect and process stability. These approaches have been widely studied by pioneers and can be found in their highlighted academic publications, such as Altintas et al. [2], Insperger and Stépán [3], Bachrathy et al. [4], and the well-known Zero-order Approximation (ZOA) method by Altintas and Budak [5]. Besides information about the engagement conditions and tool geometry, the most critical inputs required for stability predictions using these theoretical models are the cutting forces and the dynamic response of the machine tool structure at the tip of the cutting tool [6,7]. The two inputs can be acquired through either modeling or experimental characterization. Nonetheless, exclusively relying on theoretical models is usually unfeasible since it can result in substantial inaccuracies in predictions. In contrast, experimental characterization can be costly and time-consuming, requiring specialized measurement equipment and skilled operator expertise. The following presents a concise overview of these approaches. The metal cutting forces can be characterized through two fundamentally distinct methods: numerical analysis and experimental characterization. Researchers have studied numerical approaches such as the mesh-free method through an updated Lagrangian approach with dynamic refinement by Afrasiabi et al. [8,9] or finite element analysis by Gonzalo et al. [10]. However, these methods are computationally demanding, and uncertainties in the material properties of the workpiece can lead to inaccurate force predictions. Hence, the experimental approaches have received attention in the modeling of cutting forces by introducing multiple coefficients, known as Cutting Force Coefficients (CFCs). These coefficients relate the uncut chip thickness to the resulting forces and assume different dependencies such as linear [7,11], cubic [12], and exponential [13]. In this regard, the main analytical formulations are orthogonal to oblique transformation [14], mechanistic identification [7], and nonlinear optimization [15,16]. While the mechanistic calibration is relatively straightforward, the coefficients can have dependencies on process parameters such as spindle speed and feed rate [17,18]. The experimental approaches of identifying CFCs require the measurement of instantaneous or average cutting forces. While table or rotary dynamometers are commonly used in academic research (e.g [19–22]), they are impractical for industrial applications due to their high cost and the restrictions they impose on the workpiece or tool mounting, as well as imposing undesirable structural compliance. Consequently, researchers have explored indirect estimation techniques that integrate additional sensors or use NC controller signals. The fundamental concept of these methods is to measure accessible signals that are correlated with the cutting forces and then use a transformation to recover the cutting forces from the noisy distorted measurements. For example, Postel et al. [23] used accelerometers mounted on the spindle housing, Ostad Ali Akbari et al. [24] used a non-contact displacement sensor at the spindle’s rotating part, and Aslan and Altintas [25] used drive current measurements in a 5-axis milling machine. In these studies, Kalman filters were employed to compensate for the distortion of frequency content between the cutting zone and the sensor measurements. Although indirect approaches appear to be a cost-efficient alternative for force monitoring, the biggest challenge remains the accurate compensation of the distorted frequency response of the measured signal which is associated with the vibrational modes of the machine system and may require comprehensive mathematical modeling and calibration. Obtaining the machine tool’s structural dynamics at its tooltip also raises certain challenges. While direct measurement of tooltip dynamics through conventional impact testing may appear to be the most straightforward method for its ease of usage and short setup time, the strong dependence of the tooltip dynamics on the tool-holder combination necessitates repeating the impact test for every tool-holder-spindle combination. This approach is impractical for the countless number of combinations that may exist on a shop floor. On the other hand, theoretical modeling of the entire machine tool encounters sophisticated complexities and requires detailed knowledge of the machine components’ geometry and dedicated experimental calibrations for joint and damping characterization [26–28]. To alleviate these challenges, Receptance Coupling Substructure Analysis (RCSA) by Schmitz and Donalson [29] offered a viable alternative by facilitating the coupling of experimentally measured machine tool dynamics (excluding the tooling system) to theoretically modeled tool-holder assembly. Theoretical modeling of the tool-holder assembly typically involves segmented Timoshenko beams representing the tool and holder, connected through a damped-flexible joint at their interface. The stiffness and damping values of this joint are commonly tuned based on experimental measurements. Matthias et al. [30] used a Timoshenko beam model with a lumped joint interface and used the receptance of the tool-holder assembly, measured by an impulse hammer and laser vibrometer in free-free boundary conditions, to tune the lumped contact parameters. Alternatively, Ostad Ali Akbari et al. [31] introduced a finite-element-based implementation of the Timoshenko beam with a non-uniformly distributed elastic-damped connection along the tool-holder clamping length. The associated contact parameters are estimated through a nonlinear evolutionary optimization to maximize the correlation of the assembly’s bending dynamics to the dominant peaks that appeared in the emitted sound spectrum when an arbitrary object impacts the tool-holder assembly in free-free boundary conditions. Further attempts in the modeling of the tool-holder dynamics can be found in [29,32–35–38,39,40]. As both experiment-based and model-based approaches require extensive preparation and analysis, in recent years, researchers have explored the use of machine learning techniques in the prediction of stability charts. Some researchers have taken a purely data-driven approach, such as Cherukuri et al. [41], who trained a multi-layer neural network classifier on at least 600 samples to achieve acceptable stability classification accuracy. Although Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) have proven to be powerful tools for complex classification tasks, their effectiveness heavily relies on having a large and diverse training dataset that covers all possible machine tool and process configurations. However, obtaining such a rich dataset from chatter records during experimental cuts is often infeasible for industries. Researchers have utilized physical models to generate supplementary data to feed DNNs. For example, Postel et al. [6] proposed an ensemble deep transfer learning method in which they pre-trained 200 DNNs on different simulated data sets. Each of these data sets was generated considering various combinations of model parameters based on their uncertainty distributions. A fine-tuning step was conducted ultimately on each DNN with an experimental dataset. Through this transfer learning technique, approximately 103 − 104 number of the required data for pre-training were generated from simulations, while 101 − 102 of data points in the fine-tuning step were obtained from experimental cuts. However, it should be noted that for each tool-holder-spindle combination and workpiece material, a dedicated ensemble set of DNNs must be prepared, thus presenting a limitation of this approach. The use of hybrid techniques that incorporate physical models directly into machine-learning frameworks has gained popularity in recent years. Postel et al. [18] proposed a novel stability prediction method based on a neural network-supported inverse identification technique, which utilizes multiple neural networks to generate input parameters for stability calculation via ZOA. The neural network weights were tuned using a genetic algorithm, which minimized a loss function that measures the discrepancy between the predicted and observed stability limit and chatter frequency. While this inverse method successfully improved stability predictions and revealed important dependencies, such as the relationship between CFCs and spindle speed, its black-box nature limits the transferability of the gained knowledge to similar configurations. Wegener et al. [42] addressed this shortcoming by introducing a substructure-based stability prediction framework augmented with neural networks to account for unknown dependencies. The framework was trained in a similar manner to the previously mentioned work, by minimizing the discrepancies between the predicted and observed stability limits and chatter frequency. The major drawback of this updating approach is that it does not offer any information to enhance the models when both the predictions by the model and observations are stable. Although hybrid methods have proven to be a promising strategy for leveraging physical models and saving experimental data points in stability prediction refinement, these methods are based on a deterministic perspective and do not account for model uncertainties. Subsequently, the accuracy of their predictions depends on the richness of the experimental dataset in containing learnable information, which is not known beforehand. In contrast, a Bayesian perspective provides a framework for quantifying the degree of confidence in the prediction by considering the full range of possible model parameters and their respective probabilities. Karandikar et al. [43] presented a Bayesian approach that is purely data-driven for generating a probabilistic stability map from experimental chatter observations without prior knowledge of tool dynamics or CFCs. However, similar to other pure data-driven approaches, the knowledge acquired is specific to the machine and process configuration and is further limited here to the engagement condition. In [44], the same authors extended their approach to developing a closed-loop scheme for identifying optimal process parameters automatically based on a criterion on the expected improvement of material removal rate. Cornelius et al. [45] developed a physics-based stability prediction model that accounts for the uncertainty distributions associated with input parameters. These distributions are propagated through the model to create stability maps. The authors used a sampling approach to estimate posterior distributions, collecting 1000 samples with a greedy adaptive Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm, introduced by Haario et al. [46]. They then employed the posterior probability map to select the process parameters that maximize the expected increase in material removal rate, following the approach proposed by Karandikar et al. [47]. Ahmadi [48] applied Bayesian techniques to update the posterior distributions of modal parameters in turning operations by analyzing the closed-loop poles of the system based on in-process vibration measurements during stable cuts. The author collected a large set of 25000 samples using an improved Transitional MCMC algorithm from Betz et al. [49]. Li et al. [50] also modeled the bending dynamics at the tooltip by a 2DOF system whose modal parameters are obtained by fitting modes to an experimental measurement of the tooltip receptance in idle conditions. This procedure was repeated multiple times to establish a prior distribution for the modal parameter values. The objective was to refine these distributions to account for the variations of machine tool dynamics under operational conditions. They utilized an improved ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo method (IGWMCMC) that employs an ensemble of multiple walkers to enhance the convergence of the Markov Chain to the posterior distribution. Although the Bayesian model updating techniques described in the literature employ physical principles, the physics-based models they rely on have been simplified, focusing only on CFCs and the modal parameters of single-mode structural dynamics. This approach neglects the contribution of machine tool substructures, such as tool and holder, to the combined structural response at the cutting zone. Schmitz et al.[51] enhanced the physics-based model by coupling spindle-holder-tool structures via a lumped flexible-damped joint. However, consideration of a lumped joint considers an oversimplified assumption of the contact interface, and the interface parameters can vary by tool diameter, and clamping length, according to Matthias et al.[30]. Consequently, this limitation hinders the transferability of identified contact parameters between similar holder interfaces. As a result, it is not possible to effectively transfer parameter values between different machines with similar components at a substructure level. This paper further develops the concept of physics-based Bayesian machine learning for probabilistic refinement and inference of milling stability and offers the following primary contributions: . • The modular implementation of physical models facilitates the updating and exchange of knowledge at a substructure level. By incorporating a more realistic distributed holder-tool interface, the interface parameters are decoupled from the clamping length and tool diameter. This independence allows for establishing an information flow, e.g. between similar holders mounted on different machines, thereby enabling federated and transfer learning across a network of machine tools on a shop floor. • Predicting the informativeness allows quantification of the effectiveness of a specific process configuration in reducing model uncertainties and enables optimal allocation of computational resources in recursive online learning. Additionally, leveraging informativeness in Bayesian experimental design allows for the strategic selection of experiments that accelerate the learning process while minimizing the need for extensive training data. • The employed Evolutionary MCMC combined with simulated annealing uses multiple parallel chains, enhancing sample diversity by exploring various regions that may be inaccessible within a reasonable time frame for a single chain. This approach facilitates the implementation of interaction operators, such as crossover, that exchange information from different chains to improve the subsequent generation of samples, offering benefits such as faster convergence, exploration-exploitation trade-off, and robustness to initialization [52,53]. The remainder of the paper is structured as follows: Section 2 presents the substructure-based framework of physics-based models that are involved in structural dynamics and stability analysis. Section 3 is devoted to the fundamentals of supervised, recursive, and active Bayesian learning. Section 4 presents various implementations of Bayesian learning in milling stability and evaluation of their effectiveness using experimental cutting tests. Finally, the paper is concluded in Section 5. Physics-based stability prediction In this study, the theoretical modeling framework divides the milling machine into smaller substructures, with each representing a specific component, as is demonstrated in Fig. 1. This approach is highly advantageous for dealing with the numerous combinations of machine and process configurations commonly found in manufacturing sites. To determine the necessary inputs for predicting stability limits and chatter frequency using ZOA, a machine and process configuration vector x needs to contain the following specifications: . • Machine tool and spindle: to specify the machine tool dynamics that are experimentally measured at the spindle flange. • Holder-tool combination and stick-out length: to specify the required dimensions and material properties to create finite-element models of holder and tool and couple them according to the stick-out length. • Workpiece material: to initiate tangential K tc and radial K rc CFCs for each workpiece material-tool pair and can be assumed to be fairly similar for tools that share comparable characteristics such as cutting edge geometry, coating, and wear state. • Engagement angles: start ϕ st and exit ϕ ex angles to calculate the average value of directional dynamic milling force coefficients for ZOA solution [5,7] and can be precisely obtained by a geometrical simulation of the material removal, e.g. using commercial software such as MACHpro [54]. • Process parameters: spindle speed Ω, axial depth of cut a p , and feed direction angle ψ. As previously highlighted, obtaining tooltip dynamics is typically achieved by substructure coupling through RCSA. Fig. 2 illustrates the substructure coupling scheme for a generic machine-holder-tool structure. The dynamics at the machine tool side — including the machine tool body, spindle shaft, and HSK-A63 blank — are measured once experimentally at point 3 in Fig. 2 through the inverse RCSA approach presented by Namazi et al.[55]. The resulting dynamics is represented by the Frequency Response Function (FRF) matrix of H S,33 and contains the following entities: (1) H S , 33 = h S , 33 , t F h S , 33 , t M h S , 33 , r F h S , 33 , r M with h S,33, tF standing for the scalar complex-valued frequency-dependent receptance for translational force input at point 3 of substructure S and translational response at the same point. Analogously, other entities relate translational and rotational displacements (subscript t and r) to force and moment inputs (subscript F and M). Note that throughout this article, non-scalar values appear in a bold typeface. The machine tool FRFs are assumed to have uncoupled dynamics in X and Y directions. The same substructure coupling formulations hold for an extended FRF matrix that contains axes cross-coupling. As mentioned earlier, the use of beam models to obtain the dynamics of tool-holder assemblies is suitable due to their simple cylindrical geometry and necessary due to the frequent variation of their combinations. The required direct and cross FRFs between points 1 and 2 of the tooling system substructure T are obtained following a finite-element-based implementation of Timoshenko beam models with a distributed damped-flexible interface, as proposed by Ostad Ali Akbari et al. [31]. This method involves a multi-point coupling of the individual holder and tool in the spatial domain through the following matrix of flexible-damped contact at each coupling point: (2) k ˜ h t ( e ) = L c N c k t t ( 1 + j η t t ) 0 0 k r r ( 1 + j η r r ) with k tt and k rr standing for translational and rotational stiffness per unit length and η tt and η rr for translational and rotational displacement-dependent damping, respectively. This damped-elastic contact is distributed across the clamping length L c between N c clamping nodes. The significance of slope is disregarded due to its relevance in affecting the accuracy of higher-order bending modes, which are typically not associated with regenerative chatter. Finally, the FRFs of the machine tool and the tooling system are rigidly coupled by ensuring that their translational and rotational displacements are equal, i.e., X S,3 = X T,2, and their force and moment interactions are in equilibrium, i.e., F S,3 + F T,2 = 0 . The tooltip dynamics of the coupled structure ST can be obtained using the following RCSA formulation: (3) H S T , 11 = H T , 11 − H T , 12 ( H S , 33 + H T , 22 ) − 1 H T , 21 For stability prediction, only the translational displacement to force FRFs at the tooltip is required. If the feed direction is in the XY plane of the machine’s coordinate system and has an inclination angle of ψ with respect to the X direction, the FRFs should be projected to the feed and the normal directions, denoted as FN coordinate system. The projection can be achieved through the following mapping: (4) h S T , 11 , t F F F h S T , 11 , t F F N h S T , 11 , t F N F h S T , 11 , t F N N = cos ψ sin ψ − sin ψ cos ψ h S T , 11 , t F X X h S T , 11 , t F X Y h S T , 11 , t F Y X h S T , 11 , t F Y Y cos ψ − sin ψ sin ψ cos ψ In the end, the projected tooltip dynamics together with CFCs and other inputs are used to calculate the critical depth of cut a cr , model and chatter frequency f c, model using ZOA for the machine and process specified by x . To summarize, Table 1 outlines the uncertain model parameters associated with each machine and process configuration x . The utilization of logarithmic mappings facilitates the exploration of the parameter space and ensures parameters are transformed to comparable scales. The determination of the prior distribution of holder parameters considers feasible values estimated from sound analysis in [31]. Such wide prior distributions account for various interface types. Similarly, the prior distribution for CFCs is introduced to incorporate a comprehensive range of values for different tool-workpiece combinations. The vector θ contains a unique set of these uncertain model parameters for all process configurations x 1:n = { x 1, x 2, …, x n } involved in a learning cycle. On the other hand, the chatter detection system monitors the cutting process at each machine and process configuration x and provides the corresponding monitoring vector y containing: . • Stability state of the process (s): assumes a binary value with 1 and 0 representing experimental unstable and stable states, respectively. • Experimental chatter frequency (f c ): only available in case of unstable process. Probabilistic learning and inference Bayesian statistics employs probability distributions to quantify the level of uncertainty associated with the potential outcomes of a random variable. The uncertainty of the model, also known as epistemic uncertainty, arises due to the insufficient amount or quality of training data for improving the model accuracy. This concept is particularly important in the refinement of stability predictions, where the availability of experimental data is often limited. This section introduces Bayesian learning for updating model parameters based on experimental observations with a tailored likelihood function for milling stability. This allows for probabilistic inference to determine the probability of process stability. Also, active learning is introduced for optimal data collection and a faster reduction in model uncertainty. Bayesian learning In Bayesian learning, the goal is to update a prior distribution of parameters P( θ ) to an updated distribution called the posterior P( θ ∣ y 1:n , x 1:n ) given the observation likelihood P( y 1:n ∣ x 1:n ; θ ) using the Bayes rule: (5) P ( θ ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) = 1 Z P ( y 1 : n ∣ x 1 : n ; θ ) P ( θ ) and Z represents a scalar value to normalize the summation of probabilities and is the marginal probability of data under all possible model parameters: (6) Z = ∫ P ( y 1 : n ∣ x 1 : n ; θ ) P ( θ ) d θ The computation of Z involves computing high-dimensional integrals over the parameter domain and is intractable. As the computation of the posterior probability is possible up to this normalizing factor, the unnormalized version of the posterior probability is usually sufficient: (7) q ( θ ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) = P ( y 1 : n ∣ x 1 : n ; θ ) P ( θ ) Recursive Bayesian learning The recursive Bayesian model updating approach is particularly well-suited for online applications that involve sequential observations and require refinement of the model parameters with each new observation. The equation (8) P ( n + 1 ) ( θ ) = 1 Z P ( y n + 1 ∣ x n + 1 ; θ ) P ( n ) ( θ ) represents the recursive implementation of Bayesian model updating with P (n)( θ ) being the posterior distribution after the first n observations, i.e. P (n)( θ ) = P( θ ∣ y 1:n , x 1:n ). As the equation explains, the posterior after n observations becomes the prior for the next updating iteration when (n + 1)th data arrives. Likelihood function for stability refinement The likelihood function is defined as the probability of random variable realizations conditional on particular values of the model parameters. Therefore, the likelihood of a given sample indicates which parameter values are more likely than others, in terms of making the observed data more probable. The total likelihood of n observations, given a single sample of the model parameter vector θ j , is (9) P ( y 1 : n ∣ x 1 : n ; θ j ) = ∏ i = 1 n s i P s ( s i = 1 ∣ x i ; θ j ) P f ( f c , i ∣ x i ; θ j ) + ( 1 − s i ) P s ( s i = 0 ∣ x i ; θ j ) It is worth noting that the first term in the likelihood function accounts for unstable observations and considers both the stability state and chatter frequency, whereas the second term only incorporates the stability state for stable observations. The likelihood of observing a particular stability state s i at configuration x i is computed based on comparing its depth of cut a p ( x i ) to the model-predicted critical depth of cut a cr , model ( x i ; θ j ) for a given sample of model parameters θ j . This likelihood is established using a logistic (sigmoid) function defined as follows: (10) P s ( s i = 1 ∣ x i ; θ j ) = 1 ∕ 1 + exp a c r , m o d e l ( x i ; θ j ) − a p ( x i ) k and k adjusts the steepness of the state transition at stability borders. Since P s (s i ∣ x i ; θ j ) has a Bernoulli distribution, therefore: (11) P s ( s i = 0 ∣ x i ; θ j ) = 1 − P s ( s i = 1 ∣ x i ; θ j ) Moreover, the additional likelihood for unstable observations is defined by considering the experimental chatter frequency f c,i in relation to the corresponding model-predicted chatter frequency f c, model ( x i ; θ j ) for the given x i and θ j . This likelihood is established using a normal Gaussian distribution as follows: (12) P f ( f c , i ∣ x i ; θ j ) = 1 σ f 2 π exp − ( f c , i − f c , m o d e l ( x i ; θ j ) ) 2 2 σ f 2 and σ f accounts for possible uncertainties in the precision of the chatter detection system. Evolutionary Markov Chain Monte Carlo (EMCMC) MCMC is widely used for sampling from complex posterior distributions that are difficult to evaluate analytically. The primary goal of MCMC is to produce a sequence of samples that follow a Markov chain, where each state in the chain depends only on the preceding state. The efficiency and convergence rate of the chain is influenced by various factors, including the proposal distribution and the initial state of the chain. Various techniques have been developed to enhance the efficiency of MCMC. For instance, the stochastic gradient Langevin dynamics method leverages stochastic gradient information to steer the chain towards regions of high probability for the target posterior distribution [56]. Evolutionary algorithms are an effective means of discovering globally optimal regions in a search space. Their primary advantage is that they do not require gradient computation, which can be advantageous in non-differentiable non-convex problems, e.g. in physics-based stability prediction in milling. Evolutionary algorithms operate on a combination of crossover, which allows different populations to share information, and mutation, which enables the algorithm to explore the search space more thoroughly to discover the globally optimal region. The publication by Katoch et al. [57] provides a comprehensive review over evolutionary operators and their implementations. EMCMC combines the idea from evolutionary algorithms with MCMC and uses evolutionary operators, crossover and mutation, to guide the exploration of the parameter space to collect samples from regions with high posterior probability. Let { Θ n g e n } with n gen = 1, 2, …, N gen represent generations of populations with each population containing multiple individuals as Θ n g e n = { θ n g e n , n p o p } for n pop = 1, 2, …, N pop . The fitness function of a parameter vector θ j is defined as the negative of the log-posterior from Eq. (7) as: (13) F ( θ j ) = − log q ( θ j ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) The evolutionary operators of crossover and mutation produce new offspring, which are represented as { θ ˜ n g e n , n p o p } . To determine which individuals will be selected for the next generation, a survival strategy must be defined. The survival strategy employed in evolutionary algorithms can vary across implementations; for example, single-objective genetic optimization often utilizes fitness sorting, while non-dominated sorting is used in multi-objective optimization in NSGA-II [58]. When using evolutionary algorithms for sampling purposes, it is necessary to employ a different survival strategy to ensure an appropriate distribution for a Monte Carlo approximation. Drugan and Thierens [59] provided a review over various implementations of EMCMC. Inspired by Marwala et al. [60] proposing an implementation of the EMCMC combined with simulated annealing technique, the survival is defined based on the Metropolis criterion [61,62] as (14) r n g e n , n p o p = exp F ( θ n g e n , n p o p ) − F ( θ ˜ n g e n , n p o p ) T n g e n where an offspring is selected with a probability of min ( 1 , r n g e n , n p o p ) . T n g e n denotes the annealing temperature, which decreases as n gen increases. A higher temperature in early generations allows greater exploration of the search space, whereas a cooler temperature in later generations emphasizes more on sampling around regions of high posterior probability that have already been discovered. The cooling schedule is defined as follows: (15) T n g e n = ( T max − 1 ) 1 − n g e n N g e n γ + 1 that suggests a polynomial decay of the annealing temperature from T max for the first to 1 for the last generation. The hyperparameter γ adjusts the cooling rate. To implement the algorithm for this study, Pymoo [63] library is employed. Probabilistic inference The probability distributions are approximated using the samples drawn from the posterior distribution by EMCMC, i.e. θ j ∼ P( θ ∣ y 1:n , x 1:n ). To perform Monte Carlo approximations, the first portion of samples is discarded according to a burn-in number N burn-in during which the distribution of the EMCMC does not yet approximate the posterior distribution well, while the remaining m samples are retained. The probabilistic stability map, which determines the posterior probability of the stability state at each configuration, is obtained through the following Monte Carlo approximation: (16) P ( s * ∣ x * , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) = ∫ P s ( s * ∣ x * , θ ) P ( θ ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) d θ = E θ ∼ p ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n [ P s ( s * ∣ x * , θ ) ] ≈ 1 m ∑ j = 1 m P s ( s * ∣ x * , θ j ) with E θ ∼ p ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n [ P s ( s * ∣ x * , θ ) ] representing the expectation of P s (s * ∣ x *, θ ) when θ is drawn according to its posterior distribution, θ ∼ p∣ y 1:n , x 1:n to be short. The notations •* represent an evaluating process configuration whose stability state is of interest. The process conditions over a grid of spindle speed and depth of cut can be considered to create a full probabilistic map of the stability states. Similarly, a probabilistic map for chatter frequency can be created: (17) P ( f c * ∣ x * , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) = ∫ P f ( f c * ∣ x * , θ ) P ( θ ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) d θ = E θ ∼ p ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n [ P f ( f c * ∣ x * , θ ) ] ≈ 1 m ∑ j = 1 m P f ( f c * ∣ x * , θ j ) Ultimately, the posterior distribution of model parameters is estimated by a family of independent Gaussian distributions, i.e. multivariate normal distributions with zero off-diagonal terms in the covariance matrix, by calculating the mean and standard deviation of the collected parameter samples θ j . Active learning In supervised learning, the model relies on passively collected training data to learn or refine the underlying model. However, the quality of the resulting model is influenced by the quantity and relevance of the information contained within the training dataset. The passively collected data may not always include the most valuable information for model improvement, as it is gathered without considering its potential impact or informativeness. Active learning [64], in contrast, adopts a more proactive approach where the model actively seeks the most informative data for the next training iteration. This approach is motivated by the need to optimize resources spent on data collection and processing, and to reduce the model’s epistemic uncertainty in the most efficient and quickest manner. Bayesian Active Learning by Disagreement (BALD) [65,66] suggests a sequential decision process to select the next data collection at a point where the information gain is maximized for model parameters in a classification task. The acquisition function of the active learning is customized for the experimental data collection in the refinement of milling stability prediction as: (18) x n + 1 = argmin x a p ( x ) S u b j e c t t o : I ( θ ; s ∣ x , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) − λ max x ′ I ( θ ; s ′ ∣ x ′ , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) ≥ 0 with I representing the information gain as will be defined in the following. This acquisition function aims to recommend the next experimental point with the consideration of the minimum axial depth of cut a p ( x ) while having at least λ ∈ (0, 1] proportion of the maximum attainable information gain. This manner encourages the algorithm to prioritize conservative recommendations that are more likely to be stable or unstable points with low depth of cut, in order to alleviate the potential negative consequences of chatter. The symmetry of the information gain implies that I ( θ ; s ∣ x , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) = I ( s ; θ ∣ x , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) which facilitates the computations. The information gain or informativeness is then defined as: (19) I ( s ; θ ∣ x , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) = H s ∣ x , y 1 : n , x 1 : n − E θ ∼ P ( θ ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) H s ∣ x , θ The notation H refers to the entropy of a random variable and provides a measure of its associated uncertainty. Information gain is a measure of the anticipated reduction in entropy after some particular observation will be acquired. The first term in Eq. (19) represents the overall marginal entropy, whereas the second term corresponds to the expected conditional entropy. The calculation of the total marginal entropy is given by: (20) H [ s ∣ x , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ] = − ∑ c ∈ { 0 , 1 } P ( s = c ∣ x , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) log 2 P ( s = c ∣ x , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) which requires the calculations of marginal probabilities using the following equation and the corresponding Monte Carlo estimation: (21) P ( s = c ∣ x , y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) = ∫ P ( s = c ∣ x , θ ) P ( θ ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) d θ ≈ 1 m ∑ i = 1 m P ( s = c ∣ x , θ j ) On the other hand, the estimated value of the conditional entropy is obtained from the following equation and then approximated using a Monte Carlo approximation: (22) E θ ∼ P ( θ ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) [ H [ s ∣ x , θ ] ] = − E θ ∼ P ( θ ∣ y 1 : n , x 1 : n ) [ ∑ c ∈ { 0 , 1 } P ( s = c ∣ x , θ ) log 2 P ( s = c ∣ x , θ ) ] ≈ − 1 m ∑ i = 1 m ∑ c ∈ { 0 , 1 } P ( s = c ∣ x , θ j ) log 2 P ( s = c ∣ x , θ j ) Further details can be found in [65,67]. Implementations and validations This section is devoted to introducing and validating various implementations of the model-supported Bayesian framework. The algorithm implementation can be summarized in the following steps: 1. Detect similarities and shared substructures among the process configurations of interest x 1:n . For example, if multiple tool-holder combinations involve the same holder, a single set of holder parameters will be initiated and shared across them. Analogously, if the same tool-workpiece material is found in multiple operations, CFCs are shared between them, i.e. θ = [ p 1 h o l d e r 1 , p 2 h o l d e r 1 , p 3 h o l d e r 1 , … , p 4 t o o l − w p 1 , p 5 t o o l − w p 1 , … ] . 2. Initialize the physics-based model. The illustration of how components are shared and combined to form the machine and process is provided in Fig. 1. The physics-based model will be used to calculate the axial depth of stability border a cr , model ( x i ; θ j ) and chatter frequency f c, model ( x i ; θ j ) for a parameter sample θ j and process configuration of interest x i . 3. EMCMC utilizes prior probabilities P( θ j ) and the likelihood function P( y 1:n ∣ x 1:n ; θ j ), Eq. (9), to collect samples from high-probable parameter space, driven by the fitness function Eq. (13). 4. The collected samples { θ j } by the EMCMC are used to estimate the posterior parameter distributions and to generate probabilistic stability maps, through Eq. (16) and Eq. (17), and information gain diagrams through Eq. (19). The validation process is carried out through experimental cutting tests on a GF Mikron HPM800U 5-axis milling machine with a variety of tool-holder combinations and process strategies. The holders used in the validation stage are listed in Table 2, which have been selected to assess the performance of the proposed approaches on distinct collet interfaces. The selected tools in Table 3 include two flat-end mills with similar cutting-edge geometry, coating, and wear state. This provides an existence of similarity for their CFCs when machining AL6082 workpiece material, for later case studies. Table 4 provides a summary of the machine and process configurations that have been taken into consideration for the case studies. This specifies the corresponding x with tool-holder combination, stick-out length, and process parameters required to define a scenario for calculating SLDs. Table 5 also provides the hyperparameters of the learning algorithm. Fig. 3 contains the probabilistic stability maps for the three distinct holder interfaces, which are generated using the general prior distribution of model parameters outlined in Table 1. These maps show an unreliable and highly uncertain inference of prior stability states and chatter frequencies, emphasizing the need for model refinement using experimental data. It should be noted that process configuration 1 from Table 4 is selected as a benchmark to evaluate the effectiveness of various Bayesian learning implementations. Also, Table 6 includes the experimental data points used for training in the subsequent sections. Supervised learning from offline dataset This section investigates the effectiveness of the proposed Bayesian model updating framework in supervised learning across three different holder interfaces. Fig. 4 illustrates several scenarios related to this investigation. In the provided figure, the probabilistic map of stability states (a p -Ω plane) denotes the marginal probability of stability states P(s * ∣ x *, y 1:n , x 1:n ), which is calculated using Eq. (16) at each x * over a grid that covers the a p -Ω plane. The dataset of experimental data { y 1:n , x 1:n }, which was used for refining the model parameter probability distributions, is also depicted as highlighted points in the figure. Likewise, the probability of chatter frequency P(f c *∣ x *, y 1:n , x 1:n ) is generated using Eq. (17) and depicted in the f c -Ω plane. The validation cuts are performed experimentally and their stability states and chatter frequencies are recorded through process noise analysis recorded by a microphone. Further information on chatter detection methods can be found in a review article by Wang et al. [68]. Based on the results presented in Fig. 4, the effectiveness of the model refinement is highly dependent on the quality of the training dataset. In case (a), a poor dataset consisting of only stable cuts is utilized. While the location of the stable cuts may aid the algorithm in roughly identifying stability pocket locations, the confidence in classification is low, visible by a wide spread of the grey shades, due to insufficient information content of the training data. In cases (b) and (c), the inclusion of both stable and chatter cuts in training provides the algorithm with valuable information regarding chatter frequency, which is particularly beneficial for updating structural dynamics. However, it is important to note that the updated model is relatively unsure of stability states at locations on the stability maps that could not be confined by the experimental training samples. For example, in case (b), the model is uncertain about the stability states in the area between the stable and unstable training points. In conclusion, the proposed Bayesian model updating framework, supported by physical models, is highly effective in refining stability charts, even with poor training datasets. The framework can suggest highly productive stable process parameters to the machine operator based on the level of risk they are willing to take. It is worth mentioning that the full sampling procedure and generation of probabilistic stability maps for a training task were completed in around 38 s on an Intel core i7–9700 CPU. Federated learning and knowledge transfer In manufacturing industries, it is often the case that several CNC machines are present on the shop floor, and they may use similar holders, tools, or workpiece materials in their production. The federated learning concept offers a collaborative platform for all production machines to share their process monitoring data and simultaneously learn and refine their stability models. The substructuring framework, presented in Section 2, has empowered the algorithm to identify common substructures among all involved machines and processes to establish the connections for learning their uncertain parameters simultaneously. This allows the machines to learn from each other and accelerate the learning process, which can ultimately lead to improved process efficiency and product quality for all of them. Furthermore, the federated learning platform enables knowledge transfer for a more reliable initial estimation of stability states for new machine and process configurations for which no experimental training data has yet been collected. The federated and transfer learning concept is demonstrated in Fig. 5. Fig. 6 presents a scenario of federated learning, where cases (a) and (c) share the same holder and thus the same holder parameters. Additionally, all three cases use the same tool and cut the same workpiece material, thus having the same CFCs. The simultaneous model updating process involves only three experimental data points, one from each case. Despite the limited training data, the synergy created by the federated learning approach helped all cases to improve their stability predictions simultaneously, as is evident by comparing the experimental validation cuts and the refined probabilistic stability maps. In order to further illustrate the benefits of federated learning, the process configuration is kept constant for case (a) in both Fig. 4 and Fig. 6. By comparing the resulting posterior probabilistic stability maps, it can be seen that federated learning could lead to more accurate and reliable posterior predictions, e.g., the two stable points at a p = 1.25mm are predicted to be stable with higher certainty in Fig. 6 than in Fig. 4, despite the federated learning being provided with fewer training data points from their corresponding cutting scenario 1 (in Table 4) compared to the individual supervised learning in Fig. 4. The validity of the resulting posterior parameters in Fig. 7 is further assessed by comparing the variations of the modeled tooltip dynamics against impulse hammer measurements. The Monte Carlo simulation in Fig. 8 shows that the samples of the predicted FRFs are concentrated in the vicinity of the experimental FRFs, thus confirming the validity of the posteriors. Transfer learning is performed by using the posterior model parameters obtained from the federated learning (shown in Fig. 7) as priors for new process configurations where experimental training data is not yet available. Fig. 9 demonstrates three case studies where probabilistic stability maps are obtained via transfer learning. It is evident from the results that their prior predictions, i.e. with no consideration of training data in those special configurations, already have a satisfactory agreement with validation cuts. Recursive online learning and active learning Recursive Bayesian learning can be an effective technique for refining stability predictions in an online setting. As described in Section 3.2, this involves continuously monitoring process stability during arbitrary cuts and incorporating experimental data into the model to refine the probabilistic stability predictions. However, it may not be computationally efficient to perform a Bayesian updating iteration after acquiring each experimental record during an arbitrary cut, as the data may not contain enough information to improve the model. Instead, an informativeness diagram can be used to assess the informativeness of each collected data point and decide when enough informative samples have been collected to justify a Bayesian updating iteration. Fig. 10 represents a graphical summary of the recursive learning concept, and the flowchart shown in Fig. 11 demonstrates how the recursive Bayesian learning algorithm is implemented. Section 3.6 demonstrated that active learning relies on information gain to generate an acquisition function that enables informed sampling. The acquisition function in Eq. (18) is used for a recursive active learning case study in Fig. 13. Fig. 12 exemplifies the trade-off made by the acquisition function in recommending conservative experiments while considering informativeness. Referring to Fig. 13(a) is the informativeness diagram computed from the highly-uncertain priors of Table 1 before any training. The active learning acquisition function from Eq. (18) suggests the next training data collection at the spindle speed of 18870 [rpm] and depth of cut of 0.57 [mm]. This point is experimentally stable and is considered as a training point to compute the posterior stability prediction in (d) and the informativeness diagram (b). This procedure is continued for three iterations with the same pattern to gain the ultimate posterior stability prediction of (f). After training on three intelligently selected data points the model has swiftly reached to the precise and reliable stability predictions of (f). Conclusions This paper presented a constructive combination of physics-based and data-driven approaches to address the poor prediction accuracy of analytical models and the extensive effort required for experimental approaches. The Bayesian perspective acknowledges that the key model parameters correspond to a degree of uncertainty due to the limited understanding of real-world systems. This uncertainty is encountered by distributions of belief over potential parameter values. The novel integration of physics into the likelihood function enabled more effective learning by refining the model parameter distributions according to their agreement with experimental training data. The resulting probabilistic stability predictions may allow machine operators to balance their production rate and chatter risk. Additionally, the introduced online learning platform provided the means of refining stability predictions recursively through continuous process monitoring. Finally, the more effective closed-loop active learning method was introduced to drive the data collection process for accelerated learning of underlying models and improving stability predictions. In the end, the experimental validations revealed the effectiveness of the proposed methods in improving stability predictions, even with extremely poor training datasets. The method solely necessitates a microphone for monitoring processes and gathering data, making it an industrial-friendly solution. The successful implementation of the proposed approaches can potentially have a significant value creation for manufacturing industries, where accurate stability predictions are critical for enhancing production rates while eliminating costly damages from chatter.
