A high-performance voting-based ensemble model of graph convolutional extreme learning machines for identifying geochemical anomalies related to mineralization Jiaxing Chen Yongliang Chen ⁎ College of Earth Sciences, Jilin University, Changchun 130061, China College of Earth Sciences Jilin University Changchun 130061 China College of Earth Sciences, Jilin University, Changchun 130061, China ⁎ Corresponding author. How to effectively identify mineralization anomalies from geochemical survey data is one of the key problems that must be properly solved in geochemical exploration. Although supervised machine learning and deep learning techniques have been adopted to solve this problem, the performance of the established mineralization anomaly identification models is not satisfactory because the mutual relationship between neighborhood data points is not taken into account in the modeling of geochemical exploration data. The graph convolutional extreme learning machines (GCELMs) provide a new technique for modeling the graph data transformed from geochemical exploration data. To improve the performance of mineralization anomaly identification algorithms, the GCELM techniques were adopted to establish the supervised classification models for identifying mineralization anomalies from geochemical exploration data. To improve the robustness of the GCELM models in mineralization anomaly identification, an ensemble classification model called voting-based GCELM (V-GCELM) model was established by voting the outputs of multiple GCELM models. The Baishan area of Jilin Province (China) was taken as the study area for carrying out an experiment of mineralization anomaly identification from geochemical exploration data. The synthetic minority over-sampling technique (SMOTE) was used to alleviate the class-imbalance of the training data. The GCELM model, V-GCELM model and extreme learning machine (ELM) model were established for identifying mineralization anomalies, and their performances were compared in terms of the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves, area under the curves (AUCs) and lift indices. The results show that the V-GCELM model has the best performance, and its AUC and lift index are 0.9989 and 28.6, respectively. The GCELM model has the second-best performance, and its AUC and lift index are 0.9977 and 20.1, respectively. The ELM model has the worst but still high performance, its AUC and lift index are 0.9402 and 9.2, respectively. The mineralization anomalies identified by the three models have close spatial correlation with the polymetallic deposits found in the study area, and spatially controlled by the main controlling factors in the study area. Therefore, GCELM and V-GCELM are promising techniques for building the high-performance classification models for identifying mineralization anomalies from geochemical exploration data. Keywords Extreme learning machine Graph convolutional extreme learning machine Voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine Synthetic minority oversampling technique Geochemical exploration data Mineralization anomaly identification Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Geochemical exploration is an important part of mineral resources exploration. In the past decades, many new mineral deposits have been found in China using geochemical exploration techniques. Geochemical survey data plays an indispensable role in mineral resource exploration. Identification of mineralization anomalies from geochemical survey data is a key step for mineral exploration targeting. Mineralization anomalies can provide important insights into the interdependencies and co-variations of chemical elements in mineralization systems (Hawkes and Webb, 1963a; Cheng et al., 1994; Reimann et al., 2005; Carranza, 2011; Agterberg et al., 2014). How to effectively identify mineralization anomalies from geochemical survey data is one of the key problems that must be properly solved in geochemical exploration. The application of contemporary scientific theory and technology to the modeling of exploration geochemical data can reveal the complex spatial correlation between mineralization and metallogenic indicator elements, and provide scientific basis for identifying mineralization anomalies. Machine learning and deep learning techniques have been increasingly employed to model geochemical exploration data to identify patterns and extract insights from massive geochemical data sets for effectively targeting mineral prospective areas. The machine learning methods used for geochemical anomaly identification mainly include one-class support vector machine (Chen and Wu, 2017a), Gaussian mixture model (Chen and Wu, 2019), K-nearest neighbor method (Chen et al., 2021a), distance anomaly factor (Chen et al., 2021b), bat-optimized isolation forest method (Chen et al., 2021c), dictionary learning (Chen and Shayilan, 2022), self-paced ensemble algorithm (Chen et al., 2023a) and self-training support vector classifier (Chen et al., 2023b). The deep learning methods mainly include deep autoencoder network (Xiong and Zuo, 2016), deep variational autoencoder network (Luo et al., 2020), deep convolutional neural network (Zhang et al., 2021) and Bayesian convolutional neural network (Huang et al., 2022). The above-mentioned machine learning and deep learning techniques can be divided into three categories: unsupervised, supervised and semi-supervised learning. Unsupervised machine learning techniques, such as one-class support vector machine (Chen and Wu, 2017a) and Gaussian mixture model (Chen and Wu, 2019), identify not mineralization anomalies but geochemical anomalies because they do not take known mineralization information into account when modeling geochemical exploration data. Supervised machine learning and deep learning techniques, such as deep convolutional neural network (Zhang et al., 2021) and Bayesian convolutional neural network (Huang et al., 2022), identify mineralization anomalies by making use of known mineralization information in modeling geochemical exploration data. However, the performance of these supervised techniques is often affected by the class-imbalance of geochemical exploration data. In addition, deep learning techniques typically require a large amount of labeled data for effective training, which may not be readily available for geochemical anomaly detection tasks (Zhang et al., 2021). Semi-supervised learning techniques, such as self-paced ensemble algorithm (Chen et al., 2023a) and self-training support vector classifier (Chen et al., 2023b), can generally establish high-performance mineralization anomaly identification models because their performance is not affected by class-imbalance of geochemical exploration data. However, these semi-supervised learning techniques often ignore the correlation between neighborhood data points when modeling geochemical exploration data, which reduces the robustness of the mineralization anomaly identification models. Graph representation learning methods provide a flexible approach to manage complex relationships and dependencies within geochemical exploration data. Graphs, generally comprising nodes and edges, have powerful abstraction capabilities and can encode various data types, including geochemical exploration data. Graphs also effectively capture intricate and nonlinear spatial relationships among multiple nodes and their edges. Graph convolutional networks (GCNs) leverage spatial relationships between nodes to extract geological features, such as distance and connectivity, improving the performance of mineral prospectivity mapping models (Guan et al., 2022). The graph convolutional extreme learning machines (GCELM) (Zhang et al., 2020, 2023) are hybrid methods that integrate GCNs with extreme learning machine (ELM) (Huang et al., 2006; Chen and Wu, 2017b) to solve graph data classification problems. The methods have the advantages of both GCNs and ELMs in solving supervised classification problems. By considering adjacency relationships, the GCELM model transforms traditional Euclidean data into graph data and processes information through graph convolution embedding and regression layers (Zhang et al., 2020, 2023). The GCELM framework inherits the benefits of classical ELM and GCNs. ELMs capture complex patterns and nonlinear relationships in high-dimensional data by modeling graph data, and surmount the limitations of traditional machine learning methods. GCNs extract spatial features and global dependencies. GCELM offers an interpretable model, enabling a comprehension of the decision-making process. Therefore, in this study, GCELM was adopted to model the graph data transformed from geochemical exploration data for identifying mineralization anomalies from geochemical exploration data. To improve the robustness of the GCELM model in the identification of mineralization anomalies, a voting-based ensemble GCELM model (V-GCELM) was built based on multiple GCELM models for identifying mineralization anomalies. The V-GCELM model makes decisions through majority voting among the results of independent GCELM models, and the final class label is assigned to the category with the highest probability (Zhang et al., 2023). Since supervised classification algorithms often struggle with class imbalance of the training data set in geochemical exploration, the synthetic minority over-sampling technique (SMOTE) (Chawla et al., 2002) was used to alleviate the class imbalance of geochemical exploration data. A case study of applying GCELM and V-GCELM techniques to identify mineralization anomalies from geochemical exploration data was carried out in the Baishan area of Jilin Province, China. The ELM model, GCELM model and V-GCELM model were established on the 1:200,000 stream sediment survey data collected in the study area. The performance of the three models for mineralization anomaly identification was compared in terms of receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves, area under the curves (AUCs) and lift indices (Chen et al., 2014, 2021c, 2023b; Chen and Wu, 2016, 2017a, 2019; Chen and Shayilan, 2022). The main contribution of this study is to adopt the new graph data modeling techniques, GCELM and V-GCELM, to establish a high-performance GCELM model and a high-performance robust V-GCELM model to effectively identify mineralization anomalies from geochemical exploration data, and provides an experimental case study to show the superiority of GCELM and V-GCELM techniques in identifying mineralization anomalies from high-dimensional geochemical exploration data. 2 Study area and data 2.1 Study area The Baishan area of Jilin Province (China) tectonically lies in the northern margin of the North China Platform, which covers four 1:200,000 standard geological maps. The area has experienced a long and intricate geological tectonic evolution history from Archean to Mesozoic (Zhao et al., 1993; Liu et al., 2000; Wu et al., 2005; Zhang et al., 2006; Qin et al., 2014). Throughout the geological evolution history, various geological formations were formed in the study area. Granite-greenstone and upper crustal rock assemblages were first formed in the study area during the Archean period, which constitute the paleo-crystalline basement (Wu, 1992; Zhang et al., 2011). Early and late rift formation assemblages were formed in the study area during the Paleoproterozoic period, which include the Ji'an Group formed in the early rift and the Laoling Group formed in the late rift. Sedimentary formations were formed in study area during the period from the Late Proterozoic to the Paleozoic. Volcanic-sedimentary assemblages were formed in the study area during the Mesozoic period (Zheng, 1995; Liu et al., 2000; Wu et al., 2005; Liu et al., 2009). Among these geological formations, the Archean metamorphic formations and Mesozoic volcanic-sedimentary formations have the largest scale of exposure, accounting for about 25 % and 50 % of the whole study area, respectively. The study area belongs to the polymetallic metallogenic belt in the northern margin of the North China Platform (Yang et al., 1999), and 30 polymetallic deposits (occurrences) have been found (Fig. 1 ). The genetic type of the polymetallic deposits (occurrences) is mainly the post-magmatic hydrothermal type deposit, which is genetically related to the tectonic-magmatic activity occurred in Mesozoic. The main ore forming elements of polymetallic mineralization in the study area include gold, copper, lead, zinc, cobalt and molybdenum. The polymetallic mineralization occurred in the study area is mainly controlled by post-magmatic hydrothermal activity, regional faults and Archean metamorphic rocks (Wu, 1992; Zhang et al., 2011). The Mesozoic magmatic activity provided the continuous heat source, hydrothermal fluid, and some ore-forming materials for polymetallic mineralization (Zheng, 1995; Liu et al., 2000; Wu et al., 2005; Liu et al., 2009). Archean metamorphic rocks constitute the source rocks of polymetallic mineralization and contribute most of ore-forming materials (Wu, 1992; Zhang et al., 2011). Regional faults are the migration channels and deposition space of mineralization-related hydrothermal fluids. 2.2 Geochemical survey data The 1:200,000 scale regional geochemical mapping project completed in the study area in 1990 s is in accordance with the standard for geochemical surveys (No. DZ/T0011-91) (Xie et al., 1997). A total of 6,608 valid stream sediment samples (Fig. 2 ) were collected in an area of approximately 26,500 km2. Each sample was analyzed for 35 major and trace elements. The unit of Ag and Au concentrations is 10-9; the unit of the remaining 27 elements is 10-6; and the unit of 6 oxides is 10-2. The mean, variance, and variability of each element were estimated based on the element concentration data of the 6608 samples (Table 1 ). To facilitate the mineral exploration process, the entire study area was divided into 100 × 150 unit cells. By referring to the spatial resolution of the unit cells, the stream sediment survey data were interpolated using the Inverse Distance to a Power method in Golden Software Surfer. The power value of 2 was selected to control the weight decreasing speed, and the search radius of 0.06 was chosen to control the number of samples used for estimating the element concentration value of the grid point. The grid points generated by the interpolation coincide with the centers of the corresponding unit cells. Accordingly, each grid point represents a unit size of 1.2167 × 1.6365 square kilometers. At the spatial resolution of the unit cells generated in this study, it can be determined that the 30 polymetallic deposits found in the study area are spatially distributed in 30 different unit cells. Consequently, only 30 grid points are polymetallic mineralized grid points. These 30 mineralized grid points were defined as positive instances, while the remaining grid points except for the grid points in blank areas were defined as negative instances. Due to the presence of undiscovered polymetallic deposits in the study area, a few of the negative instances defined in this study actually belong to positive instances, but are incorrectly defined as negative instances. These wrongly defined instances make up the noise in negative instances. Since the percentage of noise in negative instances is very small, these noise individuals do not significantly affect the overall statistical characteristics of negative instance population. Therefore,positive andnegative instancescan be used asthe ground truth dataforROC curve analysisto evaluate the performance of the classification models established for identifyingmineralization anomalies. 3 Methodology 3.1 Extreme learning machine A classical ELM is a non-traditional training algorithm for a single hidden layer feedforward neural network (Huang et al., 2006; Ding et al., 2015; Chen and Wu, 2017b, Wang et al., 2022). Unlike the traditional neural networks training algorithm that iteratively updates interlayer weights through backpropagation, in ELM, the weights between the input layer and hidden layer are determined by random initialization, and then the least squares method is used to learn the weights between the hidden layer and output layer, resulting in a fast-training process in its learning stage and a fast inference in its testing stage. One of the advantages of the ELM algorithm is that the parameters of each neuron can be randomly initialized at the beginning of training and fixed thereafter, thus avoiding the repeated parameter adjustments required in traditional artificial neural networks. Given N instinct training instances x i , t i , where x i ∈ R n and t i ∈ R m with i = 1, 2, …, N, the linear ELM algorithm is defined as (1) ∑ i = 1 N ∼ β i f i x j = ∑ i = 1 N ∼ β i f a i · x j + b i = t j , j = 1 , ⋯ , N where f x represents an activation function such as sigmoid, tanh, or radial basis function (RBF), N ∼ denotes the number of hidden neurons, a i is the input weight vector connecting the i th hidden neuron, b i is its bias, β i is the output weight vector connecting the i th hidden neuron, x i and x j (i, j = 1, 2, …, N) are the ith and jth training instances respectively, and a i · x j represents the inner product of a i and x j . The N equations in Eq. (1) can be written in the matrix form as follows: (2) H β = T where H is the hidden layer output matrix, and each column of H represents the output of the corresponding hidden neuron with respect to the inputs x 1 , . . . , x N . The solution β ^ of Eq. (2) can be obtained by solving the following equations: β ^ = H T where H denotes the generalized inverse matrix (Moore-Penrose generalized inverse matrix) of H . The ELM algorithm consists of the following three steps: Step 1. Define the number of hidden neurons N ∼ , randomly generate input weights a i and hidden biases b i (i = 1, 2, …, N ∼ ). Step 2. Calculate the hidden layer output matrix H . Step 3. Solve the linear equation H β = T using the least square method to determine the optimal output weight β . 3.2 Graph convolutional extreme learning machine GCELM (Zhang et al., 2023) is a novel graph-based semi-supervised learning approach that combines the merits of GCNs and ELMs. The GCELM technique models graph data and attempts to leverage both the structure and node features to create an efficient learning classifier. The GCELM model provides a powerful and efficient framework for graph data classification, effectively combining the strengths of GCNs and ELMs. Its ability to handle both semi-supervised and supervised classification tasks make it a versatile and valuable tool in practical applications. GCELM first represents the Euclidean data as an undirected K -nearest neighbor graph (Kipf and Welling, 2016; Majumdar, 2018). Each data point is regarded as a node v i in the graph, and edges are determined by finding the K -nearest neighbors. The adjacency matrix A of the graph is constructed based on the neighborhood relationships. GCELM consists of two main layers. One layer is the randomized graph convolutional embedding layer, and the other is the graph convolutional regression layer (Zhang et al., 2023). Random graph convolution refers to randomly initializing weights for each neighboring node in each graph convolution operation and randomly selecting a portion of neighboring nodes to participate in the convolution operation instead of using all neighboring nodes. According to Zhang et al. (2023), the randomized graph convolutional operation can preserve structured information, and the features transformed by the random graph convolution always show better discriminative power than the original features with good diversity. Compared with the common GCN operation, the randomized graph convolutional operation does not need to iteratively update the trainable parameters using gradient descent. Incorporating the randomized graph convolutional operation into ELM not only improves the training speed, but also adapts better to different graph structures and data distributions, and improves the robustness and generalization performance of the classification model. The randomized graph convolutional embedding layer generates a random embedding matrix H for the input graph data to extract high-dimensional features of the graph nodes. It performs a random graph convolution on the input feature matrix X using a randomly initialized weight matrix W as follows: (3) H = σ AXW where A ¯ is the symmetric normalized adjacency matrix and σ ∙ is the sigmoid activation function. Superior to the random mapping of ELM, the randomized graph convolutional embedding utilizes the graph structure and is robust to noisy data points. Based on the embedding matrix H and the labels of nodes, the output weight matrix β can be obtained by solving the following ridge regression problem: (4) y = A H β According to the ELM theory (Huang et al., 2006), the closed-form solution for β can be expressed as (5) β = H ∼ T H ∼ + λ I - 1 H ∼ T Y T N T ⩾ L H ∼ T H ∼ H ∼ T + λ I N T - 1 Y T N T < L where λ is the regularization coefficient, L is the dimension of the matrix H , I N T is denoted as a unit matrix of size NT , and the superscript T denotes the transpose of the matrix. In Eq. (5), H ∼ and Y contain both labeled and unlabeled entries, H ∼ and Y are divided into labeled ( H ∼ T , Y T ) and unlabeled ( H ∼ V , Y V ) parts. The detailed calculation method and procedure of the output weight matrix β can be found in the original literature (Zhang et al., 2023). The label predictions Y V for unlabeled nodes are estimated by (6) yv = H v B The label with the maximum probability is selected as the prediction label of each node. The supervised GCELM training framework for extracting geochemical anomalies associated with polymetallic mineralization can be summarized as follows: Step1. Construct an undirected graph representation G = V , E , A using the K -nearest neighbors (KNN) algorithm. Step2. Randomly initialize the weight matrix W for the RGConv embedding layer. Step3. Calculate the embedding matrix H = σ A ¯ X W using the input feature matrix X . Step4. Set H ∼ = A ¯ H and Y as the target matrix. Step5. Solve the ridge regression problem to obtain the output weight matrix β = H ∼ T H ∼ + λ I - 1 H ∼ T Y . Step6. Make predictions using Y = H ∼ β . Step7. Select the label with the maximum inference value as the prediction for each node. 3.3 Voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine The V-GCELM is an ensemble learning method that uses multiple independent GCELM models to improve robustness and classification performance (Zhang et al., 2023). V-GCELM consists of a set of independent GCELM models, each trained with the same data set and with filter parameters generated independently. V-GCELM makes a decision by majority voting on the results of the independent GCELM models. For each sample, its probability of belonging to a specific class is calculated based on the number of GCELM models that classify it into that class. The prediction label is assigned to the class with the highest probability. V-GCELM is designed to address the issue of an unreliable decision boundary caused by the randomized filter parameters in a single GCELM model. The diversity of the GCELM models is achieved by the intrinsic randomness in the randomized graph convolutional embedding layer. The effectiveness of V-GCELM is guaranteed by a proposition that the V-GCELM model can correctly classify samples with probability one if only the number of independent GCELM models is sufficiently large. Fig. 3 shows the supervised classification flow chart of GCELM and V-GCELM for identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies from geochemical exploration data. 4 Results 4.1 Indicator element selection and data augmentation Indicator elements refer to the geochemical elements that exhibit genetic relationships with the deposits sought within the study area. Geologically, indicator elements typically constitute the mineralization or associated elements of a specific mineralization type occurred in the study area. Some researches (Chen and Wu, 2016; Zuo, 2018; Chen et al., 2021a, 2023a) have revealed a close spatial relationship exists between the concentrations of indicator elements and known mineral occurrences in a mineral exploration area. Out of the elements assayed in geochemical surveys, only a few can serve as the indicator elements for a specific deposit type in mineral exploration. The standard normal distributed statistic ZAUC can be employed to test whether a statistically significant spatial relationship exists between element concentrations and mineral occurrences (Chen and Wu, 2016; Zuo, 2018; Chen et al., 2021a, 2023b). According to Chen (2015), the AUC value for each element can be calculated based on the element concentration data and the positive and negative instances defined in Section 2.2. The standard normal distributed statistic ZAUC can be estimated according to the AUC value. According to the normal distribution hypothesis testing rule, the ZAUC value of an element should be greater than the critical value of 1.96 at the significant level of 0.05 if the AUC value of the element significantly differs from 0.5 (i.e., the AUC value of the random guess model). By referring to Chen (2015), the AUC and ZAUC values were calculated for 35 major and trace elements in this study (Table 2 ). According to the statistical results in Table 2, 17 major and trace elements, including Au, Ag, As, B, Bi, CaO, Cd, Cu, Hg, MgO, P, Pb, Sb, Sn, V, W, and Zn, were selected as indicator elements for geochemical exploration. Fig. 4 shows the contour maps of the 15 trace elements and 2 oxides selected for geochemical exploration. The grid data of the above selected 17 indicator elements and the ground truth data defined in Section 2.2 were used to construct the training data set for establishing the supervised classification models for identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies in the study area. However, there are only 30 mineralized instances in the study area, indicating that there is a serious class imbalance in geochemical exploration data, which affects the performance of supervised machine learning algorithms such as GCELM and V-GCELM. The data resampling techniques, including over-sampling and down-sampling techniques, can be used to balance the number of positive and negative instances in the training data set. However, there are only 30 positive instances in the study area. If 30 negative instances are drawn from the negative population by a down-sampling technique, the training data set composed of 30 positive and 30 negative instances cannot meet the requirement for training GCELM model and V-GCELM model. Therefore, only the over-sampling techniques are suitable for this study. Through comparing the performance of different over-sampling techniques (it is discussed in Section 5), the SMOTE algorithm was selected for oversampling positive instances to balance the rate of positive to negative instances in geochemical exploration data. The SMOTE algorithm balances the positive and negative classes ratio by generating new synthetic positive instances (Chawla et al., 2002). The Python source code for the SMOTE algorithm is from the imblearn library (Lemaître et al., 2017). The hyperparameters of the SMOTE algorithm were set to “sampling_strategy = auto”, “random_state = 42″, ”k_neighbors = 5″, and “n_jobs = None”, respectively. 4.2 Hyperparameter determination The Python source code for the GCELM and V-GCELM algorithms was obtained from https://github.com/zzj-cai/GCELM. The Python code for the ELM algorithm was obtained from https://pypi.org/project/hpelm. The original code was modified and integrated into a Python program for detecting polymetallic mineralization anomalies from geochemical exploration data. The SMOTE- augmented geochemical exploration data set in Section 4.1 was used as the training data set for establishing the GCELM model, V-GCELM model and ELM model. To make the GCELM model and V-GCELM model have the best performance in identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies, it is necessary to determine the optimal hyperparameter values of the GCELM model and V-GCELM model, such as the number of hidden neurons, regularization coefficient and neighborhood size. To simultaneously evaluate the impact of hyperparameter values and the impact of class-imbalance of a training data set on the performance of the classification model for identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies in this study, the precision-recall (PR) curve, area under the precision-recall curve (AUPRC), and F1-score (Goutte and Gaussier, 2005; Davis and Goadrich, 2006; Boyd, 2013) were selected to measure the performances of the GCELM model at different hyperparameter values. When the PR curve is used to evaluate the performance of a binary classification model, it is sensitive to the ratio of positive to negative instances of the training data set. In the learning process of a classification model, training and test data sets are usually generated randomly from the original training data set at each iteration, resulting in the ratio of positive to negative instances in the training and testing data sets changing with the iteration process. Therefore, in the learning process of binary classification models, PR curves are often used to monitor the performance of the classification model. The PR curve of a binary classification model will approach the upper right corner of the precision-recall space only when the training data set is close to the class balance and the performance of the classification model is close to perfect. In mineralization anomaly detection, the PR curve of the model intuitively reflects the variation of model performance with the imbalance of training data sets. The AUPRC is a quantitative metric for assessing the overall performance of the model, with the value of 1 indicating the perfect classification performance. In addition, the F1-score is a composite metric that balances the precision and recall, providing a more accurate measure of the model's performance. The number of hidden neurons is one of the most critical parameters in the GCELM model. Increasing the number of hidden neurons enhances the model's complexity and expressiveness, thus improving its fitting ability and enabling it to better fit the geochemical exploration data. However, excessive hidden neurons may result in overfitting (Zhang et al., 2023). Decreasing the number of hidden neurons reduces the risk of overfit, but the model's expressiveness is diminished. According to Zhang et al. (2023), when the number of hidden neurons exceeds 10, the improvement of model classification accuracy slows down; when the number reaches 30, the classification accuracy stabilizes. Therefore, tuning is performed within the range from 10 to 30 with an interval of 2. Based on the results shown in Fig. 5 a, the PR curve is closest to the upper right corner and the AUPRC and F1-scores are the highest when the number of hidden neurons is 28. Consequently, the number of hidden neurons was set to 28 in this study. The regularization coefficient λ needs to be optimized in establishing the GCELM model and V-GCELM model. In general, the GCELM model can achieve high accuracy when λ < 1. If λ > 1, the performance of GCELM declines sharply because an excessively large λ penalizes the parameters of the output layer and leads to underfitting. In this study, the optimal λ was selected in the range of 0.00005 and 10.0. Fig. 5b shows the classification performance of the GCELM model with λ of 0.00005, 0.0001,0.001, 0.01, 0.1, 1.0 and 10.0, respectively. It can be seen that when λ = 0.01, the model has the largest AUPRC value 0.92, the highest F1-score 0.84, and the PR curve closest to the upper right corner. Although the model performance is not highly sensitive to the neighborhood size K, the hyperparameter K still needs to be optimized in establishing the GCELM model and V-GCELM model. in general, a too large K value will result in that the graph convolution produces similar embeddings for each node, which reduces discriminative power. Therefore, choose a range from 5 to 50 and adjust parameter K at intervals of 5 in this study. Fig. 5c shows that the AUPRC value of the model increases monotonically as K increases from 5 to 30, and tends to decrease when K is greater than 30. When the hyperparameter K is equal to 30, the model has the largest AUPRC value of 0.91, the highest F1-score 0.84, and the PR curve closest to the upper right corner. Consequently, the optimal K value is 30 for this study. 4.3 Anomaly detection models The training data set augmented in Section 4.1 was used to train the GCELM model, V-GCELM model and ELM model for identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies in this study. The optimal hyperparameter values determined for the GCELM model in Section 4.2 (“n_hidden” = 28, “reg_para” = 1.0 and “n_neighbor” = 30) were used to initialized the GCELM model. The GCELM algorithm discussed in Section 3.2 was used to construct the supervised classification model for identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies. In the first step, the KNN algorithm was used to construct an undirected graph, which were used as the input graph data of the GCELM model. In the second step, the sigmoid function was chosen as the activation function for calculating the embedding matrix. The remaining steps were the same as described in Section 3.2. Zhang et al. (2023) used Friedman test (Hutchinson, 1996) and Wilcoxon rank sum test (Bergmann et al., 2000) and other statistical methods to test the stability of the GCELM algorithm after 30 independent runs, and found that GCELM lacked robustness. To solve the robustness problem faced by a single GCELM, Zhang et al. (2023) propose to merge multiple independent GCELMs and adopt majority voting for decision making. According to Zhang et al. (2023), the V-GCELM model can correctly classify samples with a probability of 1.0 when the number of independent GCELM models is large enough (i.e., 50 or more). In this study, the GCELM model shows a good performance but poor robustness in identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies. Therefore, a V-GCELM model was established on the basis of 50 independent GCELM models to improve the robustness of GCELM-based mineralization anomaly identification model. The 50 independent GCELM models were initialized with the optimal hyperparameter values determined for the GCELM model in Section 4.2, and then used to construct the V-GCELM model for identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies in the study area. The training process of the 50 independent GCELM models was the same as that of the GCELM model. The outputs of the 50 GCELM models were majority voted to produce the final output of the V-GCELM model. In order to compare the performance of the GCELM model and V-GCELM model with that of traditional ELM model in identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies, an ELM model was established for identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies in this study. To facilitate the comparison, the number of hidden layer neurons of the ELM model was set to 28, and the sigmoid function was selected as the activation function of the hidden layer neurons. The ELM algorithm discussed in Section 3.1 was used to establish the ELM model. 4.4 Polymetallic mineralization anomaly delineation and geological interpretation There are several methods to determine the threshold for binarizing the continuous classification scores produced by a supervised anomaly detection model for delineating mineralization anomalies. It has been documented that the mean ± 2σ method (Hawkes and Webb, 1963b), fractal and multifractal methods (Cheng et al., 1996, Cheng et al., 2000), weight of evidence (WofE) contrast (Agterberg, 1992) and Youden index (Chen 2015; Zhang et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2020; Chen et al., 2021a, 2023a; Chen and Shayilan, 2022) have been applied to determine the threshold for the separation of mineralization anomalies from the background. The mean ± 2σ method is one of the classical methods for geochemical anomaly delineation. This method determines the threshold according to the frequency distribution model of classification score data. The fractal and multifractal methods determine one or a set of thresholds according to the fractal or multifractal distribution patterns of element concentration data within the related spatial area. These three methods do not take the spatial relationship between mineralization anomalies and known mineral deposits into account when determining thresholds. Different from the aforementioned methods, the WofE contrast and Youden index determine the threshold according to the spatial relationship between mineralization anomalies and known mineral deposits and they perform very similarly in detecting mineralization anomalies. The threshold determined by the two methods is called optimal threshold because the mineralization anomalies delineated by the threshold have closest spatial relationship with known mineral deposits. In this study, the Youden index was used to determine the optimal threshold for separating polymetallic mineralization anomalies from the background because it is easy to calculate compared with the WofE contrast. The Youden index is defined as the true positive rate minus false positive rate (Chen, 2015). When using the Youden index to determine the optimal threshold, the Youden index corresponding to each possible threshold is calculated, and the threshold corresponding to the largest Youden index is defined as the optimal threshold (Chen, 2015). The larger the Youden index indicates the closer spatial relationship between the identified polymetallic mineralization anomalies and the known polymetallic occurrences. Fig. 6 shows the change curve of the Youden index of each classification model with the threshold value. The maximum Youden indices (MYIs) and optimal thresholds (OTs) of the GCELM model, V-GCELM model and ELM model were determined according to Fig. 6, and the optimal thresholds were used to delineate polymetallic mineralization anomalies in the study area. Fig. 7 shows the polymetallic mineralization anomalies optimally delineated using the optimal thresholds according to the classification scores of the GCELM model, V-CELM model and ELM model. It can be seen from Fig. 7a and b that the polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the GCELM model and V-GCELM model have similar spatial distribution patterns. The polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the GCELM model and V-GCELM model contain 97 % and 100 % of the polymetallic occurrences found in the study area, respectively. Compared with the polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the GCELM model and V-GCELM model, those identified by the ELM model obviously occupy more percentage of the entire area but contain only 90 % of the polymetallic occurrences found in the study area. Therefore, the ability of the ELM model to identify polymetallic mineralization anomalies is lower than that of the other two models. According to the above discussion, it can be seen that the polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the three classification models account for less than 10 % of the entire study area, but contain more than 90 % of the polymetallic deposits found in the study area, indicating that the polymetallic mineralization anomalies delineated in the study area have a close spatial correlation with the polymetallic deposits found in the study area. Therefore, the modeling results of geochemical exploration data are consistent with regional polymetallic mineralization characteristics of the study area. By comparing Fig. 7 with the geological map shown in Fig. 1, it can be seen that the polymetallic metallogenic anomalies identified by the three classification models are mainly located in the distribution areas of Archean metamorphic rocks and Mesozoic magmatic rocks, and are jointly controlled by NE- and NW- trending faults. According to the discussion in Section 2.1, Archean metamorphic rocks, Mesozoic magmatic rocks and regional faults are the three major metallogenic controlling factors (Wu, 1992; Zhang et al., 2011). In summary, the modeling results of geochemical exploration data are consistent with regional geological characteristics of the study area. 5 Discussion The consistency of the polymetallic mineralization anomalies delineated in the study area with regional mineralization characteristics was evaluated in terms of ROCs, AUCs and lift indices. The spatial correlation of the polymetallic mineralization anomalies with the geological characteristics was evaluated through the geological interpretation of polymetallic mineralization anomalies. The advantages and disadvantages of the GCELM model and V-GCELM model for identifying mineralization anomalies were discussed in terms of data augmentation, model performance and model robustness. 5.1 Model performance The performance of the GCELM model, V-GCELM model and ELM model for identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies was graphically measured by using ROC curves. The overall performance of the three supervised anomaly detection models was evaluated by estimating their AUC values. The statistical significance of the difference between each anomaly detection model and random guess model was statistically tested by estimating the ZAUC value of each anomaly detection model (Chen et al., 2014, 2021c, 2023b; Chen and Wu, 2016, 2017a, 2019; Chen and Shayilan, 2022). Fig. 8 displays the ROC curves of the three supervised anomaly detection models. The GCELM model and V-GCELM model have the ROC curves closer to the upper left corner of the ROC space than the ELM model, indicating that the two models perform better than the ELM model in identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies. Table 3 presents the AUC and ZAUC values of the GCELM model, V-GCELM model and ELM model. The GCELM model and V-GCELM model have the AUC values 0.9977 and 0.9989, respectively, which are significantly higher than the AUC value of the ELM model (0.9402). Therefore, the GCELM model and V-GCELM model are superior to the ELM model in terms of AUCs in identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies. The ZAUC values of the GCELM model and V-GCELM model are far higher than the tabled value 1.96 at the significant level 0.05, indicating that the polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the GCELM model and V-GCELM model have a significant spatial relationship with the discovered polymetallic occurrences in the study area. The lift index (Chen and Wu, 2016) is the ratio of the true positive rate (TPR) to the anomaly area rate (AAR), serving as an indicator for measuring the spatial correlation between the polymetallic mineralization anomalies and the discovered polymetallic occurrences. A higher lift index indicates that the polymetallic mineralization anomalies account for a smaller proportion of the entire study area but contain a greater proportion of the discovered polymetallic occurrences. The true positive rates (TPRs), anomaly area rates (AARs) and lift indices of the three supervised anomaly detection models are shown in Table 4 . The polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the GCELM model accounts for 4.8 % of the whole area and contain 97 % of the discovered polymetallic occurrences. The polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the V-GCELM model accounts for 3.5 % of the whole area and contain 100 % of the discovered polymetallic occurrences. The polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the ELM model accounts for 9.8 % of the whole area and contain 90 % of the discovered polymetallic occurrences. The lift indices of the GCELM model, V-GCELM model and ELM model are 20.1, 28.6 and 9.2, respectively. Therefore, the GCELM model and V-GCELM model are superior to the ELM model in terms of lift indices. 5.2 Consistence with geological mineralization characteristics The polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the GCELM model and V-GCELM model are closely spatially associated with Archean metamorphic rocks and Mesozoic magmatic intrusions in the study area, indicating that these mineralization anomalies are spatially jointly controlled by the Archean metamorphic rocks and Mesozoic magmatic intrusions in the study area. In addition, the polymetallic mineralization anomalies are spatially distributed along northeastern direction and spatially coincide with the regional NE-trending tectonic zone in the study area, indicating that these mineralization anomalies are spatially controlled by the regional tectonic zone composed of NE-trending faults. According to the discussion in Section 2.1, the Archean metamorphic rocks, Mesozoic magmatic activity and regional faults are the three main regional polymetallic mineralization controlling factors in the study area (Wu, 1992; Zhang et al., 2011). Therefore, the results of polymetallic mineralization anomaly identification are basically consistent with the geological mineralization characteristics of the study area. 5.3 Advantages and disadvantages of the methods The GCELM algorithm is a combination of GCN and ELM, which is used to solve the classification problem of graph data. The V-GCELM algorithm is an ensemble technique for voting the outputs of numerous GCELM models, which improves the robustness of classification models. Compared with most machine learning and deep learning algorithms such as ELM (Chen and Wu, 2017b) and deep autoencoder (Xiong and Zuo, 2016), the GCELM and V-GCELM algorithms can make full use of the correlation information between training data points to capture complex patterns and nonlinear relationships in high-dimensional geochemical exploration data and improve the performance of the supervised mineralization anomaly identification models. This is because the data set used for training the GCELM model and V-GCELM model is the graph data transformed from geochemical exploration data, which can well describe the spatial correlation between neighborhood data points in geochemical anomaly identification, so as to improve the model performance in mineralization anomaly identification. This is also why the performances of the GCELM model and V-GCELM model perform better than ELM in polymetallic mineralization identification in this study. The GCELM model and V-GCELM model are more efficient than the GCN model because they incorporate ELM to accelerate the training speed without compromising their classification performance. Besides, the randomized graph convolutional operation not only preserves structured information but also exhibits meaningful discriminative power (Zhang et al., 2023). According Zhang et al. (2020), GCELM is generally superior to GCN with same settings in classifying 27 widely used classification datasets. The disadvantage of the GCELM and V-GCELM algorithms is that the performances of the GCELM model and V-GCELM model is seriously affected by the class imbalance of training data set in solving graph data classification problems. When the GCELM and V-GCELM algorithms are used to construct supervised anomaly identification models in geochemical exploration, a data resampling technique must be applied to balance the class distribution of the training data set because of the high class-imbalance of the geochemical exploration data. Therefore, the performances of the GCELM model and V-GCELM model depend on the data resampling technique used in the data augmentation in mineralization anomaly identification. In this study, four data resampling approaches were adopted to alleviate the class-imbalance of geochemical exploration data. Table 5 shows the performance measures of the GCELM model and V-GCELM model with respect to different data resampling techniques. It can be seen that the performances of the GCELM model and V-GCELM model vary with the data resampling approaches. Among these data resampling techniques, the SMOTE algorithm can make the GCELM model and V-GCELM model achieve the best performance in identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies. 6 Conclusion The graph convolutional extreme learning machine and voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine were used to establish supervised classification models for identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies from stream sediment survey data in the Baishan area, Jilin Province, China. The performances of the graph convolutional extreme learning machine model and voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine model were compared with that of the extreme learning model in terms of receiver operating characteristic curves, area under the receiver operating characteristic curves and lift indices. The results show that the classification performances of the graph convolutional extreme learning machine model and voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine model perform better than the extreme learning machine model in identifying polymetallic mineralization anomalies. The voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine model has stronger robustness than the graph convolutional extreme learning machine model. It can be concluded that the graph convolutional extreme learning machine model and voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine provide novel and effective techniques for constructing high-performance supervised classification models for identifying mineralization anomalies from geochemical exploration data. However, a data resampling technique, such as synthetic minority over-sampling technique, must be used to alleviate the class-imbalance of geochemical exploration data when building the supervised anomaly identification models. Compared with most traditional machine learning and deep learning techniques such as the extreme learning machine and deep autoencoder network, the graph convolutional extreme learning machine and voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine can more efficiently make use of the correlation information between neighborhood data points to improve the model performance in mineralization anomaly identification. By converting high-dimensional geochemical exploration data into graph data and combining graph convolutional network with extreme learning machines, the graph convolutional extreme learning machine and voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine can construct the high-performance supervised anomaly identification models from the augmented geochemical exploration data to capture complex patterns and nonlinear relationships in geochemical data as well as the spatial interrelationships between neighborhood training samples. Therefore, the classification performance of the mineralization anomaly identification model is improved. The polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the graph convolutional extreme learning machine model and voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine model account for very small percentage of the total study area (<5.0 %), but contain almost all the known polymetallic deposits found in the study area (>96 %). In addition, the polymetallic mineralization anomalies identified by the graph convolutional extreme learning machine model and voting-based graph convolutional extreme learning machine model are spatially correlated with the regional polymetallic mineralization controlling factors such as the Archean metamorphic rocks, Mesozoic magmatic intrusions and regional NE-trending fault zone. It can be concluded that the results of polymetallic mineralization anomaly identification are basically consistent with the geological and mineralization characteristics of the study area.
