This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0) Peer-review under responsibility of the scientific committee of the 56th CIRP International Conference on Manufacturing Systems 2023 Keywords: performance management; machine learning; intraday forecasting 1. Introduction A companyâ€™s planning, management, and control are among the main activities of corporate management [1]. Finding innovative responses to changing environmental conditions and thus contributing to continuous improvement has proven vital to successful companies [2]. An essential prerequisite for continuous performance improvement is the awareness of oneâ€™s performance, thus making performance monitoring a critical provision for achieving continuous improvement, facilitating the identification and application of suitable measures [3]. Managers must make hundreds of decisions daily, relying on the support of appropriate information and aligned with a common goal [4]. In order to be competitive in the long term, companies need to be able to recognize changes at an early stage and react to them proactively [3]. Performance management systems (PMS) have been developed to tackle this challenge. Aiming for the management of process performance, goals are set by the management and translated into trackable key performance indicators (KPIs) [5]. In this context, the timeliness of information plays a decisive role in the success of responding to deviations since delayed information availability can leave decision-makers with no time to react. Usually, KPIs are formed only by shift or day, which makes the real-time reaction to deviations impossible [6]. Closing this gap, a model-based approach for online-intraday predictions of KPIs using sensor and machine data is being proposed. The structure of this paper is as follows: In the second chapter, an overview of current research on performance management and the use of machine learning in production is presented. Chapter three constitutes the core of the paper, in which two different studies are conducted and evaluated on a real-world industrial 56th CIRP Conference on Manufacturing Systems, CIRP CMS â€˜23, South Africa Intraday forecasting of OEE through sensor data and machine learning Lukas Longarda,*, Thorben Preina, Joachim Metternicha aInstitute of Production Management, Technology and Machine tools (PTW), TU Darmstadt, Otto-Berndt-Str. 2, 64287 Darmstadt, Germany * Corresponding author. E-mail address: l.longard@ptw.tu-darmstadt.de Abstract Key performance indicators are crucial for measuring and managing the performance of industrial processes. They are employed to detect deviations in production, enabling opportunities to improve manufacturing processes within the three dimensions of time, quality, and cost. In this context, the timeliness of information plays a decisive role in the success of measures since delayed information availability can leave decision-makers with no time to react. Usually, key performance indicators are updated on a shift or daily basis and thus only allow a delayed reaction to deviations that have occurred. To tackle this problem, different mixed data sampling and machine learning methods for the intraday monitoring of key performance indicators based on high-frequency sensor and machine data are investigated. By benchmarking the approaches on real-world data from the process industry, the authors show how to obtain models for real-time detection of performance deviations. To enable application for practitioners and academia in the future, a method for implementation and deployment in real-world scenarios is given. The developed methodology offers the construction of high-frequency forecasts for key performance metrics, and therefore accelerates managersâ€™ reactions to associated problems. 94 Lukas Longard et al. / Procedia CIRP 120 (2023) 93â€“98 Longard et al./ Procedia CIRP 00 (2023) 000â€“000 3 3.1. Case description and data set The approach is being developed by investigating real- world data originating from a continuous extrusion process in the plastics industry. The production consists of several downstream processes, including extrusion, funneling, sieving, and melting. Consecutively the melted semi-finished product is cast and rolled. The dataset used in this study contains three major parts. The first one is a time series of about 600 sensors, which was limited to 0.1 Hz for the pursued use case to save memory. Secondly, the MES data assigns specific machine states, such as replenishment and production, to time intervals of the sensor data. Lastly, the dataset covers the KPI data, such as employee documented good and scrap quantity, for the examined period. The performance of the process is measured by the OEE, consisting of its three components: availability rate, performance rate and quality rate (see formula 1-4 and Figure 2). Preliminary study Forecasting a processesâ€™ performance by utilizing machine- based sensor data bears major challenges. Reported earlier in current production environments KPI data is documented only once per day. While fostering the necessity to predict KPI data with higher time resolution intra-day, this leaves machine learning approaches with very sparse gold label data to learn from. Because of this lack of gold data, the simplified problem of predicting the daily key performance values is first being investigated in a preliminary study (see Figure 4). Let ð�‘‹ð�‘‹ be the high frequency sensor data and ð��´ð��´ð�‘™ð�‘™ð�‘™ð�‘™ð�‘™ð�‘™ be the low frequency daily target variables constituting performance metrics, such as active and set-up time, a model is being searched for a (with model parameters ð�œƒð�œƒ) to map: Our approach is visualized in Figure 3. Applying the tsfresh framework, statistical features (e.g. min, max, mean, frequencies and autocorrelations) from the daily time-series sensor data are being derived [22]. In a consecutive step, the featuresâ€™ significance on the target is evaluated via hypothesis testing, keeping only the most relevant information. The tests used include the two-sided univariate fisher test, the Kolmogorov Smirnov test and Kendallâ€™s tau. By condensing the time series data to one value per feature, the originally high frequency sensor data is reduced to the daily KPI label frequency. The derived features are then fed as input data into state-of-the-art regression algorithms such as decision trees, feed forward neural networks (FFNN) and support vector machine (SVM) regressors to compare their performance. The model training and comparison is conducted by splitting the dataset into train, development, and test sets, distributing the recorded days randomly between the datasets. Accordingly, feature selection through hypothesis testing focusses on training data only. The number of most relevant features, as well as respective model hyperparameters are optimized on the validation dataset to determine an optimal model configuration. Hyperparameters include the number of most significant features used for modelling. Likewise, the number of final features used varies between the different KPIs, with a preference for most models from 100 up to 250 features. ð�‘ƒð�‘ƒ(ð�‘‹ð�‘‹, ð�›©ð�›©) = ð��´ð��´ð�‘™ð�‘™ð�‘™ð�‘™ð�‘™ð�‘™ (5) hroughput Active Po er Current Figure 3: Model pipeline for the derivation of key performance predicting models from high dimensional sensor data Figure 2: Visualization of OEE data data set. In a preliminary study, a model to predict daily KPIs based on high-frequency sensor and machine data is being developed. Based on the results of the preliminary study, the main study is then conducted and a model for real-time availability rate prediction is presented. Finally, the paper concludes with a short summary and an outlook for future work. 2. Literature survey 2.1. Performance management Performance management is defined as a continuous process to identify, measure, and develop the performance of individuals and teams and to align performance with the organization's strategic goals. It helps executives achieve strategic business goals by linking the businessâ€™s goals to the individualâ€™s [7]. Contemporaneously over time, the concept of performance has evolved. The original dimensions of efficiency and effectiveness have been supplemented by productivity, flexibility, creativity, sustainability, and agility, influencing each other and having competing or complementary relationships [3]. In practical applications, KPIs are formed to measure and monitor these different performance dimensions, breaking them down to individual areas and teams [8]. KPIs are used to communicate information in aggregated form, counteracting knowledge deficits on the part of the decision-makers. These deficits result from the high control complexity of large production companies [9]. In addition, KPIs enable the identification of deviations by comparing actual and target values. Identified deviations can then be eliminated through systematic problem-solving processes, leading to continuous improvement and, hence, a company's long-term competitiveness [10]. The Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE) [11] is one of the most critical KPIs in the equipment-intensive sector [12]. It is used to determine, monitor, and improve the effectiveness of production equipment (machines, production cells, assembly lines) in the context of the manufacturing process. It comprises three components: availability rate, performance rate, and quality rate. These in turn reflect the losses over time in the dimensions of availability, performance, and quality (see Figure 1). In this context, the availability rate shows losses due to technical breakdowns, changeovers, and adjustments to the equipment. In contrast, the performance rate reveals losses due to engine idle, minor stoppages and reduced speed. The last factor the quality rate reflects losses due to defective or reworked parts. 2.2. Recent advances in performance management Recent developments in performance management incorporate the increasing availability of data and new algorithms. While companies used to compute their KPIs manually years ago, automatic calculation via IoT systems is increasingly becoming state-of-the-art [13]. The analysis of anomalies and deviations in KPIs is a central component in PMS to identify causes of deterioration and negative trends at an early stage [14]. One particularly recent development is the model-based analysis and detection of these KPI trends by leveraging machine learning techniques [15]. Xu et al. introduced an unsupervised variational autoencoder, to robustly detect deviations in seasonally varying KPIs [16]. Instead of identifying abnormal or negative trends in current timeseries, another approach is the forecasting of KPIs to estimate future performance over defined periods of time. Researchers have explored this possibility by employing machine learning techniques, such as reconstructions with semi-supervised gated autoencoders [17], partial least squares regression [18], Bayesian neural networks [19] and decision trees [20]. Expanding on the previous two KPI analysis methods are soft sensing techniques. KPI soft sensing models derive KPI values of interest, which are not monitored by a sensor directly. Instead, the current KPI status is predicted by a model processing raw input data, e.g., machine sensor outputs. The derived KPI values of interest support proactive action in PMS by increasing situational awareness and supporting informed corrective measures to meet performance goals [17,21]. This work focuses on the latter approach by developing a near real-time soft sensor that processes raw machine sensor data and predicts the strategic production KPIs of time, quality and cost. It thereby enables high frequency status monitoring. To the best of the authors' knowledge, this represents a novel application for soft sensing of KPIs in production environments. 3. Model development The evaluation cycles in classic performance management are carried out on a shift or daily basis. This means that key figures are formed based on the results of the previous day/shift and provide an overview of past performance in aggregated form. Consequently, measures in response to deficient performance can only be taken after a delay impacting subsequent days. This issue is being addressed by introducing an approach that uses process and machine data to provide near real-time performance information, improving management situational awareness and enabling direct measure escalation. The following research questions need to be answered: â€¢ Is there a quantifiable relationship between production performance indicators (daily) and high frequency sensor and machine data of the same day? â€¢ If there is a relationship: How can this relationship be used to realize intraday performance prediction for soft sensing? Case description and data set The approach is being developed by investigating real- world data originating from a continuous extrusion process in the plastics industry. The production consists of several downstream processes, including extrusion, funneling, sieving, and melting. Consecutively the melted semi-finished product is cast and rolled. The dataset used in this study contains three major parts. The first one is a time series of about 600 sensors, which was limited to 0.1 Hz for the pursued use case to save memory. Secondly, the MES data assigns specific machine states, such as replenishment and production, to time intervals of the sensor data. Lastly, the dataset covers the KPI data, such as employee documented good and scrap quantity, for the examined period. The performance of the process is measured by the OEE, consisting of its three components: availability rate, performance rate and quality rate (see formula 1-4 and Figure 2). Figure 1: Overview of the different losses of the OEE 96 Lukas Longard et al. / Procedia CIRP 120 (2023) 93â€“98 Longard et al./ Procedia CIRP 00 (2023) 000â€“000 5 The acquired MES dataset maps different machine states, such as set-up and manufacturing to time-periods. Thus, the new densely labelled dataset contains time dependent labels accurate to minutes. Following the additional dataâ€™s nature of providing additional gold labels for the time usage only and the results of the preliminary study, the availability rate is being focused on. Consecutively, a decision tree classification model is being trained to predict the machines state for each incremental time interval. Finally, by investigating the different machine states for a given day under investigation, it is possible to compute the current key performance constituents for active and set-up time. Obtaining a high accuracy for the time increment classification, the approach highlights the possibility to derive the systemâ€™s key performance from the machine data only. Aggregating the predicted states for time increments across a day, the daily predicted key performance can be compared against the dataset documented performance values, reducing RMSE prediction error to only 1.1% for active time and 0.7% for set-up time (see Table 2). Furthermore, it might be possible to obtain even higher values, by further increasing the resolution of the MES data derived condition labels. Table 2: Main study - results for normalized RMSE values and corresponding RÂ² values RMSE Active time .011 .998 Set-up time .007 .930 Downtime .029 .980 The new classifier can be used to monitor the system under operation, providing immediate feedback on the real-time status of the systemâ€™s KPI values. By predicting the machine status, the individual components of the availability rate (e.g. active time, set-up time and downtime) can be determined in real time, by summing up the corresponding predicted times. Thus, the availability rate can be calculated at any time and allows real-time assessment of the current performance. The good results for the densely labelled task emphasize the importance of the additional time resolved label data, considering the substantial improvement regarding the preliminary studies predictions. Targeting a similar increase in label density, future developments should focus on the other system KPIs to achieve a complete soft sensor-based monitoring for the investigated continuous process. The accuracy reached for the latter models are sufficient for an operationalization and use on the shop floor. The model can enable employees and managers to obtain information on the current performance of a production line/area at any time to derive suitable measures. Reducing reaction times significantly when compared to the current status quo with evaluation of KPIs at the end of the day. Aiming for a comprehensible presentation of the newly derived information to employees and managers, a dashboard is presented (see Figure 6), which provides the information concisely and clearly. The dashboard is divided into two graphs. The upper graph visualizes the current availability rate forecast for the end of the day or shift. Here, the prediction starts at the beginning of the shift with an average expectation for the availability rate (in example 80%) and then rises and falls during the day depending on actual performance (left side of figure). A prediction interval for the availability rate is calculated and displayed for the remaining production time (right side of the figure). Prevalent, the best results are achieved for the key performance values of active time, good quantity and downtime. Evaluating the model generated features shows that among many others, the model leverages a correlation between the aftercooling roll utilization and temperature control to the nozzle for predicting the respective active times. However, the results also show the difficulty of regressing accurate key performance metrics using the sparse daily labels for all predicted key performance quantities. Overall, the approach highlights the challenges and limitations for the derivation of a KPI soft sensor using the high dimensional sensor data with sparse, daily labels only (see Figure 5). However, it points into further directions, by showing the possibility of predicting especially availability rate related key performance components. It can be concluded that the insufficient accuracy for the derivation of quality and performance related predictions is being caused by the more complex relations hidden in patterns of the heating and thickness control system, however due to the scarce low frequency training data those canâ€™t be approximated for the continuous high throughput process. Meanwhile the operation time itself, as well as maintenance procedures are easier to relate, as those states can be directly represented in the procedure affected machine sensors. Furthermore, additional error is caused by human documentation of the KPI valuesâ€™ development, manually calculated and partially approximated after shifts. 3.3. Main study In the main study it is further investigated how the previous findings can lead towards a real-time OEE prediction and soft sensing. As discussed, data scarcity has been identified to be a major bottleneck. To overcome the preliminary studies modelsâ€™ limitations, e increase the datasetâ€™s labels by augmenting the human documented KPI values with MES data. This way, we overcome the limitation of the preliminary studyâ€™s models, which could only be used for soft sensing KPIs after the end of a working day. Instead, we derive features on equidistant periods of time, splitting each day into 144 ten-minute lasting timesteps. Leveraging the additional data, a new modeling approach is developed in the following. The approach enables the real-time prediction of the respective KPI and examines if better predictions are possible through the higher label density on the already high-frequency sensor data. Figure 4: Mixed data frequency modelling problem . . Figure 5: Preliminary study - results for daily downtime values Lukas Longard et al. / Procedia CIRP 120 (2023) 93â€“98 97 The acquired MES dataset maps different machine states, such as set-up and manufacturing to time-periods. Thus, the new densely labelled dataset contains time dependent labels accurate to minutes. Following the additional dataâ€™s nature of providing additional gold labels for the time usage only and the results of the preliminary study, the availability rate is being focused on. Consecutively, a decision tree classification model is being trained to predict the machines state for each incremental time interval. Finally, by investigating the different machine states for a given day under investigation, it is possible to compute the current key performance constituents for active and set-up time. Obtaining a high accuracy for the time increment classification, the approach highlights the possibility to derive the systemâ€™s key performance from the machine data only. Aggregating the predicted states for time increments across a day, the daily predicted key performance can be compared against the dataset documented performance values, reducing RMSE prediction error to only 1.1% for active time and 0.7% for set-up time (see Table 2). Furthermore, it might be possible to obtain even higher values, by further increasing the resolution of the MES data derived condition labels. Table 2: Main study - results for normalized RMSE values and corresponding RÂ² values RMSE Active time .011 .998 Set-up time .007 .930 Downtime .029 .980 The new classifier can be used to monitor the system under operation, providing immediate feedback on the real-time status of the systemâ€™s KPI values. By predicting the machine status, the individual components of the availability rate (e.g. active time, set-up time and downtime) can be determined in real time, by summing up the corresponding predicted times. Thus, the availability rate can be calculated at any time and allows real-time assessment of the current performance. The good results for the densely labelled task emphasize the importance of the additional time resolved label data, considering the substantial improvement regarding the preliminary studies predictions. Targeting a similar increase in label density, future developments should focus on the other system KPIs to achieve a complete soft sensor-based monitoring for the investigated continuous process. The accuracy reached for the latter models are sufficient for an operationalization and use on the shop floor. The model can enable employees and managers to obtain information on the current performance of a production line/area at any time to derive suitable measures. Reducing reaction times significantly when compared to the current status quo with evaluation of KPIs at the end of the day. Aiming for a comprehensible presentation of the newly derived information to employees and managers, a dashboard is presented (see Figure 6), which provides the information concisely and clearly. The dashboard is divided into two graphs. The upper graph visualizes the current availability rate forecast for the end of the day or shift. Here, the prediction starts at the beginning of the shift with an average expectation for the availability rate (in example 80%) and then rises and falls during the day depending on actual performance (left side of figure). A prediction interval for the availability rate is calculated and displayed for the remaining production time (right side of the figure). The lower graph visualizes the current status of the Figure 6: Dashboard design for real-time monitoring of availability rate Real time 2 3 Forecast ast 3 min ast 2h Performance 4 Longard et al. / Procedia CIRP 00 (2023) 000â€“000 The results (see Table 1) indicate a general agreement between the different algorithmsâ€™ performances. Prevalent, the best results are achieved for the key performance values of active time, good quantity and downtime. The goodness of the prediction can be determined by relating the RMSE with the NaÃ¯ve models results and investigating the R2 values. Evaluating the model generated features shows that among many others, the model leverages a correlation between the aftercooling roll utilization and temperature control to the nozzle for predicting the respective active times. However, the results also show the difficulty of regressing accurate key performance metrics using the sparse daily labels for all predicted key performance quantities. To the minute, it shows whether the line has been producing (in green), has been set up (in grey), or has had a malfunction (in red). In addition, the performance of the last 30 min and the last 2 h is shown and thus a positive or negative development can be derived. 4. Conclusion In this work, the necessity to improve current key performance monitoring to be timelier and therefore allow for quicker reactions to deviations during daily operation is being highlighted. It is being investigated how a timelier assessment and display of KPI values can be realized with respect to a real- world extrusion process from the plastics industry. It is being found that the prediction of key performance related metrics using only sparse daily labels imposes a challenging problem and while for the investigated process the prediction of some KPIs has been achieved with reasonable accuracy, our results show that real-time resolved KPI monitoring cannot be accomplished. Instead, a second experiment shows that more information dense labelling enriches the developed modelsâ€™ capabilities and can be used to predict real-time KPI development. Showing results for availability rate only, future research should focus on the adaptation of this approach to other KPI values, potentially necessitating a period of on-site data acquisition. Finally, after the development of a real-time capable model an interactive dashboard to reinforce management personnel on current KPI status is being presented. Allowing for a fast and intuitive overview, the dashboard summarizes recent developments under the KPI computation for the last thirty minutes, as well as medium and all-day performance reviews. Using Graph-based Visualizatio PROCIR 400561 S2212-8271(23)00688-1 10.1016/j.procir.2023.08.017 Intraday forecasting of OEE through sensor data and machine learning Lukas Longard a Thorben Prein a Joachim Metternich a a Institute of Production Management, Technology and Machine tools (PTW), TU Darmstadt, Otto-Berndt-Str. 2, 64287 Darmstadt, Germany Institute of Production Management, Technology and Machine tools (PTW), TU Darmstadt Otto-Berndt-Str. 2 Darmstadt 64287 Germany aInstitute of Production Management, Technology and Machine tools (PTW), TU Darmstadt, Otto-Berndt-Str. 2, 64287 Darmstadt, Germany Key performance indicators are crucial for measuring and managing the performance of industrial processes. They are employed to detect deviations in production, enabling opportunities to improve manufacturing processes within the three dimensions of time, quality, and cost. In this context, the timeliness of information plays a decisive role in the success of measures since delayed information availability can leave decision-makers with no time to react. Usually, key performance indicators are updated on a shift or daily basis and thus only allow a delayed reaction to deviations that have occurred. To tackle this problem, different mixed data sampling and machine learning methods for the intraday monitoring of key performance indicators based on high-frequency sensor and machine data are investigated. By benchmarking the approaches on real-world data from the process industry, the authors show how to obtain models for real-time detection of performance deviations. To enable application for practitioners and academia in the future, a method for implementation and deployment in real-world scenarios is given. The developed methodology offers the construction of high-frequency forecasts for key performance metrics, and therefore accelerates managers’ reactions to associated problems. ML Intention Object Data sources Characteristics Major results Ref HCA A Hop pellets NIR, MIR Both are rapid, non-destructive, low-cost, but MIR has a higher specificity than NIR Based on NIR and MIR data, hop pellets were divided into two clusters, but the distribution of MIR-HCA was not as clear as NIR (Machado et al., 2018) B Black pepper UHPLC-Q-Orbitrap-HRMS, 1H NMR, GC-HRMS High-throughput analysis, high sensitivity, and high resolution, and NMR-UHPLC-GC data fusion approach can reduce the dimensionality of 1H NMR and improve accuracy Based on UHPLC-Q-Orbitrap-HRMS HCA model, the clustering of samples from Brazil and Vietnam was close, and the clustering of sterilized samples and corresponding unsterilized samples was also very close (Rivera-Perez et al., 2021) C Rhizoma Coptidis HPLC, FT-NIR, FT-IR Spectra can not only can it be used for qualitative analysis, but it can also assist in quantitative analysis; Data fusion can obtain more comprehensive chemical information Based on FT-NIR, when the distance was 23, the samples of C.omeiensis and C.chinensis are clustered into one class, and the distance was 24, which involves C.deltoidea samples; Based on FT-IR, C. deltoidea and C. teeta samples are clustered into one class; Based on data fusion, C. deltoidea, C. chinensis and C. teeta samples are clustered into one class when the distance was 12 (Qi et al., 2018) PCA A Oolong tea Gustatory sensors, olfactory sensors Sensor technology is fast and accurate, and can make non-specific reactions to relevant chemical components, but only a single sensor technology cannot fully characterize samples PCA was established based on taste sensor data and olfactory sensor data respectively, and the two showed similar results.
