Research Smart Process Manufacturing toward Carbon Neutrality—Perspective Active Machine Learning for Chemical Engineers: A Bright Future Lies Ahead! Yannick Ureel Maarten R. Dobbelaere Yi Ouyang Kevin De Ras Maarten K. Sabbe Guy B. Marin Kevin M. Van Geem ⁎ Laboratory for Chemical Technology, Department of Materials, Textiles and Chemical Engineering, Ghent University, Ghent 9052, Belgium Laboratory for Chemical Technology, Department of Materials, Textiles and Chemical Engineering Ghent University Ghent 9052 Belgium Laboratory for Chemical Technology, Department of Materials, Textiles and Chemical Engineering, Ghent University, Ghent 9052, Belgium ⁎ Corresponding author. By combining machine learning with the design of experiments, thereby achieving so-called active machine learning, more efficient and cheaper research can be conducted. Machine learning algorithms are more flexible and are better than traditional design of experiment algorithms at investigating processes spanning all length scales of chemical engineering. While active machine learning algorithms are maturing, their applications are falling behind. In this article, three types of challenges presented by active machine learning—namely, convincing the experimental researcher, the flexibility of data creation, and the robustness of active machine learning algorithms—are identified, and ways to overcome them are discussed. A bright future lies ahead for active machine learning in chemical engineering, thanks to increasing automation and more efficient algorithms that can drive novel discoveries. Keywords Active machine learning Active learning Bayesian optimization Chemical engineering Design of experiments 1 Introduction Experiments performed under well-defined conditions and calculations based on first principles constitute the basis of engineering research. In chemical engineering, these activities are aimed at, for example, the development and optimization of catalysts, reaction conditions, and reactor configurations. In the chemical industry, 51 billion USD was spent in 2017 on research and development [1]. This illustrates the importance of high-quality data; however, obtaining accurate data is tedious and error prone. The design of experiments (DoE) can help in extracting the maximal information with a minimum of effort [2,3], making sure that time and resources are spent efficiently. By integrating machine learning with DoE, a more flexible and efficient DoE is achieved. This so-called “active machine learning” allows a more effective selection of experimental conditions, particularly for high-dimensional and highly nonlinear phenomena [4]. Machine learning can facilitate the automation of the whole experimental cycle, from experimental selection to model building and data analysis [5]. While the most common field of application in machine learning is model building and data analysis, the focus of this article is on the potential of combining DoE with machine learning for active machine learning. Olsson [6] defined active machine learning as a supervised machine learning technique in which the learner—that is, the machine learning model—is in control of the data from which it learns. In active machine learning, machine learning algorithms are used to iteratively determine new experimental data, the so-called training data, based on uncertainty criteria. It should be noted that “experimental” can also refer to computationally expensive high-level simulations, such as high-level ab initio calculations of molecular properties or large eddy simulations of reactive flow with computational fluid dynamics (CFD) codes [7]. Active machine learning consists of two branches with two different purposes: active learning and Bayesian optimization. Active learning aims to explore and model a process with a minimum number of “experiments” to ensure accurate predictions over the entire design space [8]. Bayesian optimization is essentially a machine learning-based optimization strategy, where iteratively new experimental data is selected to find an experiment that optimizes the objective [9]. Either active learning or Bayesian optimization can be employed for experimental selection, depending on whether the goal is to model a process and acquire process knowledge or to optimize an objective. 1.1 Basic principles of active machine learning Fig. 1 [10] illustrates the general workflow of active machine learning algorithms, starting with the initialization followed by an iterative loop consisting of three phases. The critical first step of initialization consists of clearly defining the research problem as either the modeling of an output (active learning) or the optimization of an objective (Bayesian optimization). An example of active learning is the investigation of the effect of reaction conditions, such as temperature and pressure, on the conversion [10,11]. With Bayesian optimization, the goal is to find the optimal reaction conditions to maximize this conversion [12–14]. In both cases, a design space is set up that defines the ranges of the studied variables by considering the objectives and the intrinsic limitations of the experimental tools. A machine learning model is then initialized and trained using a small sample of labeled data, which comes from experiments whose outcomes are known, stemming from literature, previous experiments, or newly performed experiments. In general, the amount of preliminary labeled data is very low. After initial training, the machine learning model is able to make rudimentary predictions in the design space. The model can vaguely estimate where an optimum could be situated for Bayesian optimization, or which experiment—the so-called query—is most informative for active learning. While the definition and initialization of both active learning and Bayesian optimization are essentially the same (and are not even too different from a classic experimental campaign), the main differences and advantages are found in the model training. Active learning is purely based on exploration, to enable predictions of the design space that are as accurate as possible. Conversely, Bayesian optimization balances both exploration and exploitation in order to find the optimum in the design space, treating every iteration as the potentially final one. Exploitation investigates areas with a high objective value to find an optimum nearby, whereas exploration discovers areas for which the predictions are unknown and therefore uncertain. Exploration requires a measure of uncertainty in the predictions to identify which areas of the design space remain unexplored [15]. Therefore, popular machine learning models for active machine learning are Gaussian processes [16–19] and Bayesian neural networks [20–22], as these allow an uncertainty estimation of their predictions. Another advantage of Gaussian processes is that they deal very well with noisy measurements, which are inherent in real-life experiments. By adding a noise term to the Gaussian process kernel, the machine learning model can estimate the experimental uncertainty and allow optimal performance of the active machine learning method [16,23]. Neural networks can also be employed for active machine learning purposes, but approximative methods such as Monte Carlo dropout or model ensembling are required to estimate the model uncertainty [11,24,25]. After initialization, the active machine learning procedure consists of three phases: the training of the machine learning model, the selection of new experiments, and the execution and annotation of these experiments (Fig. 1). The active machine learning query (phase 2) is determined through a so-called acquisition function, which is a measure of potential informativeness or optimality. The model needs the most informative subsequent data point, which is the point where the acquisition function is maximal for the selected query. The query is performed and new data is gathered (phase 3), after which the machine learning model is retrained (phase 1) and can now make improved predictions. This loop is sequentially iterated until an optimum (Bayesian optimization) is found or a sufficiently accurate model (active learning) is obtained. To further illustrate the workflow, we present the example of a researcher examining the performance of a new catalyst for a chemical process. The researcher either aims to investigate (with active learning) or optimize (with Bayesian optimization) the effect of reaction variables (design space), such as the temperature, pressure, and reactant concentrations, on the desired product yield (objective). First, initial experiments must be performed at a number of random combinations of temperature, pressure, and reactant concentrations. Next, the researcher initiates the active machine learning loop by training the machine learning model on these randomly picked experimental data points, after which the model proposes a new experiment. When using active learning, this experiment is the most informative one; when optimizing with Bayesian optimization, this experiment is the most likely experiment to improve upon the desired product yield. The researcher performs the experiment and retrains the machine learning model, which now makes improved predictions. The experimental selection continues until the desired number of experiments is performed and an optimal machine learning model or process condition is obtained. 1.2 Active machine learning in chemical engineering The applications of active machine learning span all the length scales of chemical engineering, from ab initio calculations [17,18,26] to material, molecule, and catalyst design [27–36], reaction design [12–14,37–42], and reactor design [43–45]. For example, the design of catalysts is an important asset in achieving carbon neutrality, as catalysts can enable more sustainable processes and can increase the energy efficiency of chemical processes in general [46]. However, catalyst design is still deemed an art nowadays, as it mainly relies on high-throughput screening and limited theoretical relations, such as the Sabatier principle and linear scaling relations [47–50]. This makes catalyst design prone to human bias, as researchers tend to exploit catalyst designs that are known to work, which hampers real breakthroughs [51,52]. With active machine learning, this human bias is removed, and a substantially larger fraction of the catalyst space can be studied. Currently, the applications of active machine learning in catalysis only consider a limited design space, varying only the catalyst composition while maintaining the catalyst structure [53,54]. For example, Zhong et al. [53] performed Bayesian optimization on density functional theory (DFT) calculations to identify and synthesize promising electrocatalysts for the reduction of CO2, whereas Nugraha et al. [54] determined the optimal composition of the most active PtPdAu catalyst to electrocatalytically oxidize methanol. In reaction or process design, the goal of Bayesian optimization is to determine the optimal operating conditions in order to maximize the product yields, minimize the emissions per product, achieve the highest energy efficiency, and so forth. Optimization of reaction conditions has been demonstrated multiple times, including multi-objective reaction optimization with both discrete and continuous variables, likely making this the most well-developed field of active machine learning in chemical engineering [12–14]. Shields et al. [39] applied Bayesian optimization to optimize the reaction conditions for a Mitsunobu reaction and obtained an optimal yield (> 99%) for several non-intuitive reaction conditions after 40 experiments, thereby overcoming the standard reaction yield of 60%. With active learning, the goal is to acquire reaction knowledge that can be used for reactor and catalyst design, process control, or retrosynthesis. Eyke et al. [11] demonstrated the potential of active learning for DoE in reaction design by predicting reaction yields for combinations of catalysts and solvents with a minimum of available data. Recently, a DoE tool for the study of chemical reactions was developed and validated on the catalytic pyrolysis of plastic waste by Ureel et al. [10]. CFD has become an important tool for reactors, optimization, and trouble shooting. Bayesian optimization makes it possible to find an optimal reactor configuration with a minimum of computationally intensive CFD simulations. Park et al. [44] demonstrated the power of multi-objective Bayesian optimization by maximizing the gas holdup and minimizing the power consumption of a stirred tank reactor. Clearly integrating active machine learning in CFD allows for a faster and more efficient reactor design. This survey shows that chemical engineering is a broad and diverse research field with a whole spectrum of possible active machine learning applications. Nevertheless, the use of active machine learning is not yet widespread, and there are some hurdles to overcome before it can become a trusted asset in the chemical engineer’s toolkit. In this perspective article, we focus on active machine learning as a DoE technique for an experimentalist and how to popularize it. We identify three types of thresholds: convincing the experimental researcher, the flexibility of data creation, and the robustness of active machine learning algorithms (Fig. 2 ). In the following sections, we discuss each of these challenges and how they can be overcome. 2 Convincing the researcher 2.1 Big data misconception At present, a knowledge gap exists between the experimentalist community and machine learning experts [55]. This knowledge gap is the fundamental reason why active machine learning is not yet being systematically applied by experimentalists. First, there is a misconception that big data is mandatory for active machine learning and that an enormous experimental campaign is required to make it feasible. Nugraha et al. [54] reported on an optimal catalyst composition performing only 47 of a total of 5151 possible experiments, as shown in Fig. 3 . In their work, Bayesian optimization was employed to determine the optimal PtPdAu catalyst composition for the electrocatalytic oxidation of methanol. Similarly, Schweidtmann et al. [12] identified their Pareto front after 68 experiments for a four-dimensional reaction optimization. Moreover, Ureel et al. [10] showed that active learning strategies are already beneficial for experimental campaigns consisting of as few as 18 experiments. These examples illustrate that both active learning and Bayesian optimization are already feasible for smaller datasets. A second issue is related less to the experimental researcher and more to the intrinsic algorithms. Initially, all active machine learning algorithms explore the entire design space, which can result in counterintuitive or trivial queries. Consequently, the experimentalist loses confidence in the machine learning tool. The initial selection of experiments does not rely on any preliminary or physical knowledge within the machine learning models. Therefore, this issue is related both to human bias and the perception of these algorithms by their users, and to the absence of preliminary knowledge within these models. Integrating process knowledge beforehand in the machine learning model is the most powerful methodology to alleviate this problem. Such knowledge can be incorporated via two different approaches: either through the design of the machine learning model, such as a Gaussian process kernel [56], or through training on literature or simulation data [57]. The incorporation of preliminary knowledge into active machine learning models will be discussed in Section 4.1. 2.2 Ease of use In active learning strategies, multiple factors are varied at the same time, whereas regular DoE strategies often vary a single factor at a time. This makes the post-processing of the experiments less trivial, as the effects of the factors are not isolated. As a result, a statistical analysis is required to draw conclusions from an experimental campaign using an active learning strategy [58]. These tools are incorporated in regular DoE software but not in the active machine learning packages that are currently available. This problem is closely related to another issue that limits the applicability of active learning—namely, its ease of use. Many different active machine learning packages exist these days, such as Gryffin [59], Phoenics [60], and BayesianOptimization [61] for Bayesian optimization, and Gaussian N-dimensional active learning framework (GandALF) [10] or general and efficient active learning (GEAL) [62] for active learning. However, most of the current active machine learning packages must be configured with Python, except for GandALF, which uses a csv spreadsheet. The use of these active machine learning tools requires programming skills, as they offer no graphical user interface (GUI), hampering the usage of these methodologies. Thus, at present, researchers that wish to use active machine learning must make a substantial time investment. This “activation barrier” is too high for many researchers, particularly because of the required ability to code. 3 Improving the flexibility of data creation 3.1 Constrained active machine learning Active machine learning algorithms are often developed on simulated data, where there are no practical limitations on the data creation side [32,36,63]. However, in real life, experimental units or procedures do not allow this flexibility. For example, even a completely automated experimental unit often needs to heat up or cool down, or requires time to stabilize, which slows down the generation of a new data point when different temperatures are selected by the algorithm. In addition, experiments are often performed in parallel (e.g., in high-throughput units), as opposed to the algorithms, which assume a sequential selection of experiments. Therefore, active machine learning strategies should be constrained to the unit on which they are used, to allow for an optimal experimental efficiency that will make them applicable to real-world applications [64]. In the example above, it is often easier to heat an experimental unit than it is to cool it; therefore, an extra constraint should be added to the algorithm to make it preferable to select experiments that increase rather than decrease in temperature. Next to constraints resulting from how the experimental equipment operates, constraints can also be important for simulations [43,45]. Let us consider a case that involves optimizing a reactor in silico using CFD. When defining the reactor geometry for CFD, it is not trivial that every type of geometry is feasible to simulate, nor that the geometry can be properly meshed or the results are mesh independent [65]. When these constraints are non-trivial, a separate machine learning model can be trained to learn the constraints and enforce the viability of the simulations [43]. Another example with constrained experimental units is a high-throughput experimental campaign that is used to screen different catalytic materials. Within these units, several experimental variables, such as temperature and pressure, are often fixed for every type of experiment per batch. This requires another constraint for the batch selection of these experiments, as the variables must be fixed for all selected queries. To tune active machine learning algorithms according to their application, a close collaboration between the machine learning expert and the experimentalist is thus required. In this way, the benefits of applying active machine learning are also available for less flexible experimental units. Symbiosis between the experimentalist and the machine learning scientist will benefit both parties. First of all, it will extend the fields of application for active machine learning as researchers become more aware of the benefits of active machine learning. This close collaboration will help in identifying useful features within these active machine learning algorithms, such as blocking or automatic post-processing. More practical constraints might be added to the experimental selection, such as the time or cost required for a proposed experiment. Lastly, this collaboration between the experimentalist and the machine learning expert assists in informing experimental researchers and removing the currently existing biases against active machine learning. 3.2 Automation In an ideal case, active machine learning is coupled with a flexible automated experimental unit or is even equipped by a robot [12,14,66]. Thus, the control and optimization of the performance of the experiments can become optimal, saving valuable time and effort. Automated experimental units are increasingly being applied in molecular synthesis and chemical engineering, although these units are not yet commonplace [67–69]. One requirement of automated robotic units is that they should be reconfigurable [70]. Moreover, they should have a broad application range and should not be limited to the investigation of a single reaction type or a narrow temperature range. Of course, the use of automated units is not self-evident, as they are often expensive and are currently not well-suited for every problem. For example, despite past efforts [71], the automated synthesis and testing of catalysts is a challenging task, especially when studying a broad design space [72]. By coupling these systems with active machine learning techniques, enormous time saving is expected for experimental campaigns, as this will speed up reaction and catalyst optimization, as well as the acquisition of scientific knowledge. A last threshold of these automated units is the question of the safety of these units. By expanding the catalyst or reaction design space, safety concerns increase, as doing so increases the probability that undesired reactions will occur. Therefore, good chemical knowledge is still required when employing these units in order to identify and incorporate safety constraints. Here, the definition of safety constraints again requires close collaboration between experimental experts and machine learning scientists. 4 Algorithm robustness 4.1 Data transfer When performing experiments, it is advantageous for the experiments to be widely applicable and to serve multiple purposes. The information gathered in experiments should be made available according to the FAIR guiding principles (i.e., findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reusability) and can then be of value for other researchers [73]. However, with active machine learning, a single objective is chosen, which determines the experimental selection. This hampers the applicability of the experiments, as only one experimental output is well-studied. For example, when investigating reactions, the conversion is typically selected as the output of interest; however, this limits the information on other properties, such as yields or selectivity. In the worst-case scenario, the yields are not measured and no information is gathered; contrarily even when these yields are measured, it cannot be guaranteed that all trends are considered in the example. As the goal of active machine learning is to model conversions, this method ignores the behavior of interesting reaction yields, which can result in trends remaining hidden. With Bayesian optimization, this does not pose an issue, as the goal is to optimize an objective, which makes the data per definition less generally applicable. Multi-objective Bayesian optimization techniques exist, whereas only single objective strategies are possible for active learning, meaning that all interesting outputs should be incorporated within a single active learning objective [12,40,44]. Therefore, to ensure the reusability of the gathered data, it is important that not only the modeled output but also other potential relevant outputs are measured during experiments. After creating data that is of wide interest, it is important to be able to incorporate that knowledge into active machine learning tools. Fig. 4 summarizes the different data sources and modeling strategies that can be employed to achieve this. When an active machine learning model is pretrained on literature data, an improved initial experimental selection is achieved that resolves the issue of suboptimal initial selection that was mentioned earlier [57]. The incorporation of literature data is trivial when the experimental uncertainty is similar to that of the newly gathered data. However, when the literature data is of better or inferior quality than the gathered data, it is important for the machine learning model to be able to make a distinction between the two. Heteroscedastic machine learning models exist [63], but they do not necessarily permit the incorporation of two separate noise factors, as the variation in noise is dependent on the variable in heteroscedastic models. Conversely, multi-fidelity active machine learning strategies make it possible to employ widely abundant low-quality data for accurate pretraining of the active machine learning model [74–76]. These methods have been developed based on simulated “experimental” data only, but they are very promising for improving the performance of active machine learning tools when applied to real experimental data. Moreover, these multi-fidelity models can also be used for the incorporation of data from a mechanistic model into the machine learning model. When the uncertainty of the mechanistic model predictions is known, an appropriate distinction can be made between experimental data and modeled data, both with their respective uncertainties, in the multi-fidelity model. In this way, additional mechanistic information can be incorporated into a machine learning model, which improves the experimental selection. Data that is closely related—but not similar in nature—can also serve as an initialization for active machine learning models [77]. For example, when modeling reactions with one type of catalyst and literature data on another catalyst are available, this data might still contain valuable information for an active learning model [78]. With active transfer learning, the goal is to leverage this knowledge from nearly similar data to obtain a machine learning model with an improved perception of the examined problem. Active transfer learning is the combination of the two main methods of active machine learning and transfer learning to make machine learning less data intensive. With transfer learning, (abundantly) available low-quality data is used to pretrain a machine learning model, which is then refined with a limited amount of high-quality data. In this way, rudimentary physical knowledge is introduced into the machine learning model, which again improves the initial experimental selection. This methodology has been proven to work on the reaction yield classification of cross-coupling reactions, by pretraining a machine learning model on reactions with different nucleophiles [78]. The reuse of literature data within active machine learning applications will further enhance the performance of these tools. The first active transfer learning approaches are being developed within chemical engineering, but further development of algorithms is crucial to make active transfer learning applicable within all domains of chemical engineering. 4.2 Synthesizability Active machine learning can be used to determine the optimal query for either optimization or modeling purposes. However, for certain problems, it is not evident that these queries are executable. For example, in catalyst or molecule design, novel compounds are proposed to synthesize and test the property of interest. Here, the representation of the catalyst or molecule is crucial for the synthesizability of the queries. Synthesizability, which is defined as the feasibility of the proposed queries, refers to whether the proposed catalysts or molecules can be synthesized, as illustrated in Fig. 5 . Often, a vector containing the catalyst composition is a simple representation of a catalyst [54,79]. This ensures the synthesizability of the catalyst but limits the design space explored by the active machine learning algorithm, as only the composition is varied and no structural or geometrical properties are considered. Ideally, the complete catalyst space is considered for every problem by, for example, considering the complete three-dimensional (3D) geometry as a representation of the catalyst site or molecule. However, not every imaginable catalyst’s or molecule’s 3D geometry can be synthesizable, so there is tradeoff between the magnitude of the design space, so-called creativity, and synthesizability. As illustrated by the previous example, the problem of synthesizability essentially boils down to a problem of the machine learning representation upon which constraints are added to enforce synthesizability. One intuitive approach is to use the synthesis process of the catalyst or molecule as the machine learning representation. A vector containing the catalyst composition, calcination temperature and time, and presence of ion exchange or impregnation can be used to represent a catalyst. In this way, the synthesizability of the queries is ensured, as every proposed recipe is executable. However, this representation does not necessarily ensure an easy mapping to the property of interest, and an increased amount of data might be required to model this relation. Aside from this intuitive approach, learned machine learning representations make it possible to create a continuous representation, which ensures the validity of the proposed queries [80,81]. By training recently developed methodologies such as variational auto-encoders or generative adversarial neural networks on a set of synthesizable molecules or catalysts, a learned machine learning representation—that is, a so-called latent space—can be developed, ensuring the synthesizability of the proposed queries [80,82,83]. Upon this representation, additional constraints on the catalyst or molecule can be enforced, according to the application [31]. Finding an adequate representation is always important in machine learning problems. For active machine learning, this representation is essential in order to harmonize both synthesizability and creativity. 5 Conclusions and perspectives Active machine learning is extremely well suited for use by chemical engineering researchers to speed up experimental campaigns ranging from molecule and catalyst design to reaction and reactor design. However, active machine learning is not well-known among experimental researchers, and many active machine learning applications are not currently user friendly. Better collaboration between machine learning experts and chemical engineers can overcome these barriers. Such interactions will also help to tune active machine learning algorithms, depending on the applied (automated) experimental units and procedures, which will improve the performance of these algorithms. A key barrier here is the suboptimal initial experimental selection, which can be overcome by integrating transfer learning and active learning with the aid of multi-fidelity models. Moreover, the application domain of active machine learning can be significantly extended by adapting general active machine learning algorithms to obtain “tailor-made” algorithms, depending on the setup constraints. While the algorithms should be customized, the data should be generally usable, such that performed experiments can serve multiple purposes. By harmonizing synthesizability and creativity, active machine learning is bound to make significant advances in the fields of molecule and catalyst synthesis. Recent promising breakthroughs will allow active machine learning to become an essential tool for the chemical engineer and will further facilitate autonomous and efficient scientific discoveries, which will contribute to a more sustainable chemical industry in the future. 101403 S0377-0265(23)00054-4 10.1016/j.dynatmoce.2023.101403 The Authors Fig. 1 (a) Schematic diagram of the circulation structure and bathymetry (m) in the Pacific Ocean, and (b) long-term average SST (°C) derived from Argo data spanning January 2010 to December 2020. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Ensemble-ML model flowchart for estimating OSTS in the Pacific Ocean. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Comparison of long-term monthly average SST (a) and SSS (b) in the Pacific Ocean (120°E to 80°W, 50°S to 50°N) between January 2010 and December 2020, using Argo (represented by dashed black line) and satellite (represented by solid blue line) data. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Comparison of long-term average SST and SSS obtained from satellite (left panel) and Argo data (middle panel) in the Pacific Ocean, spanning from January 2010 to December 2020. The right panel displays the differences between the satellite and Argo data (satellite minus Argo). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Comparison of OSTS estimation using the Ensemble-ML model (black line) and four individual machine learning models (ExtraTrees: yellow line, XGBoost: blue line, LightGBM: purple line, RandomForest: red line). Evaluations are based on RMSE (a) and R2 (b), both averaged across all depths for the entire study area in 2020. CAS Key Laboratory of Ocean Circulation and Waves, Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of Sciences Qingdao China Estimation of the ocean subsurface thermal structure (OSTS) is important for understanding thermodynamic processes and climate variability. In the present study, a novel multi-model ensemble machine learning (Ensemble-ML) model is developed to retrieve subsurface thermal structure in the Pacific Ocean by integrating sea surface data with Argo observations. The Ensemble-ML model integrates four individual machine learning models to enhance estimation accuracy and reliability. Our results exhibit good agreement between the satellite sea surface temperature (SST) and sea surface salinity (SSS) data and Argo observations, providing validation for the utilization of these datasets in the Ensemble-ML model. The Ensemble-ML model exhibits better performance compared to individual machine learning models, with an average root mean square error (RMSE) of 0.3273 °C and an average coefficient of determination (R²) of 0.9905. Notably, incorporating geographical information as input variables enhance model performance, emphasizing the importance of considering spatial context in OSTS estimation. The Ensemble-ML model accurately captures the spatial distribution of OSTS across depths and seasons in the Pacific Ocean, effectively reproducing critical temperature features while maintaining strong agreement with Argo observations. Nevertheless, its performance shows relative weakness within the thermocline layer and the equatorial Pacific region (spanning from 10°S to 10°N latitude), which are characterized by complex circulation systems. Despite these challenges, the Ensemble-ML model effectively reproduces the spatial distribution of OSTS of the Pacific Ocean. This indicates the potential of machine learning models, particularly ensemble models, for enhancing OSTS estimation in the Pacific Ocean and other regions, offering valuable insights for future research and applications in physical oceanography. Keywords Ensemble machine learning model Satellite observations Ocean subsurface thermal structure Pacific ocean Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ocean temperature, as an important parameter of seawater, plays important roles in various aspects of the Earth’s climate system (Qu et al., 2000; Levitus et al., 2012; Abraham et al., 2013; Qi et al., 2020; Tsubouchi et al., 2021). Changes in temperature can affect various oceanic phenomena, such as marine heatwaves (Smale et al., 2019), water mass formation (Speer and Tziperman, 1992), thermocline layer formation (Du et al., 2020), and the evolution of El Niño (Planton et al., 2021). Moreover, these changes can exert substantial impacts on marine ecosystems (Toseland et al., 2013). Hence, the accurate estimation of the ocean subsurface thermal structure (OSTS) is important for studying marine ecosystems, ocean dynamic processes, and global climate. As the world’s largest ocean, the Pacific Ocean is characterized by complex circulation patterns, rendering it a critical component of the global climate system ( Fig. 1). A comprehensive understanding of the ocean thermal structure in this region holds utmost significance, which plays a significant role in comprehending the impacts of climate change, monitoring marine ecosystems, and forecasting extreme weather events (Trenberth and Caron, 2001; Toseland et al., 2013). Consequently, it is very important to estimate the OSTS in the Pacific Ocean, which is vital for understanding the intricate physical processes governing oceanic and atmospheric interactions and their influences on climate system, such as the underlying mechanisms of El Niño/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) (McPhaden et al., 2011; Hoell et al., 2014). Traditionally, the OSTS estimation in the Pacific Ocean has largely depended on numerical modeling and assimilative dynamic model methods (Liu et al., 2005; Kako and Kubota, 2009; Yin et al., 2012). Nevertheless, the computational demands imposed by these methodologies are significant, owing to the intricate nature of thermodynamic processes. Thus, the pursuit of a more accurate and efficient approach for OSTS estimation has emerged as a research hotspot. The rapid advancement of satellite remote sensing technology has provided valuable, high-resolution observational data of the sea surface, such as sea surface temperature (SST), sea surface salinity (SSS), sea surface height (SSH), and more. Early studies have demonstrated the existence of surface manifestations of some oceanic subsurface phenomena, which can be used to retrieve the complex structures within the ocean interior through the utilization of sea surface data (Ali et al., 2004; Klemas and Yan, 2014). For example, SSH can be used as indicators of thermocline depth, and its changes can reflect changes in the depth of the thermocline (Wilson and Coles, 2005). SST is closely linked with the ocean's interior temperature structure. It has been demonstrated that SST can be used to estimate the OSTS (Chu et al., 2000). Moreover, Vernieres et al. (2014) and Lu et al. (2016) have illustrated a strong association between SSS and subsurface salinity structures. All these results indicate that there is a close mapping relationship between sea surface variables and subsurface structures. This concept has inspired many researchers to use different approaches to investigate the potential of sea surface parameters for estimating ocean subsurface temperature and salinity structures, including statistical relationships (Yan et al., 2020), empirical orthogonal functions (Meijers et al., 2011), parametric models (Chu et al., 2000), and linear regression models (Guinehut et al., 2012). These innovative approaches have demonstrated significant potential for advancing our understanding of the complex processes governing the ocean as well as its influence on climate and ecosystems. However, it is vital to acknowledge the distinct strengths and limitations inherent in each method, thereby inspiring researchers to delve into innovative approaches for retrieving the intricate structures of the ocean interior through the utilization of sea surface data. Recently, machine learning has gained popularity in geoscience fields, including ocean and atmosphere research, offering new insights into the dynamics and thermodynamic processes of the ocean (Reichstein et al., 2019; Zheng et al., 2020). Additionally, machine learning has exhibited promising potential in the prediction of climate variations, contributing to our understanding of Earth's complex climate system (Ham et al., 2019). Therefore, we can utilize the powerful information extraction capabilities of machine learning models to discover the relationship between sea surface data and subsurface structures. In recent years, estimating OSTS using machine learning methods has become a topic of significant interest. Ali et al. (2004) employed an artificial neural network (ANN) approach, utilizing sea surface data to reconstruct the thermal structure. Their findings showed the efficacy of the ANN approach in accurately estimating OSTS using sea surface data. Moreover, they demonstrated its remarkable capability in predicting cyclone tracks (Ali et al., 2007). Wu et al. (2012) utilized a self-organizing map neural network to reconstruct OSTS using sea surface data. Their study demonstrated the superiority of their model over traditional methods in the North Atlantic. Other studies, such as those by Su et al. (2015, 2018, 2021), have demonstrated successful OSTS estimation using different machine learning methodologies. Lu et al. (2019) introduced a clustering-neural network method for estimating subsurface temperature using remote sensing data. Their study revealed the superior performance of the pre-clustered neural network method compared to the non-clustered approach. Bao et al. (2019) employed the fruit fly optimization algorithm (FOA) in conjunction with a generalized regression neural network (GRNN) to successfully estimate the subsurface salinity structure of the Pacific Ocean. Most recently, Meng et al. (2021) proposed a novel machine learning-based model for reconstructing subsurface temperature and salinity structure using a pre-trained neural network, reporting high accuracy compared to traditional linear methods. Despite the advantages shown by machine learning and deep learning methods in estimating OSTS, they still have limitations due to the requirement of large amounts of high-quality data, which is difficult to obtain in oceanography. Researchers are therefore exploring innovative approaches to enhance the accuracy and effectiveness of these models under limited data conditions. One such approach is the multi-model ensemble, which has gained popularity in oceanography due to its ability to combine the strengths of multiple models and mitigate the limitations of individual models (Becker et al., 2022). Compared to traditional machine learning methods, the multi-model ensemble has demonstrated a significant advantage in estimating and predicting oceanographic and climate phenomena, such as SST variability and trends, precipitation patterns, and ocean circulation patterns (Stouffer et al., 2006; Weisheimer et al., 2009; Xu et al., 2020; Qi et al., 2022; Zhao et al., 2022). Recently, Ko et al. (2023) explored the application of a consensus machine learning model in tropical cyclone (TC) intensity-change forecasting. The consensus machine learning model was based on six classical machine learning models, namely, Logistic Regression, k-Nearest Neighbors, Decision Trees, RandomForests, Support Vector Machines, and ANN. Their results indicated that the consensus machine learning model exhibits notable performance in TC intensity-change forecasting, especially in the forecasting of rapid intensification. Here, we propose a novel ensemble machine learning (Ensemble-ML) model to reconstruct the OSTS in the Pacific Ocean by using sea surface data. Our Ensemble-ML model is based on four individual models, including ExtraTrees, extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost), RandomForest, and light gradient boosting machine (LightGBM), and we use an ANN to combine the outputs of these models. The study is structured as follows: data and methodology are presented in Section 2, followed by a description of the results in Section 3. In Section 4, we provide a summary of our results and insights. 2 Data and methodology 2.1 Data A variety of multisource satellite observations were utilized to estimate the OSTS of the Pacific Ocean in this study. Based on earlier studies, we have selected SST, SSS, SSH anomaly (SSHA), and SSW as inputs for the deep learning model. The SSW data can be divided into eastward wind speed (USSW) and northward wind speed (VSSW) components. Additionally, geographic information such as longitude (LON) and latitude (LAT) were also included as inputs. The monthly SST data utilized in this study, covering the period from January 2010 to December 2020, were obtained from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) using a 0.25° latitude × 0.25° longitude resolution (Reynolds et al., 2002). The monthly SSS data were obtained from the Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity (SMOS) Level-3 SSS product with a horizontal resolution of 0.25° latitude × 0.25° longitude (Boutin et al., 2018). The monthly SSHA data were obtained from the Archiving, Validation and Interpretation of Satellite Oceanographic (AVISO) data center with a horizontal resolution of 0.25° latitude × 0.25° longitude (Hauser et al., 2020). The SSW data were derived from the Cross-Calibrated Multi-Platform (CCMP) product with a horizontal resolution of 0.25° latitude × 0.25° longitude (Atlas et al., 2011). It should be noted that the SSW has two temporal resolutions: it is monthly from 2010 to 2015 and 1/4 day from 2016 to 2020. The monthly Roemmich-Gilson Argo Climatology (RG-Argo) gridded data, which has a horizontal resolution of 1° latitude × 1° longitude, were utilized to train and test the model's performance (Roemmich and Gilson, 2009). All the data used in this study, including the SSW, were monthly averaged from January 2010 to December 2020. They were interpolated onto a 1° latitude × 1° longitude grid, covering the Pacific Ocean from 120°E to 80°W and from 50°S to 50°N. Missing data points were excluded. The data utilized in this paper is summarized in Table 1. 2.2 Methods As mentioned previously, ensemble learning techniques have been widely recognized for their ability to improve estimation accuracy by incorporating the outputs of multiple machine learning models. Among many ensemble learning methods available, ANN is one of the most popular methods for merging multiple models, owing to its effectiveness and simplicity. Based on results of earlier studies, we chose four machine learning models as our foundational models: XGBoost, LightGBM, RandomForest, and ExtraTrees (Callens et al., 2020; Su et al., 2021; Hu et al., 2021). Each of these models has demonstrated robust performance in various oceanography-related work. Here, we propose an ANN-based Ensemble-ML model to estimate the OSTS in the Pacific, which combines outputs of four pre-trained individual models. 2.2.1 Machine learning models The XGBoost and LightGBM are two popular gradient boosting frameworks that have gained increasing attention in recent years. XGBoost incorporates the second derivative of the error function at each data point to optimize the loss function (Chen et al., 2015). During model training, it only uses a subset of samples and features for training, effectively improving model generalization ability and reducing underfitting and overfitting phenomena. LightGBM, a gradient boosting framework, has garnered significant attention in recent years for its remarkable efficiency and accuracy surpassing other boosting frameworks. It can divide continuous features into discrete bins using a histogram-based algorithm to handle sparse data and reduce memory usage (Ke et al., 2017). RandomForest and ExtraTrees are two popular ensemble learning methods that enhance model accuracy by integrating multiple decision trees. RandomForest builds each tree by randomly selecting a subset of data points and features, and then consolidates the predictions of all trees through either majority voting or averaging to generate the final prediction (Breiman, 2001). In contrast, ExtraTrees constructs each tree by employing random sub-sampling of both the features and the training data, and applying random thresholds for each feature, leading to the creation of more random and less biased trees (Geurts et al., 2006). Unlike RandomForest, ExtraTrees grows trees to their maximum extent without any pruning, which reduces the model's variance and prevents overfitting. These algorithms are renowned for their efficiency and speed and are often employed in scenarios involving large datasets and high-dimensional data. We also utilize ANN in our study, a popular machine learning technique inspired by the human brain's neural networks (Haykin, 1998). ANN is comprised of multiple interconnected layers of nodes and can learn complex nonlinear relationships between inputs and outputs. It has been extensively applied in oceanographic research, with successful applications in the estimation of ocean temperature and salinity structure and prediction of cyclone tracks (Ali et al., 2004, 2007; Meng et al., 2021). The ANN's capacity to model intricate relationships between variables makes it a valuable tool for machine learning tasks, including regression and classification problems. 2.2.2 Ensemble-ML model Fig. 2 illustrates the flowchart of the Ensemble-ML model to estimate the OSTS in the Pacific Ocean. This model comprises two main steps: (1) development of the training, validation, and testing datasets, where sea surface data, including SST, SSS, SSHA, SSW, LON, and LAT, are used as inputs, while Argo data serve as labels; and (2) the model training stage, in which four individual machine learning models (XGBoost, RandomForest, ExtraTrees, and LightGBM) are trained to estimate the OSTS of the Pacific Ocean. Then, we combine the four models' outputs using ANN to obtain the final estimation for the Ensemble-ML model. The training dataset is used to train the model, and the validation dataset is used to verify the model's performance during training and to prevent overfitting. The test dataset is used to evaluate the model's finalized performance. Previous studies have shown that an 80–20 % split between training and testing in machine learning is a widely accepted convention to learn from data while also preventing model overfitting (Pauthenet et al., 2022; Tian et al., 2022). However, due to data limitations in this study and to facilitate result comparisons, we select monthly averages from January 2010 to December 2019 as the training dataset, with 80 % randomly selected for training and 20 % for validation. The model is evaluated using data from 2020, utilizing metrics such as root mean square error (RMSE), normalized root mean square error (NRMSE), and determination coefficient (R²). To prevent overfitting, early stopping and dropout techniques are implemented. We adopt a grid search approach to determine the optimal parameter combinations for each individual machine learning model, as shown in Table 2. The estimated values obtained from each machine learning model are expressed as follows: (1) OSTS XGBoost = F XGBoost SST , SSS , SSHA , SSW , LON , LAT OSTS RandomForest = F RandomForest SST , SSS , SSHA , SSW , LON , LAT OSTS ExtraTrees = F ExtraTrees SST , SSS , SSHA , SSW , LON , LAT OSTS LightGBM = F LightGBM SST , SSS , SSHA , SSW , LON , LAT Where OSTS XGBoost , OSTS RandomForest , OSTS ExtraTrees , OSTS LightGBM are the estimated values obtained from XGBoost, RandomForest, ExtraTrees, and LightGBM, respectively, while F XGBoost , F RandomForest , F ExtraTrees , F LightGBM are the model functions for the optimal parameters of XGBoost, RandomForest, ExtraTrees, and LightGBM, respectively. The final model results are obtained by calculating the weighted sum of the estimated outputs from four individual machine learning models based on ANN as follows: (2) OSTS estimation = ANN ( OSTS XGBoost , OSTS RandomForest , OSTS ExtraTrees , OSTS LightGBM ) 3 Results 3.1 Comparison between satellite data and argo observations The accuracy and effectiveness of machine learning models depend greatly on the accuracy of input variables. Inaccurate inputs can lead to unreliable model outputs, which hinders progress in the field. Thus, it is crucial to validate input variables to ensure optimal performance. Previous studies have identified SST and SSS as the two most important factors in the estimation of OSTS (Qi et al., 2022; Pauthenet et al., 2022). Therefore, a temporal and spatial comparison was carried out between satellite-derived SST and SSS data and Argo-observed data. Our results reveal a substantial agreement in the seasonal variations of SST between satellite and Argo data. Moreover, the seasonal changes in satellite-derived SSS also exhibit a strong correlation with Argo-derived SSS data, as illustrated in Fig. 3. The correlation coefficients between satellite and Argo data are 0.9951 for SST and 0.9228 for SSS, respectively. These results confirm the accuracy and reliability of satellite-based data, thus validating their suitability for use in machine learning models, such as the Ensemble-ML model we employed. Furthermore, a spatial comparison of long-term averaged (2010–2020) SST and SSS derived from satellite and Argo data was conducted ( Fig. 4). The results demonstrate a high consistent spatial distribution of satellite-derived data with Argo-observed data. Both datasets revealed a roughly symmetrical pattern of SST around the equator, with temperature values gradually decreasing from the equatorial Pacific towards both poles. Maximum SST discrepancies were mainly observed in the area near 40°S and 40°N, with discrepancies not exceeding 1.2 °C (Fig. 4c). Similarly, the spatial distribution of SSS derived from satellite and Argo observations exhibited consistent patterns, including the presence of the eastern Pacific salinity front, a high salinity region in the southeastern Pacific Ocean, and a low salinity region in the northeastern Pacific Ocean. Overall, these results validate the accuracy and reliability of satellite-derived data, providing crucial support for the estimation of OSTS. 3.2 Comparison of ensemble-ML model with individual models After identifying the optimal combination of parameters, we proceeded to evaluate the performance of the Ensemble-ML model as well as four individual models in the estimation of OSTS in the Pacific in 2020. Fig. 5 shows the vertical distribution of RMSE values, showing an increasing trend from the surface to a maximum around 100–150 m, followed by a subsequent decrease. In contrast, the vertical variation pattern of R2 exhibits distinct differences compared to RMSE. Apart from the XGBoost and ExtraTrees models, the vertical variation of R2 was not significant in other models. Nonetheless, from the surface to a depth of 100–150 m, R2 exhibited a decline trend. Importantly, within the depth range of approximately 100–150 m, the RMSE values were relatively higher, while the R2 values were lower. This trend is likely due to the influence of the thermocline layer, which results in the challenges of accurately estimating the OSTS. Overall, the Ensemble-ML model consistently outperformed the four individual models with lower RMSE values and higher R2 values (Fig. 5). The performance of the Ensemble-ML model and the four individual machine learning models in estimating the OSTS in the Pacific Ocean is summarized in Table 3. The Ensemble-ML model demonstrated superior accuracy, yielding an average RMSE of 0.3273 °C and an average R² of 0.9905, surpassing the performance of the individual models. The LightGBM model exhibited the second-highest overall accuracy, with an average RMSE of 0.3572 °C and an average R² of 0.9894. The RandomForest and ExtraTrees models achieved the third and fourth positions, respectively, with average RMSE and R² values of 0.4232 °C/0.9841 and 0.7408 °C/0.9508. In contrast, the XGBoost model demonstrated the lowest overall accuracy, with an average RMSE of 0.9046 °C and an average R² of 0.9374. One noteworthy aspect of this study, which distinguishes it from earlier studies, is the incorporation of geographical information as input variables in the Ensemble-ML model. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate the effectiveness of including geographical information as an input. To achieve this, two sets of experiments (Cases 1 and 2) were conducted, each using different combination of input parameters ( Table 4). In Case 1, we selected all the input parameters SST, SSS, SSHA, USSW, and VSSW, along with LON and LAT, while in case 2, LON and LAT were not included as input parameters. As shown in Fig. 6, Case 1 yielded significantly lower RMSE and higher R2 values than Case 2 across all depths. For Case 1, the Ensemble-ML model exhibited vertically averaged RMSE and R2 values of 0.3368 °C and 0.9900, respectively. In contrast, for Case 2, the corresponding values were 0.5012 °C and 0.9752, respectively. These results clearly demonstrate that incorporating geographical information (LAT, LON) as an input greatly improves the precision of OSTS estimation in the Pacific Ocean. This indicates the importance of including geographical information in the estimation of OSTS. Nonetheless, it is worth noting that the effectiveness of geographical information could vary depending on the location and spatial resolution of the data. For a detailed explanation of this issue, further research is necessary. 3.3 Evaluation of the ensemble-ML model’s performance Here, we provide a comprehensive evaluation of the Ensemble-ML model's performance in estimating OSTS, examining it from various perspectives. First, we conducted a spatial comparison between the OSTS estimated by the Ensemble-ML model and derived by the Argo at four different depths (50 m, 100 m, 500 m, and 1000 m) in 2020 ( Fig. 7). The results show that the Ensemble-ML model performed well, as the estimated OSTS distribution closely matched the Argo observations at various depths. The Ensemble-ML model successfully captured the key temperature features using sea surface data. At 50 m depth, both the Ensemble-ML model estimated data and Argo-derived data revealed a symmetric distribution around the equator, with temperatures gradually decreasing towards the poles. The western Pacific region exhibited the highest temperatures, exceeding 30 °C. Relatively large temperature differences between them primarily occurred in the eastern equatorial Pacific region (>1.5 °C), which can be attributed to the complex circulation structure in this region (Fig. 7a). The complex upwelling system in this region poses challenges in accurately estimating the upper-layer temperature structure using sea surface data. At 100 m depth, there was also a good agreement between the Ensemble-ML model estimated OSTS and Argo observed OSTS. However, we observed slightly larger differences compared to the 50 m depth, ranging primarily from − 0.78 to 0.78 °C. This difference is mainly related the presence of the thermocline layer at this depth. With increasing depth, the temperature exhibited greater stability. At 500 m depth, the temperature range was confined to 3.92–11.16 °C, indicating relatively small temperature differences, primarily ranging from − 0.33 to 0.36 °C. At 1000 m depth, the temperature difference was found to be minimal, ranging from − 0.16 to 0.12 °C. The discrepancies in the estimation process can be ascribed to two sources: errors stemming from data and model. Data errors mainly originate from the limitations associated with observational instruments and the influence of environmental conditions. On the other hand, model errors stem from the intrinsic shortcomings of the Ensemble-ML approach, a statistical method that draws on the interplay between sea surface data and the underlying configuration of ocean structures. The relationship between sea surface data and subsurface temperature structure exhibits considerable variability due to various dynamic processes, including downwelling and upwelling, which results in errors in the estimation model. To further verify the significance of including geographical information in OSTS estimation, we conducted a spatial comparison. This compared the OSTS as estimated by the Ensemble-ML model (which did not use geographical information as input) with the data derived from the Argo observation in 2020, as shown in Fig. 8. While the Ensemble-ML model without considering geographical information can capture most temperature features from sea surface data, it displayed greater errors across various depths compared to the Ensemble-ML that did include geographical data. This further demonstrates the important role of geographical information in OSTS estimation. To provide a more thorough evaluation of the Ensemble-ML model's vertical performance, we selected two representative sections for analysis: a zonal transect (a) along the equator spanning from 150°E to 80°W, and a meridional transect (b) along 160°W from 50°S to 50°N, as depicted in Fig. 9. By comparing the OSTS derived from Argo observations with the Ensemble-ML model estimation in these sections ( Fig. 10), we further evaluated the model's accuracy in estimating the vertical structure. The Ensemble-ML model successfully captures the spatial distribution of OSTS and exhibits strong agreement with Argo observations. For the zonal transect (a), both the observed and estimated temperature exhibited a pronounced east-west gradient in the surface layer and thermocline depth, as indicated by the 20 °C isotherm. Specifically, the thermocline depth is about 50 m in the eastern Equatorial Pacific, compared to over 150 m in the western Equatorial Pacific. The temperature decreased rapidly from the surface down to the thermocline depth, below which it tended to decrease more gradually, reaching a relatively stable range of 3.1–7.8 °C below 500 m. In the upper 150 m, we observed large temperature differences (less than 2 °C) between 150°W and 90°W, with the observed temperature values lower than the estimated temperature values. Similarly, for the meridional transect (b), the Ensemble-ML model accurately reproduces the OSTS and exhibits consistent spatial distribution patterns with the Argo observations. However, relatively large differences (exceeding 1.5 °C) mainly occurred in the upper layer (50–240 m) of the equatorial region, which can be attributed to the complex circulation system in the equatorial Pacific region. To further assess the vertical performance of the model, we conducted a comparison between temperature profiles estimated by the Ensemble-ML model and Argo profiles in some key regions during 2020 ( Fig. 11). Considering the horizontal distribution features of temperature, we selected four representative regions (Boxes A, B, C, and D) as illustrated in Fig. 9. Box A (150–180°E and 5°S–5°N) is located in the western Pacific warm pool, Box B (170–120°W and 5°S–5°N) is situated in the Niño 3.4 region, Box C (135–115°W and 15–25°S) is in the maximum SSS region of the South Pacific Ocean, and Box D (170°E–170°W and 20–30°N) is in the maximum SSS region of the North Pacific Ocean. By selecting these boxes, we were able to conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the Ensemble-ML model's ability to capture the complex and distinct temperature features in these regions. Our results indicate a good level of agreement between the vertical temperature profiles estimated by the Ensemble-ML model and those observed by Argo in the four selected regions (Fig. 11). The accurate estimation of temperature values in these key regions is also demonstrated by the calculated vertical mean RMSE and R² values for each box. The calculated RMSE and R² values for Boxes A, B, C, and D were as follows: 0.1867 °C and 0.9996, 0.1310 °C and 0.9997, 0.1742 °C and 0.9995, and 0.2498 °C and 0.9988, respectively. Correlation density scatterplots were generated to assess the relationship between temperature estimates from the Ensemble-ML model and Argo at various depths ( Fig. 12). The scatterplots demonstrate a good agreement between the temperature estimated by Ensemble-ML model and derived by Argo, with points closely aligned along the line of equal value. The RMSE and R² values were computed to assess the agreement between the Argo-observed temperature and the Ensemble-ML model estimated temperature at depths of 50 m, 100 m, 500 m, and 1000 m. At 50 m depth, the RMSE and R² values were 0.4540 °C and 0.9954, respectively. At 100 m depth, the RMSE and R² values were 0.5331 °C and 0.9933, respectively. For 500 m depth, the RMSE and R² values were 0.2058 °C and 0.9835, respectively. At 1000 m depth, the RMSE and R² values were 0.0741 °C and 0.9867, respectively. These results provide additional evidence of the Ensemble-ML model's reliability and accuracy in estimating OSTS in the upper 1000 m of the Pacific Ocean. Although the Ensemble-ML model has demonstrated good performance in estimating OSTS in the Pacific Ocean, its seasonal performance has yet to be evaluated. In the following section, we assessed the model’s performance during four different seasons at different depth levels in 2020. To ensure comparability across depths, we normalized the RMSE values (NRMSE) by dividing them by the range of the monthly temperature range from Argo (defined by the difference between its maximum and minimum values) for each grid and depth. The NRMSE and R² values for different seasons at various depths are presented in Fig. 13. We evaluated the model's performance in different seasons, including February (winter), May (spring), August (summer), and November (autumn). The Ensemble-ML model demonstrates good performance across different seasons, as depicted in Fig. 13. The NRMSE values in different seasons exhibited an increasing trend from the surface to about 50–100 m depth, followed by a decreasing trend to about 500–600 m depth, and then an increasing trend to 1000 m depth. The maximum NRMSE value appeared between 50 and 100 m, likely due to the presence of the thermocline layer. Moreover, the accuracy of the Ensemble-ML model generally decreased with increasing depth below 600 m. Estimating phenomena in the deeper layers (below 600 m) becomes more challenging due to their weaker surface manifestations using sea surface data. Moreover, the higher NRMSE values in the upper 100 m may be attributed to the intricate dynamic processes occurring in the upper ocean. As for R², its values were generally greater than 0.95 from the surface to 1000 m depth, which also indicates the model's good seasonal performance. Overall, the Ensemble-ML model performs well in OSTS estimation across different seasons, highlighting its reliability and accuracy in the Pacific Ocean. The above discussion evaluates the performance of the Ensemble-ML model for 2020. Naturally, a question arises: How does the Ensemble-ML perform across different years, especially during unique periods like the El Niño phase? To address this, we have conducted a leave-one-out verification experiment. We estimated the OSTS for each year from 2010 to 2020, training the Ensemble-ML model on data from the remaining ten years. For instance, to estimate the 2010 data, we used the dataset spanning 2011–2020, whereas the 2011 data estimation obtained from the combined 2010 and 2012–2020 datasets, and so on. This methodology provided us with OSTS data for the entire period from 2010 to 2020. Using the estimated data, we calculated the ocean heat content in the upper 200 m of the equatorial Pacific Ocean (between 120°E to 80°W and 10°S to 10°N), subsequently comparing it with Argo observations. As shown in Fig. 14, the Ensemble-ML's estimation of ocean heat content agrees well with the Argo data, a consistency that persists even during the 2015–2016 El Niño event. The correlation coefficient between the Ensemble-ML's estimates and the Argo observations is 0.89 after a 3-month moving average, exceeding the 95 % confidence interval. Such a good agreement between the datasets exhibit the model’s robustness in accurately estimating OSTS and highlights its potential for future research applications. 4 Discussion and conclusions In this study, an Ensemble-ML model was proposed to estimate the OSTS of the Pacific Ocean, utilizing a combination of sea surface data and Argo observations. The Ensemble-ML model combines four machine learning models (ExtraTrees, XGBoost, RandomForest, and LightGBM) to improve the accuracy and effectiveness of the OSTS estimation. The model's performance was thoroughly evaluated across various aspects. Satellite-derived SST and SSS data exhibited strong agreement with Argo observations in terms of both spatial and temporal distribution. This validates the suitability of satellite-based data for machine learning models like the Ensemble-ML model. The Ensemble-ML model consistently outperformed the individual machine learning models, achieving the highest level of accuracy in estimating OSTS in the Pacific Ocean with an average RMSE of 0.3273 °C and an average R² of 0.9905. The model's performance further improved when including geographical information as inputs, highlighting the importance of considering spatial context in OSTS estimation. Our evaluation demonstrated that the Ensemble-ML model accurately captured the spatial distribution of OSTS at different depths in the Pacific Ocean, consistently reproducing important temperature features and showing good agreement with Argo observations. Additionally, the model performed well across various seasons and depths, indicating its robustness and potential applicability in a wide range of contexts. One of the major challenges in OSTS estimation is the presence of the thermocline layer, characterized by a rapid change in temperature, which hinders the accurate prediction of subsurface temperature structure. Our results indicated that the Ensemble-ML model's performance was relatively weaker in the thermocline layer, with higher RMSE values and lower R² values observed at depths of 100–150 m. Nevertheless, our model still demonstrated a high level of overall accuracy. The complex circulation systems in the equatorial Pacific region, such as upwelling and downwelling processes, pose additional challenges in accurately estimating OSTS. In this study, the Ensemble-ML model exhibited relatively larger discrepancies in this region, especially in the upper layers (50–240 m). However, despite these challenges, the model effectively reproduced the spatial distribution of OSTS and captured the vertical temperature structure in the Pacific Ocean. Errors in the estimation process can be attributed to two main sources: data errors and errors in the estimation model. Data errors primarily stem from observational equipment and environmental conditions, while estimation model errors arise from the inherent limitations of the Ensemble-ML method. Despite the limitations and challenges, the performance of Ensemble-ML model in estimating OSTS in the Pacific Ocean is promising. The Ensemble-ML model could potentially be applied to other ocean basins or regions, although further investigation is required to understand the model's effectiveness in different contexts and regions. In conclusion, this study introduces a novel application of an Ensemble-ML model for accurate estimation of OSTS in the Pacific Ocean using sea surface data. The model demonstrates a high level of accuracy and reliability, effectively capturing the spatial distribution of OSTS and the vertical temperature structure. Our findings indicate the potential of machine learning models, particularly ensemble models, for enhancing OSTS estimation in the Pacific Ocean and other regions, offering valuable insights for future research and applications in physical oceanography. It is worth mentioning that the selection of input variables may not represent the optimal combination, leaving room for further analysis and future research.
