College of Materials and Environmental Engineering, Hangzhou Dianzi University, China. College of Materials and Environmental Engineering Hangzhou Dianzi University China ∗∗ Corresponding author. Machine learning is extensively utilized for predicting creep rupture of high-temperature steels. Recently, five soft-constrained machine learning algorithms (SCMLAs) have been developed to enhance the extrapolation capabilities of machine learning. These SCMLAs were applied to the austenitic steel Sanicro 25, showing their potential. To improve SCMLAs, this study has introduced new guidelines that address temperature culling within the input range and temperature extrapolation beyond the input range. Leveraging these guidelines, the SCMLAs were extended to various austenitic and martensitic stainless steels. The predicted results of TP316H, the data of which is representative of austenitic stainless steels, were validated through error estimates. Furthermore, notable agreement has been reached for temperature culling and temperature extrapolation, as demonstrated for TP91 and TP92 martensitic steels. The effects of single casts and the temperature dependence of the predictions have been analyzed for the studied materials. Consistent results can be readily achieved through systematic evaluations of SCMLAs for extrapolating up to 300,000 h or three times the maximum experimental rupture time for the studied materials. It is demonstrated that SCMLAs can provide reliable creep rupture life prediction across various high-temperature materials. Keywords Creep rupture extrapolation Soft-constrained machine learning Soft-constrained neural network Stainless steels Error estimate 1 Introduction Creep properties play a vital role in engineering materials serving at high temperatures and stresses for a long time, such as fossil fuel-fired, petrochemical, and nuclear power plants. The accurate prediction of creep rupture behavior has a long history; many models have been developed to address this challenge. Empirical or phenomenological models, such as the Norton equation, Time-Temperature Parameters (TTP), and the Wilshire Equation, have gained prominence due to their simplicity and ability to yield good fits to observations. However, these methods rely on multiple adjustable parameters and, in general, lack a solid theoretical foundation. In contrast, fundamental models for predicting creep rupture of fcc metals have been proposed [1–6] but are not yet widely used in spite of their potential. They require a quantitative description of the operating mechanisms, which are not always available. Some common TTPs generally assume an approximately linear relationship between creep rupture life (t R) and temperature (T K), i.e., log(t R) vs. 1/T K, implying a constant activation energy (Q c) for creep rupture [7–9]. However, this does not always hold, for example for TP91 (9Cr1MoVNb) steels [8]. In practice, it is often observed that there is a change in Q c at longer times, indicating alterations of the creep rupture mechanisms [8,10], which may be attributed to particle coarsening or substructure coarsening [10]. Consequently, common TTPs may overestimate the creep rupture life. To mitigate this overestimation, Maruyama et al. proposed a multiregion analysis approach based on the stress exponent and activation energy. The multiregion analysis has been successfully applied to single casts of various materials such as austenitic stainless steels TP316H [7], high Cr steels TP91 [8,9,11] and TP92 (9Cr1.8W0.5MoVNb) [10]. On the other hand, machine Learning algorithms, such as Neural Networks (NNs), present a compelling alternative to conventional empirical methods for analyzing creep rupture data due to their flexibility. These algorithms eliminate the need to presuppose a specific function, thus empowering the method to handle complex datasets. Machine learning algorithms have found extensive applications in resolving a multitude of engineering challenges involving complex interactions, including creep [12–22]. For instance, Hakimian et al. [23] employed four machine learning classifiers (random forest (RF), decision tree (DT), support vector machine (SVM) and bagging classifier) to predict the corrosion behavior of stainless steels, where they found that DT and bagging classifiers exhibited superior accuracy. Zhao et al. [24] leveraged machine learning algorithms across four categories (linear regression, support vector regression, regression tree, and Gaussian process regression) to search for better properties of Cu alloys using unsatisfactory results from trial-and-error tests. In the realm of creep behavior prediction, machine learning algorithms have been extensively used for predicting creep rupture life of austenitic stainless steels [13,17,25,26], 9 % Cr steels [14], and Ni-base superalloys [16]. Notably, Shin et al. [13] employed synthetic input features, encompassing precipitates (including NbC and M23C6) computed using ThermoCalc and the interaction of alloying elements with phases and temperatures, to predict the creep properties of austenitic stainless steels, utilizing five machine learning algorithms (RF, linear regression, nearest neighbor, kernel ridge, and Bayesian ridge). It is important to bear in mind that while machine learning algorithms are primarily designed for interpolation within datasets; they are often used for extrapolation as well, leading to a longstanding debate about their extrapolation capabilities. Many researchers argue that the NN cannot be used for extrapolation, but only interpolation [27–29]. Conversely, some researchers have attempted to use NN as extrapolators [30–33]. Applying common machine learning algorithms can manage interpolation errors in data, yet they may result in considerable extrapolation errors. This has recently been demonstrated for creep rupture data, where the use of common machine learning algorithms leads to predictions that deviate from physical reality [19,20]. However, by integrating constrained requirements on common machine learning algorithms, reasonable extrapolation results have been obtained [19–21]. Meanwhile, the concept of Physics-Constrained NN (PCNN) has emerged, offering improved generalization and extrapolation capabilities by combining the common NN with underlying physical principles [34–37]. By integrating constraints on the derivatives of the creep rupture curves, it can be assured that the predicted creep rupture curves show a physically correct behavior [19–22]. This assertion has been validated by applying post-assessment tests (PATS) recommended by European Creep Collaborative Committee (ECCC). The inclusion of these constraints helps prevent unphysical fitting and extrapolation. New algorithms have been developed for the constrained NN and TTP [19–22] by encoding the constraints into the common NN or TTP frameworks. Five soft-constrained machine learning algorithms (SCMLAs) have been formulated and implemented for the austenitic stainless steel Sanicro 25, where the constrained requirements on the first and second derivatives of the creep rupture curves are integrated into conventional machine learning algorithms [20]. In addition to the constrained derivatives, systematic methods for evaluating the stability, accuracy, and consistency of the results have been introduced. This approach goes beyond the sole reliance on the regression coefficient and mean squared error of the common machine learning algorithms. Furthermore, the distribution of the prediction errors generated by the SCMLAs has been quantitatively analyzed and applied in the assessment of the remanent creep life of high-temperature alloys [21]. SCMLAs have been systematically employed for the analysis of an advanced commercial austenitic stainless steel, Sanicro 25 [20]. However, the dataset for Sanicro 25 is typically well-organized, which may not be representative of most austenitic stainless steels, especially the common grades like TP316H and TP321H with multiple casts. The primary source of the significant scattering observed in experimental data, especially the data reported by the National Institute of Materials Science (NIMS, Japan), is the cast-to-cast variation [9]. In light of these considerations, in this study, we will analyze all casts and single casts for the studied materials, and evaluate the temperature dependence of creep rupture life predictions, according to the post-assessment tests proposed by Maruyama et al. [8–10]. This study aims to extend the applications of SCMLAs to various austenitic stainless steels and martensitic stainless steels, encompassing prediction and extrapolation of creep rupture life. The effects of single casts and the temperature dependence of the predictions will be evaluated. Furthermore, the stability of SCMLAs will be assessed through the selective elimination of specific temperatures, including temperature within the experimental range and the highest temperature, an approach referred to as temperature culling and extrapolation. Accordingly, this study will introduce a new guideline for temperature culling and extrapolation. 2 Methods 2.1 Soft-constrained machine learning algorithms Settings of machine learning algorithms, including Neural Networks (NN), can be found in various references [16,25,30,31] and programming languages or software like MATLAB and Python. In this study, the aforementioned five soft-constrained machine learning algorithms (SCMLAs) will be employed. Detailed explanations of the principles of these algorithms are provided in Ref. [20]; thus, only essential information will be summarized here. Five common machine learning algorithms were adopted, including three variants of backpropagation NN: Bayesian Regularization NN (BRNN), Levenberg-Marquardt NN (LMNN), and Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno Quasi-Newton NN (BFGNN), along with two forms of machine regression (MR): Limited-memory BFGSNNMR (LBFGSNNMR) and Support Vector MR (SVMR). Within these common machine learning algorithms, the training process for LMNN and BFGNN automatically halts when generalization gives no further improvement, indicated by a decrease in mean squared error for validation samples. As for BRNN, training ceases according to adaptive weight minimization (regularization). Bayesian regularization expands the loss function in the training process to search for the optimum model for both the minimal error and the minimal weights [38]. SVMR cross-validates a support vector machine regression model using various kernel functions. LBFGSNNMR trains a neural network for regression, with an activation function in the hidden layer. According to physical principles, creep rupture life must decrease with increasing stress at a given temperature for creep rupture curves. This implies that the first derivative of the rupture curve must be negative, while the second derivative is also negative. An exception to this rule is the so-called sigmoidal behavior, which requires special analysis but is not considered here. The requirements on the first and second derivatives of the predicted creep rupture curves are given as follows [19–22]: (1) m = d log t R d log σ ≥ 1.5 ; d 2 log t R d log σ 2 ≤ 0 ; d log t R d log T ≤ 0 ; where t R is the rupture time, σ the creep stress, and T the absolute temperature. In this study and in the authors' prior work [20,21], the term ‘log’ pertains to the logarithm with a base of 10. m is the inverse of the slope of the creep rupture curve with a minus sign for convenient illustration. The minimum m value helps ensure that the creep rupture curves are not too steep for extrapolation at extended times. The inclusion of the second derivative serves to eliminate oscillations or unphysical extrapolation of the predicted curves. Additionally, the temperature-related derivative prevents the occurrence of crossovers or bending back of the predicted curves at varying temperatures. The significance of the constraints has been well documented in Refs. [20,21]. To generate reasonable creep rupture life prediction and extrapolation, the constrained derivatives in eq. (1) are integrated with the five common machine learning algorithms, thereby creating the soft-constrained machine learning algorithms (SCMLAs), i.e. SC BRNN, SC LMNN, SC BFGNN, SC LBFGSNNMR, and SC SVMR [20]. The parameter configurations during the training and optimization of SCMLAs are detailed in Table 1 . The input parameters are stress and temperature, and the output is the creep rupture life, all in logarithmic form with a base of 10. For creep rupture prediction, one hidden layer is employed, in accordance with the findings that one hidden layer is usually sufficient to model the creep behavior [19,20,39]. The architecture used for the NNs is 2-n-1, where n is the number of neurons in the hidden layer. Regarding the datasets, they are randomly divided in a ratio of 70:15:15 for training, validation, and testing for NNs. 2.2 Stability and extrapolation guidelines Fitting all data using SCMLAs can be readily carried out. However, ensuring stability and repeatability for extrapolation demands thorough analysis. The guidelines for stability analysis have been comprehensively documented in Ref. [20], where the main principles are as follows: (1). Reanalyze the data with 50% of the longest creep rupture time data removed (PAT 3.1). (2). Reanalyze the data with 10% of the lowest stress dataset at each temperature removed (PAT 3.2). (3). Extrapolate the creep rupture time to longer times using the network obtained from fitting short-time data. Compare the extrapolation results at longer times to the available experimental data. The predicted results from the above analysis should exhibit only marginal differences compared to the original analysis (unculled ones) [40]. It has been shown that the ECCC PATs can be satisfied automatically with constrained TTP and machine learning algorithms in many cases [19,20,22,41]. Moreover, extrapolations from short to long times have exhibited good agreement with the unculled results [19,20]. Furthermore, alongside the stability analysis proposed in Ref. [20], new guidelines for temperature culling and extrapolation have been introduced in this work, aiming to enhance the reliability of the model for creep rupture life extrapolation. This guideline is outlined as follows: A. Utilize SCMLAs to fit experimental data through culling of specific temperatures. Temperature culling involves eliminating temperatures within the experimental range, while temperature extrapolation involves removing the highest temperatures within the experimental range. This process generates a network. B. Employ the network created in step A, which is now held constant (frozen), to predict creep rupture life at the target temperature. Document and preserve these predicted results for further analysis. C. Subsequently, conduct a thorough comparison between all available experimental creep rupture data and the predicted results generated in step B. 2.3 Solution requirements In contrast to relying solely on the regression coefficient, mean squared error or cross-validation loss, stringent and systematic criteria have been imposed on the final solutions of the predicted results [20], as outlined below. (1). Apart from the constraints in eq. (1), the solutions should satisfy the requirements of stability analysis, including PAT 3.1 long time culled, PAT 3.2 low stress culled, extrapolation from short to long times, and prediction at specific temperatures. The errors between the unculled data and the culled data should remain under 10% [20,22]. (2). To assess the reliability of the extrapolation procedure, an extrapolation is performed based on culled data of t max/3 to t max, where t max is the maximum experimental rupture time. The predicted rupture stresses close to t max should not deviate significantly from the experimental data points. (3). The consistency of the methods is assessed with the relative deviation (RD) of the solutions, average relative standard deviation (ARSD), and self-consistency index for each algorithm. The RD, ARSD, and self-consistency index are defined below. (2) RD i j = σ i j − σ j ‾ σ j ‾ (3) SD j = ∑ i = 1 n σ i j − σ j ‾ 2 n − 1 ; RSD j = S D j σ j ‾ × 100 % ; ARSD = ∑ j = 1 n j R S D j n j ; where i is the ith solution, e.g., i = 1-n, where n is the number of solutions. j is the jth temperature. n j is the number of temperatures. σ i j is the predicted stress at a given temperature j for each solution i. σ j ‾ is the average predicted stress at a specific temperature j averaged over the solutions i. SD j is the standard deviation at the temperature j averaged over the solutions, RSD j is the relative standard deviation at temperature j. ARSD is the relative standard deviation also averaged over the temperatures. The self-consistency index for each algorithm can be taken as 1-ARSD. It should be stated that the ARSD and self-consistency index introduced here primarily serve as tools for evaluating the consistency of the machine learning algorithms, given that distinct solutions may arise during the training process. The prediction errors, calculated as log(predicted rupture time/experimental rupture time), along with their distribution have been comprehensively addressed in a previous paper [21] and will not be reiterated here. A schematic representation of the evaluation process for SCMLAs is depicted in Fig. 1 . 2.4 Experimental information Experimental creep rupture data of austenitic and martensitic stainless steels were used in this work to validate the proposed models. The experimental information is listed below. (1). Austenitic stainless steels 316H, including tubes and plates with 10 different casts [42,43]; and austenitic 18Cr10Ni3CuNbN stainless steel Super304H with four different casts [44,45]. (2). Advanced tempered martensitic high Cr ferritic stainless steels 9Cr1MoVNb, TP91 (including tubes, plates, and pipes), with 11 casts [46], and 9Cr0.5Mo1.8WVNbB, TP92 (where T indicates tubes and P pipes), with 4 different casts [47]. 3 Results 3.1 Fitting and extrapolation Creep rupture life prediction for austenitic stainless steels, high Cr steels, and Ni-based alloys has been successfully performed through the utilization of the five soft-constrained machine learning algorithms (SCMLAs), resulting in satisfactory outcomes. An illustrative example is demonstrated for the austenitic stainless steel TP316H using SC LBFGSNNMR, as shown in Fig. 2 . Considering the substantial scatter within the experimental data of TP316H [42,43], the data that results in pronounced scatter at low stress levels at each temperature were excluded from the training process and reserved as validation data for the models. The training and optimization parameters can be found in Table 1. The prediction curves are compared to all the experimental data (including the large scatters), where a reasonable fit can be obtained, as depicted in Fig. 2a). Fig. 2b) illustrates extrapolation from t max/3 to t max, where t max is the longest experimental creep rupture time. This extrapolation analysis hinged on generating a model using experimental creep rupture data below t max/3, which was then employed to extrapolate outcomes at extended times. These extrapolated results were subsequently compared to experiments at longer times. Notably, compared with Fig. 2a) of fitting all experiments, the extrapolated results in Fig. 2b) exhibit a reasonable prediction with an extrapolation factor of over 3 in time. During extrapolation from short to long times, the experimental data at longer times (creep rupture time larger than t max/3) were unseen to the training and fitting process of SCMLAs. The first and second derivatives of the prediction curves that satisfy the criteria in eq. (1) with creep rupture time up to 300,000 h are shown in Fig. 2c) and d). It is essential that the first and second derivatives should satisfy the requirements of eq. (1) not only for creep rupture data beneath t max/3, but also at extended times up to 300,000 h. Fig. 2e) effectively demonstrates the absence of bending back or cross-overs for the predicted results over an extended time of 1,000,000 h, with temperatures ranging from 575 to 775 °C with 25 °C intervals, according to PAT 1.2 of ECCC [40,48]. PAT 2.1, which pertains to the biases of the predicted results, has been well documented in Ref. [21] and is not repeated here. The stability analysis of TP316H using SC LBFGSNNMR is depicted in Fig. 2f), encompassing PAT 3.1 long time culled, PAT 3.2 low stress culled, and extrapolation from short to long times. The errors between culled and unculled ones are reasonable and smaller than 10% recommended by ECCC [40]. To ascertain the final predicted values of the studied materials, a comparative evaluation of the five SCMLAs is necessary. In Fig. 3 a), a comparison of four SCMLAs for the creep rupture prediction of TP316H is presented. At extended times, such as 300,000 h, the average values obtained from these four algorithms can serve as the final predicted stresses. Notably, SC SVMR has been omitted from Fig. 3a), due to its substantial deviations observed during extrapolation from t max/3 to t max, as indicated in Fig. 3b). Similarly, for Super304H, the average values derived from the three SCMLAs presented in Fig. 3c) can be regarded as the final predicted values for extended times, such as 3t max. SC BRNN and SC SVMR failed in extrapolating from t max/3 to t max for Super304H, as illustrated in Fig. 3d). Remarkably, it has been demonstrated that the average value of all five algorithms can be adopted as the final predicted values for Sanicro 25, considering their minimal significant differences [20]. The quantitative determination of the final creep rupture prediction is based on evaluating the capability of the five SCMLAs for extrapolation from short to long times. These results demonstrate that the methods are reliable for fitting and extrapolating creep rupture life. It is worth noting that all methods do not automatically generate satisfactory results. The applicability of each method must be verified, for example, with the help of the culling analysis in Fig. 2f) and Fig. 3b) and d). Fig. 4 presents a comparison of creep rupture fitting and extrapolation for high Cr steels TP91 and TP92. Extrapolation from t max/3 to t max was carried out following the guidelines outlined in sections 2.2 and 2.3. The results clearly demonstrate a strong agreement between extrapolation from t max/3 to t max and fitting of all data, as depicted in Fig. 4a) for TP92 steels. This consistency underscores the stability and reliability of the methods for extrapolation. For TP91, as shown in Fig. 4b), the relative deviations between fitting all data and extrapolation from t max/3 to t max, are generally within 10% at the maximum creep rupture time for each temperature, except for the case of 650 °C. The relative deviations, expressed as σ extrap/σ fit, involve comparing the predicted stresses at the maximum creep rupture time, where σ extrap and σ fit represent the predicted stresses obtained through extrapolation from t max/3 to t max and fitting all data, respectively. At 650 °C, the relative deviation is approximately 11%, and it tends to increase with increasing creep rupture time, which is due to the sharp decline of the experimental data at longer times, which the model cannot cover fully. 3.2 Temperature culling and extrapolation Incorporating the reanalysis of PAT 3 group and the extrapolation from short to long times, this study introduces the novel guideline for temperature culling and extrapolation, as elaborated in section 2.2. This facet gains prominence due to its significance in various engineering applications, particularly the extrapolation to higher temperatures. Fig. 5 illustrates one example for predicting creep properties through temperature culling at 575 °C and 625 °C for TP91 high Cr steels, encompassing tubes, plates, and pipes across 11 different casts. The SC LMNN method was employed to fit the experimental data excluding experimental data at 575 °C and 625 °C, and the obtained prediction curves were then compared to the experiments at those specific temperatures, where a good agreement can be obtained, as depicted in Fig. 5a). Furthermore, the predicted results based on fitting all data and those excluding experiments at 575 °C and 625 °C were compared in Fig. 5b). It can be readily seen that there are negligible differences between fitting all data and prediction through temperature culling, and both can agree well with the experiments. Notably, comparable results were obtained with the other methods, but they are not presented here. Fig. 6 provides an illustrative example of temperature extrapolation at 700 °C for an advanced tempered martensitic high Cr ferritic stainless steel TP92 using SC BRNN. First, a network was established employing SC BRNN by utilizing all the experimental creep rupture data, excluding those exceeding 1000 h at 700 °C, as shown in Fig. 6a), which is referred to as extrapolation with t R < 1000 h at 700 °C (t R represents creep rupture time). Subsequently, the predicted results from Fig. 6a) were compared to various datasets, including all experimental data and fitting of all data (unculled), as demonstrated in Fig. 6b). It is evident that there exist only minor differences between unculled ones and extrapolation with t R < 1000 h at 700 °C, suggesting that it is stable and reliable for temperature extrapolation using SCMLAs. To eliminate the restriction imposed by the threshold value of 1000 h at 700 °C, which is commonly available for many materials, an additional dataset is introduced in Fig. 6b) as indicated by the dashed line. This dashed line corresponds to the prediction curve obtained by culling all experimental data at 700 °C, referred to as extrapolation with 700 °C culled. The errors exhibited a slight increase compared to the culling of t R > 1000 h at 700 °C, especially at longer times; however, these errors (σ extrap/σ fit, with σ extrap and σ fit denoting the predicted stresses obtained through extrapolation with 700 °C culled and fitting all data) remain within 10% compared to the unculled ones, affirming the reliability of temperature extrapolation at the highest temperatures. Regarding the extrapolation with 700 °C culled, the omission of prediction curves at other temperatures is due to the near absence of discrepancies when compared to the unculled results. The first and second derivatives that satisfy the requirements of eq. (1), including at 700 °C, are not repeated here. Besides 700 °C, it is also possible to generate the prediction results at other temperatures, such as 650 or 725 °C for TP92 steels. Comparable results can be obtained using other methods for a number of materials; TP92 serves as an illustrative example within this context. 3.3 Effects of single casts The significant scattering observed in the experimental data in the preceding figures primarily results from variations between different casts. Thus, the effects of single casts will be further analyzed in this section. It is important to note that unless otherwise specified, the results discussed in this paper pertain to all casts. For specific analyses of single casts, they will be explicitly designated. Fig. 7 presents the results depicting the effects of single casts on the studied materials using SC LMNN. In Fig. 7a), a comparison is made between predictions based on all casts and those based on single cast MGC for TP91 steels. It is apparent that the single cast MGC can effectively represent the mean predictions of all casts, with only minor deviations between them. Nevertheless, it is evident that at lower stress levels and longer time regions, particularly at 600–650 °C, the predictions exhibit more pronounced deviations. This divergence may be attributed to substantial alterations in the failure mechanisms; however, the model does not fully account for these changes. Moving to Fig. 7b), predictions based on all casts are compared with those based on single casts of MJP and MJU for TP92 steels. For MJP, the predictions closely align with experiments, and show only slight deviations from the predictions of all casts. However, in the case of MJU, the predictions agree well with experiments but exhibit substantial deviations from the predictions of all casts and MJP. The deviations may be attributed to the quality of the MJU data. The creep rupture times of MJU fall within the range of 527–20992 h, which is significantly lower than for other casts (with a maximum of 118,649 h). Additionally, the shorter time range of 10–500 h is absent in MJU compared to other casts. These observations raise concerns about the suitability of the MJU data for extrapolation using SCMLAs. Alternatively, the extrapolation results of MJU demonstrate a similar trend to those generated by Maruyama et al. [10], who employed the multiregion analysis and observed a transition within the median-term range. Furthermore, they suggested that the notable deviations from MJP can be attributed to differences in prior austenite grain size. Fig. 7c) exhibits an analysis focused on single casts of AAF and AAL for TP316H. It is evident that AAL and AAF represent the upper and lower bands of the creep rupture data, respectively. The predictions agree with experiments but deviate significantly from the mean predictions based on all casts. This indicates that these single casts exhibit significantly different behavior compared to other casts. The results demonstrate that analysis of single casts should be carried out, particularly those that exhibit significant deviations. However, it is worth noting that the quality of AAF data may not be suitable for extrapolation using SCMLAs, despite reasonable agreement being obtained. On the other hand, to study the general behavior of TP316H, five casts with minimal deviations between them, namely AAA, AAB, AAC, AAM, and AAN (referred to as ABCMN in this paper), were analyzed and presented in Fig. 7d). A comparison of fitting all data and extrapolation from t max/3 to t max, for casts ABCMN, reveals strong agreement, suggesting that it is feasible to fit and extrapolate the creep rupture life of TP316H by combining data from several casts. In conclusion, SCMLAs can be successfully applied for analysis of single casts, such as MGC of TP91, MJP of TP92, five similar casts of TP316H, the single cast of Sanicro 25 [20], and four similar casts of Super304H. However, it is not advisable to use the methods for single casts with lower quality data. Fig. 8 illustrates the temperature dependence of creep rupture predictions, i.e., log(t R) vs. 1/T K. The comparison involves regression fits, SCMLAs predictions, and experimental data for single casts. In Fig. 8a), the results for a single cast MGC of TP91 steels are examined. The regression lines tend to overestimate the creep rupture life at 80 MPa, while the SC LMNN predictions gives a better representation at stress levels of 100 MPa and 140 MPa. The regression lines depicted in the figures were obtained through ordinary least squares regression, employing the experimental data for log(t R) and 1/T K. As suggested by Maruyama et al. [10], the regression fits or common TTPs often overestimate the creep rupture life at longer times due to the expected transition in deformation and rupture mechanisms, which is related to the changes in the activation energy. Multiregion analysis for TP91 shows evident transitions [8,9], whereas the SCMLAs in this study consistently show minor smooth transitions, indicating that the model accounts for the changes in rupture mechanisms to a limited extent. Similar minor transitions are observed for a single cast AAL of TP316H, as depicted in Fig. 8b). In the case of AAL, the regression fits represent the experimental data, suggesting no significant changes in activation energy under the presented experimental conditions. It is evident from Fig. 8 that the changes in activation energy with temperature are larger for TP91 than for TP316H. 3.4 Fitting and self-consistency error estimates Fig. 9 presents a comprehensive overview of error estimates for SCMLAs applied to various materials. In addition to the regression coefficient and error histogram which are basic requirements of common machine learning algorithms, the relative deviation in solutions and self-consistency of algorithms have been employed, as outlined in section 2.3. Fig. 9a) and b) display the regression coefficient and error histogram of fitting analysis for TP92 using SC BRNN and TP91 using SC LMNN, respectively. The regression coefficient stands at approximately 98% for all fitting computations and around 96% for all extrapolation analyses, including the unphysical results derived from common machine learning algorithms, indicating that the high regression coefficient alone cannot serve as a reliable indicator for reasonable fitting analysis. Additionally, the error histogram demonstrates a normal distribution with reasonably small errors; similar outcomes were observed across various algorithms and materials. Turning to Fig. 9c) and d), these figures illustrate the relative deviation histogram (RDH) of fitting solutions for Super304H using SC SVMR and extrapolation at 700 °C for TP92 using SC BRNN, respectively. The relative deviations obtained according to eq. (2) are reasonably small (within ±1%) and exhibit an approximately normal distribution, indicating that the methods can generate consistent results for creep rupture prediction. Comparable patterns were noted for other cases, although they are not depicted in the figure. The fitting accuracy and self-consistency index of the algorithms, expressed as 1-ARSD, where ARSD is the average relative standard deviation of the predicted results at different temperatures, c.f. eq. (3), is depicted in Fig. 9e) and f) for TP316H and Super304H, respectively. The self-consistency index of SCMLAs across various stability analyses (including fitting of all data, PAT 3.1, PAT 3.2, and extrapolation from short to long times) exceeds 97.5% for TP316H at 300,000 h and for Super304H at 3t max, indicating that the methods can generate consistent results across different analyses. Comparable findings were observed for other materials. These results clearly demonstrate the effectiveness of the methods, yielding reliable and consistent outcomes. All the presented methods exhibit low fitting errors. The methods are also self-consistent, i.e., they are stable against culling of some of the data. This does not mean that the methods automatically generate accurate extrapolation results, as demonstrated in section 3.1. Specifically, SC SVMR for TP316H, as well as SC BRNN and SC SVMR for Super304H deviated from the experimental data close to t max in the test of extrapolation from t max/3 to t max and had to be excluded from the extrapolation. This demonstrates that careful analysis must always be made for the extrapolation results to ensure that they are consistent with the experimental data. 4 Discussion 4.1 Influential factors It has been exemplified by Sanicro 25 [20] that arbitrary and unphysical results can be generated using the common machine learning algorithms without the constraints in eq. (1). This observation extends to the present study with TP316H and Super304H, depicted in Fig. 10 , where evident occurrences of bending backs, crossovers, and flexing of prediction curves emerge. Similar patterns are observed across other cases, though not explicitly shown. As stated in section 3.4, comparably high regression coefficients (98%) can be obtained for constrained and unconstrained methods. However, it has come to light that focusing solely on low errors and high regression coefficients cannot ensure the physical validity of fitting and extrapolation results across all studied materials, including Sanicro 25 [20]. Notably, while BRNN has been suggested to have a better capability of avoiding overfitting and enhancing generalization performance [16,34,36,38,49], it is evident in the context of creep, that it can generate unphysical results without the constraints. The testing and comparisons reveal that variations in hidden neurons, loss functions, and evaluation numbers do not significantly affect the final predictions. This aligns with the findings for Sanicro 25 [20]. The dominant factor lies in the soft-constrained derivatives, which play a crucial role in ensuring rational outcomes. Consequently, common machine learning algorithms without constraints are inadequate for accurately fitting and extrapolating creep rupture properties. In the context of temperature extrapolation, a threshold of 1000 h at 700 °C has been selected, a value readily available across various materials. As demonstrated in Fig. 6b), employing creep rupture times below 1000 h at 700 °C has facilitated improved accuracy compared to culling all experiments at this temperature. This finding implies that reliable temperature extrapolation by soft-constrained machine learning algorithms (SCMLAs) using short-term data (e.g., 1000 h) can be obtained. TP316H was selected for this study due to its data distribution being representative of many austenitic stainless steels, such as TP347H and TP321H. For most creep rupture curves, the constraints in eq. (1) can be used. To date, SCMLAs have been successfully applied to various materials, including austenitic stainless steels like Sanicro 25 [20], TP316H, TP321H, NCF800H (32Cr21NiMnSi), Super304H, advanced martensitic high Cr ferritic stainless steels such as TP91, TP92, SUH616B (12Cr1Mo1W0.3V), and Ni-based superalloys like Ni–13Cr4.5MoTi6Al, where similar outcomes were obtained. 4.2 Methods comparison A hard-constrained neural network (NN) has been proposed by He and Sandström [19], where new algorithms have been developed from scratch by encoding the constraints in eq. (1) into the NN frameworks. The physics-constrained NN (PCNN) and hard-constrained NN usually require complex encoding of the physical constraints into the new algorithms. Allthese methods provide alternative approaches for analyzing the properties of materials. Moreover, a constrained TTP (Time-Temperature Parameter) method has been proposed for creep rupture analysis of austenitic stainless steels [22]. Compared with the hard-constrained NN and the constrained TTP methods, SCMLAs exhibit analogous behavior in terms of fitting and extrapolation. In this study, SCMLAs have been extended to various austenitic and martensitic stainless steels, where the obtained results can be applied to high-temperature alloys. The SCMLAs also present an alternative approach for creep rupture assessment. It has been demonstrated that SCMLAs could be applied to predict the remaining creep life of high-temperature steels and alloys. Such an approach has been proposed by He and Sandström [21], involving the fitting of prediction error distributions using log-logistic distribution functions, where the probability of premature creep failure can be evaluated quantitatively using the position of outliers. There are creep rupture curves where the second derivative is not consistently negative. The first derivative is always negative. In particular, this is the case for so-called sigmoidal curves, which can be due to extensive precipitation reactions. However, such situations are difficult to handle with statistical methods such as NN or TTPs anyway because the temperature and time dependence of the precipitation reaction must be identical to that of the rupture process, which is rarely the case. Cases with complex metallurgical reactions should instead be treated with fundamental models. Such models have successfully been developed by the authors [1–6]. Thus, the assumption about negative derivatives implies little restriction to statistical methods. In the fundamental models, the evolution of microstructures and defects, such as dislocation hardening, precipitation hardening, solid solution hardening, stacking faults contribution, and creep cavitation along grain boundaries, are considered. The employment of fundamental models offers valuable insights into the mechanisms governing creep rupture, granting a more reliable prediction for longer times. However, their intricate nature has restrained their widespread adoption, impeding their broader usage. In the end, it is crucial to recognize the limitations of the SCMLAs and other statistical methods like TTPs. These methods are inherently data-driven; it is worth noting that extrapolating by a factor exceeding 3 in time following the ECCC suggestions is not recommended. The methods have been applied to single casts of materials; however, it is not recommended to utilize the methods for single casts with low-quality data. Data quality hinges on the distribution and size of the dataset, without strict criteria. High-quality data is characterized by well-distributed experimental data within fine time and stress intervals, as exemplified by MJP of TP92 in this study. Conversely, low-quality data emerges from a small dataset size or gaps in data distribution within fine stress or time intervals, resulting in substantial prediction uncertainties, such as MJU of TP92 in this study. For further illustration, in case of low-quality data, extrapolating from 30,000 h to 100,000 h becomes problematic when experimental data in the range of 10,000–30000 h is absent, leading to an extrapolation ratio of 10 instead of 3, rendering extrapolation unfeasible. 5 Conclusions • New guidelines for temperature culling, involving the removal of specific temperatures within the input experimental range, and temperature extrapolation beyond the input experimental range have been introduced in this study. The implementation of these guidelines yields significant agreement between experimental and predicted results, facilitating effective temperature culling and extrapolation. • Soft-constrained machine learning algorithms (SCMLAs) have been successfully applied to various austenitic and martensitic stainless steels. The methods are associated with low fitting errors, and they are self-consistent, i.e., they are stable after culling some of the long-term data. To obtain accurate extrapolation results, the predicted rupture values should also be verified against the test of extrapolation from t max/3 to t max. • Comprehensive evaluations have been conducted for SCMLAs, covering constrained derivatives, fitting of all data, extrapolation from short to long times, temperature extrapolation, temperature culling, culling of long-time and low-stress data, as well as error estimate using relative deviation and self-consistency. The methods that fulfil all the requirements can predict creep rupture with consistent accuracy when extrapolated to 300,000 h or three times the longest experimental creep rupture time for all investigated materials. • SCMLAs can be effectively applied to single casts of materials with high-quality data, but it is discouraged to employ the models for single casts with lower quality data. • The temperature-dependent creep rupture life predictions reveal that SCMLAs partially account for the transitions in fracture mechanisms. • These findings suggest that SCMLAs offer an alternative avenue for assessing creep rupture life.
