Ecological carrying capacity is key to evaluating sustainable development capacity, and land use change has varying degrees of impact on ecosystems. This study explores the ecological carrying capacity based on land use change, which is important for the conservation and scientific and rational use of ecosystems. Therefore, in this study, three machine learning classification 3algorithms, namely support vector machine, random forest and artificial neural network, were selected for accuracy comparison and analysis based on multi-source data, using Southwest Guangxi Karst-Beibu Gulf as the study area. The Patch-generating Land Use Simulation Model is used to dissect the spatial and temporal changes in ecological carrying capaciyt from 1990 to 2040 and future trends. The results showed that (1) Coupling multiple sources of data and machine learning classification algorithms can ultimately improve land use classification accuracy. The RF is compared and found to be the optimal classification algorithm for this study. (2) The area of arable and grassland gradually decreases between 1990 and 2040, mainly encroached upon by build land; the area of forested land gradually recovers, the watershed fluctuates up and down, and the area of build land gradually increases. (3) The ecological carrying capacity from 1990 to 2040 shows a trend of decreasing and then increasing, and the area of low and medium–low decreases from 2020 to 2040, with arable land and forest land having a stronger potential to increase ecological carrying capacity. Nanning City, Qinzhou City and Chongzuo City are severely damaged. The framework provides an effective tool for exploring future ecological carrying capacity to support the ecological conservation and future sustainable development of the region. Keywords Ecological carrying capacity Land use Machine learning Random forest PLUS model Guangxi Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction Ecological carrying capacity (ECC) is the key to evaluating sustainable development capacity and is an important analytical tool for global environmental change, which has an important role in the development of human and eco-social systems (Arrow et al., 1995; Guo et al., 2017; Qiu et al., 2021). Land is the carrier of terrestrial ecosystems and the basis for human survival and development, and land use change is closely linked to human activities and the structure of terrestrial ecosystems. (McBain et al., 2017). Since China's reform and opening up, economic development has neglected ecological protection, and the development of many regions has exceeded the ECC of the region, making the development model unsustainable (Qiu et al., 2021). Therefore, it is necessary to explore the ECC based on land use change, which is important for improving ecosystems and sustainable development. In the early 20th century, some scholars had already started land-related research, focusing on land registration, land classification and mapping (Chen., 1996; Anderson et al., 1976). During the 1950s and 1980s, space technology continued to develop and land use classification based on remote sensing data gradually began to become mainstream. Beginning in the 1990s, research on land use in China began to move from its beginnings to a flourishing development. Currently, high precision long time series intelligent extraction and future prediction of land information is already a global hotspot and frontier (Zhang et al., 2023; Benjamin et al., 2013; Kline, 2004; Wang et al., 2022). With the rapid development of remote sensing technology, land use classification methods are gradually changing from the traditional visual interpretation to remote sensing intelligent classification algorithms (Shukla et al., 2018). Among the intelligent classification algorithms for land use, the widely used and representative algorithms are Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), Artificial Neutral Network (ANN). The RF is an ensemble algorithm composed of different decision trees that can handle high-dimensional data, fast training, and simple implementation. However, classification noise can appear to be overfitting, which will affect classification accuracy (Zhang et al., 2016). The SVM model solves the problem of data classification by solving the optimization problem and finds the optimal classification hyperplane in the high-dimensional feature space. Its small sample training supports high-dimensional feature space. However, for large-scale training samples and multicategory classification problems, corresponding improvements need to be made (Li et al., 2009). The ANN simulate biological neural structures for classifying and storing data. They are simple to operate, do not require complex mathematical models and have a high learning capacity, but are not subject to human control, have slow learning times and take a long time to train (Gu et al., 2019). Nowadays, single data sources and classification methods in complex ecosystems are not sufficient to meet research needs. How to efficiently use multiple sources of data to quickly extract land surface information and realise high precision comparative analysis of machine learning algorithms is still in the development stage. Therefore, we realize the extraction and accuracy comparison of multiple machine learning algorithms for land use, with a view to providing technical support for the screening and formulation of optimal algorithms for intelligent land use information extraction. Land use includes both quantitative and spatial aspects in its projections. Currently, the more commonly used models are Markov, Grey Model (GM(1,1)) and Logistic models (Zhang et al., 2021). The Cellular Automaton (CA) has a unique advantage in geotemporal simulation, with powerful spatio-temporal coupling characteristics and spatial computing power, which can realize the simulation of complex systems by analyzing the way of spatio-temporal location transformation. Therefore, there are many models combined with CA models for comprehensive use, such as CA-Markov, CA-ANN and CA-logistic are more widely used. Today, there are new land use models such as the Future Land Use Simulation (FLUS) model and the Patch-generating Land Use Simulation (PLUS) model (Qiu et al., 2021). The FLUS model is derived from CA and improves on the traditional basis by combining ANN algorithms to extract conversion probabilities for various land types. It is an adaptive competition mechanism through roulette wheel selection that increases the accuracy of the simulation significantly, but the method is quantitatively under-predictive, requires coupling to other models, and lacks conceptual and mechanistic mining of land use drivers (Liu et al., 2017). The PLUS model is constructed by RF and CA. It addresses the shortcomings of traditional CA models in two areas, namely transformation rule mining and patch dynamic change simulation. The model proposes a site sprawl analysis strategy, and a CA model with multiple types of random patch seeding mechanisms with better interpretation (Liang et al, 2021). The ECC was introduced by Park in 1921. It is defined as the maximum size at which a certain organism can survive in a certain environment and reflects the ecological supply capacity (Park, 1921). In terms of research content, it includes the ECC of tourism, the ECC of agriculture, forestry and fisheries (Hu et al., 2020; Wu, 2019). In the environmental assessment method, it include the ecological footprint method, the three-dimensional ecological footprint model, and the life cycle assessment method (Zhou, 2019; Yang et al., 2020). In terms of areas of study, it includes countries, urban agglomerations, watersheds and administrative regions across the globe. A large number of scholars have focused their research on the ECC on administrative units or watersheds (Li et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2020). Due to the effectiveness of statistical data updating and the variability, there is a deficiency in revealing the spatial pattern of the ECC, and relatively few studies have been conducted at the raster scale(Shan et al., 2012). The ecological footprint method is one of the most common methods used by experts and scholars to study the ECC. It is a mature method, highly operational. However, in the calculation of important parameters, it mostly refers to “global hectares” or “national hectares”. However, it is worth noting that there are problems such as large scale variability and poor targeting, and the final calculation results are inaccurate (Shan et al., 2012). Therefore, this study makes reference to the previous achievements and optimises two shortcomings of the current situation. Firstly, This study calculates the ECC index based on the land use raster scale, with a view to quantifying and spatially expressing the ECC of the region and realising the spatial pattern analysis of the regional the ECC. Secondly, this study has improved the ecological footprint model by using “provincial hectares” instead of the traditional “global/national hectares”. This study aims to improve the accuracy of the calculation of the ecological carrying capacity index and provide a scientific basis for analysing the ECC of the region. The Southwest Guangxi Karst-Beibu Gulf is an integrated transition zone spanning the mountain-river-sea-edge. It has the fragility of karst mountains, the complexity of multiple watersheds and the interaction of coastal zones. Its ecosystems are integrated, diverse and complex. The frequent occurrence of cloudy and rainy weather in the region makes it difficult to acquire and process high-quality remote sensing images, and poses many technical problems for long time series monitoring and prediction of the ecological environment. In the context of China's new era, the region is a new strategic pivot point for the open development of the southwest central and southern regions, a new land and sea corridor in the west and a newly promoted free trade zone, and the heart of the Beibu Gulf City Cluster, the Pan Delta City Circle and the China-ASEAN City Cluster. It is located at the south-western border being pushed to the forefront of China's opening up to the outside world and has been given a rare and historic opportunity. Therefore, how to scientifically carry out monitoring and assessment management of complex ecosystem data to provide data support and theoretical basis for the sustainable development of terrestrial ecosystems and provide scientific reference for regional ecosystem management. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Research content This study proposes a model framework that integrates machine learning, improves ecological footprint and PLUS model. The study investigates past and future spatial and temporal changes in land use and ECC. Details of the study are given below. (1) In this study, Landsat remote sensing images were used as the base data, combined with multiple sources of data such as topography and climate. Three machine learning classification algorithms, namely SVM, RF and ANN, were selected for accuracy comparison and analysis, and the classification algorithm with the highest accuracy was selected as the classification algorithm for this study. (2) This study examines the spatial and temporal changes and spatial shifts in land use over the past 30 years, and analyses the spatial and temporal trends in ECC, in conjunction with an improved ecological footprint methodology. (3) The PLUS model constructed based on coupled RF and CA predicts the ECC pattern in 2030 and 2040 and analyses the future change trend. The changes in ECC of each land use type from 1990 to 2040 were explored. 2.2 Study area The Southwest Guangxi Karst-Beibu Gulf (E104°28′∼109°56′, N20°26′∼25°07′), consisting of the Southwest Guizhou Karst Region and the Beibu Gulf Economic Zone, contains seven cities and 55 counties, it has a total area of 108,365.41 km2 (Fig. 1 ). The topography of the region gradually decreases from north-west to south-east as a whole, with a top-down slope along the foothills of the Yunnan-Guizhou Plateau to the coastline of Beibu Gulf. It has a subtropical monsoon climate with hot and rainy summers, mild and less rainy winters and abundant heat, with distinct dry and rainy seasons. Temperatures in the study area range from 2.8 to 40.4 °C, with precipitation ranging from 1745.6 to 3111.9 mm. The area is rich in rainfall and water resources, and sometimes extreme weather can occur. The northwestern part of the study area is a karst mountainous region with serious stone desertification, poor soil, prone to drought, not easy to cultivate, and serious soil erosion. The coastal area of the northern bay is densely populated by humans, with unreasonable development of coastal zone resources such as sea enclosures and scenic development, and aquaculture destroying marine resources. The region's forest, wetland and grassland resources are all declining from 1990 to 2020. By the end of 2020, the total population of the region reaches 26.43 million people and the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) reaches 1,212.783 billion yuan. 2.3 Data source and data pre-processing The remote sensing image data are Landsat series images from the United States Geological Survey (USGS) with a spatial resolution of 30 × 30 m and a temporal resolution of 16 d. This study perform radiometric correction, mosaic and crop fusion pre-processing of the image classification. Digital Elevation Model (DEM) data were obtained from the National Center for Basic Geographic Information (Qiu et al., 2021). The obtained data were extracted from the DEM using GIS spatial analysis for 30 × 30 m in the study area, and pre-processed by unified projection (Albers projection coordinate system, datum D Krasovsky 1940), cropping and reclassification. Through spatial analysis tools, slope and slope direction were calculated for the analysis of the driving mechanism and the restricted area setting for simulation prediction. The meteorological data in this study include mean annual precipitation and mean annual air temperature. This study spatially interpolated the acquired data using the inverse distance weighting method to produce a dataset of the spatial distribution of mean temperature and mean annual precipitation at a spatial resolution 30 × 30 m for each year. The underlying geographic information data includes highways, railways and settlements. This study modified the data by means of Google Earth data validation vectors (Dai et al., 2020). The data were mainly used to drive the mechanism detection and simulation prediction of the restricted area setting, and the highway distance, railway distance and settlement centre distance were calculated by the Euclidean distance method to obtain a spatial distribution layer with a spatial resolution 30 × 30 m. 2.4 Research methods 2.4.1 Training sample and test sample selection After analysing the general situation of the study area, this study used Google Earth and existing land use data products, with the Normalized Differential Vegetation Index (NDVI), Normalized Differential Water Index (NDWI), Normalized Differential Build Index (NDBI) and DEM as the most auxiliary data (Dai et al., 2020). According to the principle of uniform distribution of samples, manual visual interpretation was used to select cultivated land, forest, grassland, water and build land in order based on a priori knowledge and spectral features of the features. This study built a training sample set and a test sample set according to the ratio of 7:3. This study repeatedly experimented according to the algorithm results and adjusted the inconsistent results repeatedly until the classification results reached a high accuracy. The training samples and test samples for each land class are shown in Table 1 and Table 2 . 2.4.2 Random forest RF is an integrated learning algorithm that is more accurate than a single classifier. The principle is to randomly select training samples and feature parameters for decision tree classification, and the final result is obtained by integrated decision tree voting (Breiman, 2001). (1) y = Y max ∑ t ∈ F f x , t = y Where, F is the random forest expression F={f1, f2,…, fn }, I is the indicative function, which takes the value of 0 or 1. A value of 1 indicates that the function holds and the classification target with the highest number of votes is the final type. 2.4.3 ECC calculation - improved ecological footprint model Ecological footprint models are widely used in ECC research, and have the advantages of intuition, simple operation and high feasibility. At present, the calculation of ecological footprint in China is unified in national and global hectares (Shan et al., 2012), and there is no unified calculation method based on “provincial hectares”, which will affect the reliability and relevance of the results. This study therefore uses the 'provincial hectare' as the unit of accounting. The statistical yearbook data was used to recalculate the provincial equilibrium and yield factors, which are decisive for the ECC calculation (Gu et al., 2019). Finally, the results of the provincial parameters were entered into the ecological footprint formula to calculate the ecological carrying capacity index, the formula is as follows: (2) Q = ∑ i = 1 n A i × p i × r i Where Ai is the productive land area of category i, pi equilibrium factor, and ri is the yield factor. 2.4.3.1 Equilibrium factor The equilibrium factor, which characterizes the differences in the productive capacity of different land classes, can convert the per capita occupancy of different productive land classes into equilibrium area by the following formula. (3) p i = p i ¯ p ¯ = E i F i / ∑ E i ∑ F i Where pi is the equilibrium factor of productive land of class i, p i ¯ is the average productivity of land i, p ¯ is the productivity of all land, Ei is the total production of land of class i, and Fi is the productive area of land of class i. 2.4.3.2 Yield factor The yield factor is an expression of the difference in productive capacity between the same land class geographically, and due to the different natural and human factors, which leads to the different productivity of each land class in each year, the conversion of the yield factor is needed, as follows. (4) r i = p i j ¯ p ¯ i = E i j F i j / E i F i where ri is the yield factor of productive land of category i, p i j ¯ is the average productivity of land i, p ¯ i is the productivity of all land, E i j is the total output of land of category i in region j, F i j is the area of land of category i in region j, Ei is the total yield of land of category i, and Fi is the productive area of land of category i. 2.4.4 ECC prediction - PLUS model In this study, the PLUS model is used to simulate and predict the spatial and temporal patterns of ECC in the study area. Compared with other related models, the PLUS model can obtain higher simulation accuracy and more reasonable spatio-temporal patterns. The PLUS model consists of two modules, a framework for transformational rule mining based on land sprawl analysis strategies and a CA model based on a multi-type stochastic patch seeding mechanism. (1) Based on the overlay of ECC change data, the part of change between two periods of data is extracted, and then randomly selected sampling points are selected and trained separately to explore the relationship between the spatial change of ECC and the driving factors using the RF algorithm. The algorithm is able to handle high-dimensional data as well as the multicollinearity between variables, and finally output the probability of ECC change. (2) The PLUS model uses a multi-type random patch seeding mechanism based on a descending threshold, which is implemented through a process of calculating the overall probability. (3) In this study, Kappa coefficients and FOM coefficients are used for classification accuracy validation. Based on the confusion matrix Kappa coefficients have a very significant advantage for consistency testing. 3 Analysis of results 3.1 A comparative study of machine learning algorithms for land use in 2020 based on multi-source data 3.1.1 Overall classification accuracy comparison analysis The overall classification accuracy of the three intelligent classification algorithms is shown in Table 3 , and the overall classification results and local results are shown in Fig. 2 . This study compared the results of the three machine learning algorithms using only Landsat data involved in classification (A) and those using multiple sources of data involved in classification (B) separately and found that the overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient were significantly higher using multiple sources of data involved in classification. The SVM has the least improvement in overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient. The study area is large in scale and the SVM algorithm has some spatial advantages for small sample training, which is more prominent for large-scale training samples and multi-category classification problems in this region. The ANN showed the greatest improvement in overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient. As the ANN is not under human control and the Training Rate parameter is set to improve the classification speed of the algorithm, but reduces the accuracy of the classification and has the problem of more fragmented patches. The study area has a staggered distribution of land cover types, for which the heterogeneity of the image elements is large. The RF classification algorithm is prone to overfitting situations, which in turn affects its classification accuracy. The final classification accuracy results show that the RF algorithm has the highest overall accuracy (89.4%) and Kappa coefficient (0.88) for land use classification. Therefore, the RF algorithm coupled with multiple sources of data can obtain higher classification accuracy and at the same time have better classification efficiency. 3.2 Analysis of spatial and temporal land use patterns 1990–2020 The results show that the cultivated land is gradually decreasing in area from 1900 to 2020, mainly in Nanning and Yulin, with a relatively concentrated distribution in recent years. The area of forest land is on the rise, mainly in the northern part of Baise and Chongzuo. The forest has been the most widely distributed type of land use in the region and plays a vital role in the ecological environment of the region. The distribution of grassland in the area is relatively small and has been sporadic over the years. The water are the least regionally variable land type, with a relatively stable spatial distribution, especially for river and lake types, with no significant changes. There is a clear tendency for build land to expand, with Nanning, Yulin and Beihai expanding the most. When simulated the spatial distribution of GDP based on nighttime lighting, it was also the three cities mentioned above that had a higher rank, indicating a direct relationship between urban construction and the economy. However, it is important to consider the reasonableness and appropriateness of the expansion of Build land, which once again confirms the need to study the ECC and to always adhere to the concept of “green water and green mountains are the silver mountain of gold” (Fig. 3 ). To further grasp the study land use area, calculations were made to obtain Fig. 4 . The results found that overall, the largest area of forest land was found, accounting for about 65% of the study area, followed by arable land, accounting for about 25% of the study area, with the remaining 10% being grassland, water and build land, respectively, and the smallest area of water, accounting for about 2% of the study area. From 1990 to 2020 the area of cultivated land and grassland is on a downward trend, and the area of forest and build land is on an upward trend, with the expansion of build land encroaching on cultivated land and grassland. The area of water variation remains within 50 km2, which is somewhat related to the precipitation of the year. Although the area of forest and build land has increased year by year, the city has developed and the ecological environment has been improved. However, the decline in cultivated land and grassland should not be overlooked. If natural resources are used in an unreasonable manner and food security may not be guaranteed, then ecological risks will increase and there will be a risk of a decline in the ECC. The spatial transfer of land use from 1990 to 2020 is shown in Fig. 5 . The results show that there is less transfer out of build land, basically from forest and cultivated land to build land, mainly in Yulin and Nanning. These two cities are key construction areas in Guangxi and key areas in the national development strategy. The forest transfer is highly variable, and the forest transfer out of the terrain is mostly flat and hilly, closer to water sources, but also in the vicinity of cultivated land. The next step of ecological restoration and land improvement should focus on the forest, otherwise both forest restoration and biodiversity conservation will be at increased risk. The spatial transfer of water is relatively smooth. Many waters are surrounded by cultivated and build land. The cultivated land has been a priority for the government and relevant parts of the planning, and the cultivated land has been centrally regulated as productive land. These areas have flat terrain, complete water facilities and convenient transportation. The grassland is always scattered and randomly distributed, with a clear shifting distribution in the north and south-west of Baise. 3.3 Analysis of spatial and temporal changes in the ECC The ECC is calculated by improving the ecological footprint model, and the GIS spatial analysis is used to classify the ECC per unit area into 5 levels using the geometric breakpoint method, which are low (0–1.462), middle-low (1.463–2.776), middle (2.777–4.392), middle-high (4.393–6.454), high (6.455–8.176) finally obtained the ECC level map for 1990–2020 as shown in Fig. 6 . The ECC per unit area for the four periods 1990–2020 ranges from 0.884 to 8.176, with an average value of 4.531, which is a middle-high class overall. The trend of the ECC rises and then continues to fall, with a downward trend in the karst mountains, mainly in Baise and Chongzuo. The main categories are middle and middle-low. The basin and its surrounding areas are dominated by low, with the upper reaches having a greater impact on a number of rivers downstream. The Beibu Gulf coastal zone region, as a whole, shows a small downward trend. 3.4 Spatial and temporal patterns of the ECC forecast for 2020–2040 3.4.1 PLUS model simulation accuracy validation The simulation results take the real the ECC of the study area in 2020 as a comparison, and use Kappa coefficient and FOM coefficient to verify the accuracy. The spatial distribution of the ECC in 2010 was chosen as the input data, and the simulation results were compared with the real data in 2020, resulting in a Kappa coefficient value of 0.836. The consistency of our simulation accuracy results is good and the results are credible. The result of calculating FOM coefficient is 0.325, due to the resolution setting of 30 × 30 m and the large scope of the study area, the simulation accuracy cannot reach very high, the overall accuracy is high and the error value is small, which indicates that the simulation accuracy has reached the ideal effect. (Fig. 7 ). 3.4.2 Analysis of spatial and temporal patterns of the ECC prediction The results found that overall, the ECC per unit area in 2030 and 2040 ranged from 1.299 to 8.832, with a mean value of 5.06. The ECC as a whole is middle to high, showing a transitional trend of increasing carrying capacity from the southwest karst region to the southeast coast, with the watershed as a link. In comparison, the trend in the ECC of the study area over the two years is upwards, with the ECC of the watershed remaining low and the ECC of the cropland and woodland increasing and becoming more widely distributed. (Fig. 8 ). This study counted the area of each class and found that there is an increasing trend towards better the ECC in the study area. The area of low and middle-low are slowly decreasing and some of the middle-low is being converted to high. The middle accounts for a relatively small proportion of the study area. The middle-high is more variable and also has the widest distribution of the ECC classes in the region, with an increasing trend from 2010 to 2040. The high shows a trend of first decreasing and then increasing, with small changes and a risk of degradation grade, and should be strengthened, with enhanced means of governance and improved governance systems. (Fig. 9 ). 3.5 Trends in the ECC of various land use types from 1990 to 2040 Different land use types have different ecosystem services and correspondingly different ECC, and it is necessary to explore the trends. The ECC of cultivated land is rising and then falling, and the arable area and yield factor are declining year by year. It is vital to pay attention to water and soil pollution to ensure food security. Forests are showing a continuous decline followed by an increase, and much of the degradation of forest land is caused by encroachment of cultivated land and build land, which should be brought to the attention of policy makers. Grasslands are in a downward trend and have been characterised in the study area as an unstable ecosystem with an irregular and fragmented distribution. The ECC of the waters is low, and the waters are mostly in the water interaction zone and sea-land interaction zone, with complex ecosystems and fragile ecological environments. 2010′s low ECC spatial distribution is also mainly distributed in the coastal zone areas, which, together with the frequent occurrence of natural disasters in the coastal zone, has contributed to the reduction of ECC. The upward trend in the ECC of build land is closely linked to the ecological projects that have been continuously proposed in recent years and to the accelerated urbanisation process (Fig. 10 ). 4 Discussion 4.1 Research content aspects At present, global ecological problems and climate change are currently intensifying, and global climate change must have a non-negligible impact on the ECC of the region. This study combines the characteristics of the study area with the fact that climate change varies greatly from ecosystem to ecosystem and plays an important role in woodland restoration, watershed change and crop growth. In the future we need to actively explore how the ECC is driven in this respect and assess whether this will affect local ecological security (Deeksha et al., 2022). The local ecological situation needs to be assessed and analysed with reference to the international situation, for example in relation to the SDGs. The main reason for such strong changes is the conversion of large amounts of forest to dryland, which has increased food security but has had a greater impact on the forest ecosystem. The region is mountainous and the destruction of forests is prone to natural disasters such as soil erosion and landslides. Of course it cannot be overlooked that according to the first SDGs report submitted in 2019, many of the SDGs will not be achieved by 2020 and 2030 if UN member states continue to follow the current development model and such conclusions as mentioned above also apply to this region (Kavvada et al., 2020). Comparing similar studies, it is found that the RF algorithm is the highest accuracy in the comparative analysis of land use machine learning algorithms based on multi-source data, which is similar to and different from the results of some scholars (Gu, 2018; Dai, 2020), mainly because of the different scales selected for the study area, and the smaller training samples of the study sample area have obvious advantage, for other algorithms in general. In the analysis of land use change, arable land showed a decreasing trend and forest land and construction land showed an increasing trend, and the study concluded that the trend of the results of the third national land resources survey coincided (Huang, 2021). In the analysis of ECC based on land use change, a large amount of arable land was converted to construction land, and the ECC of arable land showed an upward trend, and the ECC of basin was lower, etc. also obtained similar results as some scholars could (Zhao, 2020). The comparison found our research to be advantageous and we propose a modeling framework that integrates machine learning to improve the ecological footprint and PLUS. The results of the present study are more systematic than those of Zhao (2020), which used a single method. Li (2021) uses the administrative unit as the unit of study, and base the final results on a raster for the study unit to improve accuracy and also to provide more targeted decision support. This study has applied the PLUS model with the highest accuracy for ECC prediction (Gou et al., 2022; Lin et al., 2022), which enriches the research results in this area and can provide better technical support and data support. The reliability of the land use classification results is discussed in qualitative comparison with existing land use data products in order to make it more intuitively clear. This study uses the China Ecosystem-type Classification Dataset (CECD) data for comparison (Liu et al., 2014). As shown in Fig. 11 , this study also found that the spatial distribution of rivers was also found to be more consistent for both data types for all land use types. However, for fine water CECD extraction was generally effective. The river differences between the two are mainly due to the spatial resolution of the data and the method of production. The CECD data is produced by visual interpretation and often includes deltas and alluvial fans in the centre of the river for ease of mapping. Spatial consistency is best for forest and moderate for cultivated land. The consistency is better for build land, with CECD easily mapping bare land, vegetation and farmland inland of built-up areas as build land, and the results of this study are able to identify small areas of build land better. In summary, the classification results of this study are in good agreement with the CECD and the final classification results of this study are credible. 4.2 Data and methodological aspects This study uses a single dataset, different classification algorithms to analyse the difference in classification accuracy of land use types in the same study area. Differences in classification accuracy between different datasets and the same classification algorithm for the same study area were also used. This study succeeded in selecting the algorithm with the highest accuracy, showing that machine learning algorithms are very effective when applied to improve the accuracy of land use classification. The RF outperforms SVM and ANN in terms of classification efficiency, while high accuracy increases the amount of data, parameters and complexity of the classification, which all have an impact on classification efficiency. In the use of machine learning algorithms, long time-series intensive, high precision, high spatial and temporal resolution data analysis, in addition to being based on multi-source data and combining feature parameters, has become a trend and direction for research. In particular, multi-seasonal phase analysis should be carried out in water and vegetation extraction, which will continue to be considered for addition in future research. In the simulation forecasts carried out by applying the PLUS model, the drivers selected are not fully representative of the changes in ECC in the study area. The neighbourhood weights were assigned from the empirical calculations made by the previous ECC, and the conversion rule settings and simulation parameter settings are also subjective. The richness and detail of the constraint settings lead to the extent that they also affect the final simulation accuracy, which is bound to be somewhat biased. The PLUS model also suffers from limitations in the accuracy of the spatial allocation algorithm, and a comparison of simulation results with actual observations in 2020 found that the PLUS model is unable to predict new patches, the allocation model applies statically, and the drivers are all selected from historical data. If the environment in the ECC changes, there are potential changes that cannot be described. The future ECC simulations would benefit from adding dynamic environmental variables to the model reducing errors due to new patches. In the future, the inclusion of future urban ecological planning data and future climate data will continue to be explored to improve the accuracy of the simulations. 4.3 Limitations There are limitations to this study due to limited research time, data acquisition and personal competence. In the selection of algorithms for applying machine learning for land use classification, only three algorithms, namely SVM, RF and ANN, were compared and analysed. The algorithm selection is relatively traditional and insufficient in number. Deep learning algorithms such as ultra-random trees, rotating forests and convolutional neural networks are further considered in subsequent studies, and more in-depth comparative analysis of classification errors and their causes is conducted to further improve classification accuracy (Dai et al., 2020). The projections in this study are based on natural developments only and there is no discussion of multiple scenario simulation projections. Future developments are highly uncertain and should need to be explored in more ways. However, the discussion of however many scenarios is not a precise prediction of the future, but an attempt to explore possible future directions in an appropriate way to provide decision makers with response options. There is no clear indicator system for researchers at home and abroad to refer to, so there is still a certain degree of subjectivity after combining various forms of selection, and it does not fully represent the ECC of the study area, so it is difficult to use a more accurate and reasonable method to verify the scientific and systematic selection of factors. This study realises the extraction and accuracy comparison of multiple machine learning algorithms for the region, with a view to providing technical support for the screening and formulation of optimal algorithms for the extraction of intelligent land use information. This study reconstructs the pattern of ECC changes over the past 30 years and predicts the next 20 years, which is conducive to the selection of appropriate ecological development patterns and the promotion of sustainable development in the region. 5 Conclusions This study couples multi-source data to compare the overall accuracy of different algorithms and the accuracy of different land uses. It was found that coupling multi-source data and machine learning algorithms could ultimately improve the overall land use classification accuracy. The validation showed that the RF algorithm had the highest accuracy for each, with an OA of 89.4% and a kappa of 0.88. The corrected allocation prediction model was used to forecast the ECC for 2030 and 2040, and the validation results were better than the prediction results. The results show that: from 1990 to 2040, the area of cultivated land and grassland gradually decreases, the water fluctuates up and down, and the area of build land gradually increases. From 1990 to 2040 ECC as a whole belongs to the medium–high, showing a trend of first decreasing and then increasing with 2000 as the inflection point, and from 2020 to 2040 the low and medium. The future focuses on the continuing changes in forests and arable land in terrestrial ecosystems. Ecological conservation is particularly important in the densely populated city of Nanning. Ltd. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ OA-Window This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license. 2022-10-20T06:54:45.906Z http://vtw.elsevier.com/data/voc/AddOnTypes/50.7/aggregated-refined NSFC NSFC http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/SciValFunders/501100001809 http://sws.geonames.org/1814991 CAMS CAMS http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/SciValFunders/501100003345 http://sws.geonames.org/1814991 item S2096-5796(22)00098-5 S2096579622000985 1-s2.0-S2096579622000985 10.1016/j.vrih.2022.09.002 321628 2024-01-09T20:39:28.449623Z 2023-08-01 2023-08-31 1-s2.0-S2096579622000985-main.pdf https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S2096579622000985/MAIN/application/pdf/ac436fadb38906f712d61b3d22c0127f/main.pdf main.pdf pdf true 47934947 MAIN 24 1-s2.0-S2096579622000985-main_1.png https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S2096579622000985/PREVIEW/image/png/44dc03ae485de8405b36baad0637a968/main_1.png main_1.png png 56108 849 656 IMAGE-WEB-PDF 1 1-s2.0-S2096579622000985-am.pdf https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/egi:10WWF2HLWJG/MAIN/application/pdf/163d51f4e572747fd695f32588af3be1/am.pdf am am.pdf pdf false 1576283 AAM-PDF Virtual Reality & Intelligent Hardware â€¢ Review â€¢ August 2023 Vol. 5 No. 4: 293â€“316 10.1016/j.vrih.2022.09.002 Review of intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer based on machine learning Han JIANG*, Wenjia SUN, Hanfei GUO, Jiayuan ZENG, Xin XUE, Shuai LI State key Laboratoty of Virtual Reality Technogy and Systems, Beihang University, Beijing 100083, China Received 4 June 2022; Revised 31 August 2022; Accepted 29 September 2022 Abstract: Gland cancer is a high-incidence disease that endangers human health, and its early detection and treatment require efficient, accurate, and objective intelligent diagnosis methods. In recent years, the advent of machine learning techniques has yielded satisfactory results in intelligent gland cancer diagnosis based on clinical images, significantly improving the accuracy and efficiency of medical image interpretation while reducing the workload of doctors. The focus of this study is to review, classify, and analyze intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer based on machine learning and deep learning. This paper briefly introduces some basic imaging principles of multimodal medical images, such as the commonly used computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), ultrasound (US), positron emission tomography (PET), and pathology. In addition, the intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer were further classified into supervised learning and weakly supervised learning. Supervised learning consists of traditional machine learning methods, such as K- nearest neighbor algorithm (KNN), support vector machine (SVM), and multilayer perceptron, and deep learning methods evolving from convolutional neural network (CNN). By contrast, weakly supervised learning can be further categorized into active learning, semisupervised learning, and transfer learning. State-of-the-art methods are illustrated with implementation details, including image segmentation, feature extraction, and optimization of classifiers. Their performances are evaluated through indicators, such as accuracy, precision, and sensitivity. In conclusion, the challenges and development trends of intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer were addressed and discussed. Virtual Reality & Intelligent Hardware, 2023, 5(4): 293â€“316 1 Introduction Cancer is a malignant tumor, and the survival rate after cancer treatment is closely related to the period of cancer development. Relevant studies have shown that with the early detection of breast cancer and timely surgical treatment, the 5-year survival rate of patients can exceed 80%, whereas that of advanced breast cancer patients is approximately 50%[1]. Cancer diagnosis is currently being streamlined. Usually, computed tomo- 2096-5796/Â©Copyright 2023 Beijing Zhongke Journal Publishing Co. Ltd., Publishing services by Elsevier B.V. on behalf of KeAi Communication Co. Ltd. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). *Corresponding author, vrlab@buaa.edu.cn graphy (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), ultrasound (US), and other imaging examinations are performed first, from which the doctor provides a preliminary clinical diagnosis. The diagnosis process is mainly based on the doctors' subjective judgment; thus, the diagnosis results are subjective and largely limited by the doctorsâ€™ skills and experience. In particular, inexperienced doctors are prone to misdiagnosis, and even doctors with long-term practical experience have difficulty making completely consistent and accurate judgment when facing various complex diseases. Research shows that two doctors with more than 10 years of experience in abdominal imaging have only 67%â€“70% accuracy in identifying 130 pancreatic cysts on CT images[2] because most of the useful information in the image is hidden in tiny gray changes, which are difficult to recognize by humans[3]. Meanwhile, as cancer rates increase with doctors having to read more images, chronic overwork is more likely to cause misdiagnoses[4]. In recent years, diagnosis methods based on artificial intelligence have attracted increasing attention because they cannot only reduce the subjectivity of human operation but can also achieve an accuracy far exceeding the level of experienced doctors[5]. It also has significant advantages in terms of efficiency. Machine learning algorithms have been used to interpret X-ray images since the mid-1960s. By the mid-1980s, computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) algorithms were first used for cancer detection and diagnosis using chest radiographs and mammograms. Later, the application scope gradually expanded to imaging modes, such as CT and ultrasound[6]. Traditional CAD algorithms perform image preprocessing, image segmentation, feature ex- traction, and image classification. Image preprocessing is required to improve the image quality. Various filters[7â€“9] can be used to remove noise, and methods such as histogram equalization[10] can be used for contrast and boundary enhancement. The purpose of image segmentation is to separate the region of interest from the image background. Common methods include threshold segmentation[11], edge detection[12], and cluster segmentation[13], among others. The extracted features can be roughly divided into two categories: external and internal features of the region. Based on feature extraction, a machine-learning algorithm is used to classify the images. Machine learning algorithms are divided into supervised and unsupervised learning based on the presence of labels. Supervised learning methods include Bayesian classifier[14] and minimum distance classifier[15], whereas unsupervised learning methods include K-means clustering algorithm[16]. Table 1 lists the number of publications on AI-based gland cancer diagnosis using supervised learning and weakly supervised learning since 2010, which indicates that this field is developing vigorously. In Figure 1, we also present a line chart to show the trends in these research fields since 2010. Data implies that in recent years, deep learning methods have dominated, which in- volves the majority of studies. Transfer learning, which is the most popular weakly supervised learning method, has developed most rapidly and has more related studies than traditional methods since 2021. Compared with manual diagnosis, although tra- ditional machine learning algorithms have made great progress in diagnosis speed with the diagnosis results able to reach a level similar to that of manual diagnosis, the quality of the results depends heavily on the selection and representation of image features[6]. In recent years, deep learning technology has been widely used because of its ability to au- Table 1 Statistics of GoogleScholar publications on AI-based gland cancer diagnosis methods since 2010 Category Specific methods Amount supervised learning traditional methods 5565 deep learning 7070 weakly supervised learning active learning 482 transfer learning 2554 semi-supervised learning 795 1800 1600 1400 1200 1000 800 600 400 200 0 20 10 20 11 20 12 20 13 20 14 20 15 20 16 20 17 20 18 20 19 20 20 20 21 20 22 Traditional methods Active learning Semi-supervised learning Deep learning Transfer learning Year Figure 1 Research trend of Google Scholar publications on AI- based gland cancer diagnosis methods since 2010. Virtual Reality & Intelligent Hardware August (2023) Vol. 5 No. 4294 tonomously learn advanced features hidden in data and achieve nonlinear mapping between inputs and outputs. However, owing to the small amount of training database, deep learning technology is prone to overfitting[17]. In the medical field, owing to the small number of cases or the protection of patient privacy, there is a lack of training data available. However, deep learning algorithms lack explicability. Although the specific operation of each step in the decision-making process of the deep model is clear, it cannot be described using semantics that can be understood by humans. This paper summarizes the intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancers using machine learning. We selected a large number of representative works published in authoritative international journals and conferences within the last five years, which have proposed new directions or breakthrough solutions to the problems existing in previous methods. We also selected several landmark studies that first applied machine- learning methods to tumor imaging diagnosis. We collected diagnostic methods for multiple types of gland nodules, compared and analyzed the technical improvements of machine learning methods longitudinally, and discussed the universality of the methods among different gland types. In the second part of this paper, the imaging principles of multimodal medical images, such as the commonly used CT, MRI, US, positron emission tomography (PET), and pathology, are summarized. The third and fourth parts of this paper presents the intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer based on supervised learning and weakly su- pervised learning, respectively. Finally, the problems and development trends in intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer are summarized and analyzed. 2 A brief introduction to the imaging principles of commonly used medical imaging modes The urgent need for the early detection and diagnosis of diseases is driving the development of imaging models. In addition to CT, MRI, PET, and other commonly used imaging modes, photoacoustic imaging, nanoimaging, and other technologies have emerged in recent years. The imaging principles of the commonly used medical imaging modes are briefly introduced below. 2.1 Computed tomography (CT) Computed tomography mainly uses the principle of radioactive elements producing different attenuation through different media to perform gray-scale imaging. A CT image is a series of continuous cross-sectional images that can be reconstructed to show the entire organ. CT can be divided into ordinary and enhanced scanning methods. To make the lesion clearer, contrast agent injection is required for enhanced scanning; however, there are also problems such as rapid clearance of the contrast agent, potential renal toxicity, and possible allergic reactions. Despite high exposure to ionizing radiation, CT imaging has been widely used for the screening and evaluation of breast cancer[18,19], thymic carcinoma[20], lung cancer[21], and other cancers because of its faster examination speed, lower cost, and higher efficiency. 2.2 Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) By applying a radiofrequency pulse with a certain frequency to the human body in a static magnetic field, a magnetic resonance phenomenon occurs when the hydrogen protons in the human body are stimulated. When the pulse is stopped, the protons produce radio signals during the relaxation process. An MRI image is generated by receiving radio signals, spatial coding, and image reconstruction. MRI images provide high sensitivity, high spatial resolution, high temporal resolution, and excellent soft tissue contrast. They can also display anatomical sectional information in a three-dimensional form. In addition, MRI does not use ionizing radiation or radioactive tracers, making it less harmful to humans than CT. The limitations of MRI are long imaging time, high equipment cost, motion artifacts, and potential implant artifacts. It is also inappropriate for Han JIANG, et al. Review of intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer based on machine learning 295 patients with pacemakers and claustrophobia[22]. Currently, MRI is mainly used for the diagnosis of prostate, breast, head and neck, and brain tumors[1]. 2.3 Ultrasound (US) imaging Ultrasound imaging uses an ultrasonic beam to scan the human body and obtain images of internal organs through the reception and processing of reflected signals. It is one of the most widely used diagnostic imaging methods because of its noninvasiveness, non-ionizing radiation, high spatial resolution, wide availability, low cost, and real-time imaging[23]. Ultrasound contrast agents have been developed to enhance acoustic signal differences between normal tissues and target lesions. The problems of ultrasound imaging lie in the high false-positive rate, image quality that is significantly affected by the level of operators, and all types of inherent artifacts and noise[24]. Ultrasound imaging technology can be applied to the screening of breast masses and the evaluation of breast density, among others[25]. 2.4 Positron emission tomography (PET) Positron emission tomography (PET) involves radioactive labeling of metabolites in cellular activities, such as fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG), and the subsequent usage of a highly sensitive camera to capture photons gen- erated during decay for imaging. Owing to the vigorous metabolism of malignant tumors, more marker compounds accumulate, which can be reflected in images, thus realizing the diagnosis and analysis of lesions. PET is a powerful and widely used medical imaging technology with the characteristics of high tissue penetration, high sensitivity, and real-time quantitative imaging analysis. In addition to anatomical in- formation, PET can provide biological information at the molecular level based on nuclide tracking. The problem with PET lies in its limited spatial resolution, dependence on the experience and knowledge of inspectors, and high inspection costs[26]. Currently, PET is primarily used for the diagnosis, metastasis, and staging of malignant tumors, such as breast, lung, and colorectal cancers, to facilitate the clinical development of better treatment plans[1]. 2.5 Pathological section imaging Pathological section imaging first requires patient biopsies to obtain pathological tissues. The pathological sections are then obtained through embedding, sectioning, staining, and other steps. Finally, the pathological sections are scanned with high resolution and full view of vision. The scanning images are seamlessly spliced to complete section digitization to finally obtain digital pathological images. Using pathological images are the most direct method for cancer diagnosis because they can provide information at the cellular level of diseased tissue. They have been also widely used in the classification, risk stratification, and prognosis of breast, thyroid, prostate, and other cancers. 2.6 Multimodal imaging PET is extremely sensitive, has sufficient tissue penetration, and provides functional information at the molecular level; however, its spatial resolution is limited. CT provides excellent spatial resolution but pro- duces a large amount of ionizing radiation. Fluorescence imaging provides optimal spatial resolution; how- ever, its tissue penetration is limited[26]. To overcome these limitations, multimodal imaging methods have been gradually developed. Applications of multimodal imaging in oncology have focused on combining anatomical imaging with functional imaging, such as PET and CT, to improve diagnostic specificity and target clarity. In recent years, the fusion of multimodal images has become more common, such as multiparameter magnetic resonance imaging sequences, different PET tracer images, and PET and MRI images, which allows the results to better characterize tumor phenotypes. PET and CT are commonly used for the diagnosis, staging, Virtual Reality & Intelligent Hardware August (2023) Vol. 5 No. 4296 and treatment of head and neck, lung, and breast cancers. PET and MRI are superior to PET and CT in specific applications, such as liver cancer, owing to the better soft tissue contrast of MRI. Studies have shown that PET and MRI have better diagnostic accuracy than single-mode imaging (multiparameter MRI and PET) for detecting the location of primary prostate cancer tumor[27]. It should be noted that multimodal imaging is a relatively new mode, and the challenge lies in uniformly preprocessing and fusing different images. As shown in Table 2, a public database of various gland cancers were collected and sorted in this study, and the information on image modes and database sizes are provided. This was a within-subjects laboratory study in which participants wore an HMD, were immersed in a virtual environment, and were required to repeatedly move forward along a road and stop at a target. The velocity of their movement on the road was controlled with different finger postures, such as curling (flexing) or ex- tending the fingers. The participants were instructed to move as rapidly as possible toward each target. The participants were aged 18 years or older and had no arm or shoulder injuries during the past month. The University Committee on Human Research approved the study, and the subjects signed an informed consent form. 3 Diagnosis method of gland cancer based on supervised learning With the development of artificial intelligence technology, several machine learning algorithms have been applied to medical image analysis and processing. Moreover, great progress has been made in the intelligent diagnosis of gland cancer, greatly reducing the burden on doctors, improving the accuracy of cancer diagnosis, and reducing the occurrence of missed diagnosis and misdiagnosis. In general, machine learning models must learn from the training database, with each training sample corresponding to an event or object. The training sample consists of two parts: a feature vector (or sample) describing an event or object and a label representing the truth output. In the classification task, the labels represent the training sample category. In regression tasks, the label is a real value corresponding to the sample. Machine-learning methods can be divided into supervised and weakly supervised learning methods. Chapters 3 and 4 summarizes and analyzes recent research results on supervised learning and weakly supervised learning, respectively. Supervised learning requires the inference of the probability of occurrence from labeled training data. The training dataset includes a set of samples. In supervised learning, each instance comprises an input object (usually a vector) and the desired output value (also known as a supervised signal). Supervised learning algorithms perform feature analysis on a training database and generate a set of inferential logic to map new instances to the results. Below, we classify and summarize the research achievements in the past five years based on traditional machine learning and deep learning algorithms. 3.1 Diagnosis method of gland cancer based on traditional machine learning algorithm The workflow of the diagnosis method for gland cancer based on traditional machine learning can be sum- marized as follows. (1) Generate ROIs. (2) Extract handcraft features from the ROIs. (3) Select the features. (4) Classify the features using single or multiple classifiers. In 2017, Xia et al. proposed a method based on an extreme learning machine (ELM) to classify thyroid nodules as malignant or benign on ultrasound images[28]. The workflow is illustrated in Figure 2. To identify the most recognizable features, researchers used a feature selection technique based on ReliefF to score the extracted features, and the eight highest-scoring features were input into the ELM classifier. Specifically, the ELM is a multilayer perceptron with only one hidden layer. Using ELM and ReliefF, this method achieved a high accuracy of 87.72%. Similar to the ELM-based approach mentioned above[28], Mohanty et al. utilized a parameter-optimized kernel extreme learning machine (KELM) to construct an automated diagnosis system for breast cancer in 2020[29]. This system contains five phases, as detailed in Figure 3. The first step was to generate ROIs, which was conducted by manual cropping using two ground-truth parameters: the center and radius of the abnormal regions. The second step was to extract features using a cross-diagonal texture matrix (CDTM). Haralickâ€²s features were then extracted from each ROI. Third, to reduce the dimension of the features and enhance the overall performance, KCPA is adopted to reduce the size of the high-dimensional feature space. Compared to the method proposed by Xia et al. both studies used ELM as their classifier; however, they operated with different kernel functions[28]. This method achieved an accuracy of 0.974 and 0.926 for the Mammographic Image Analysis Society (MIAS) and Digital Database for Screening Mammography (DDSM) datasets, respectively. Aside from the extreme learning machine, other traditional machine learning techniques, such as K-nearest neighbor algorithm (KNN) and support vector machine (SVM), have also been adopted in the detection of gland cancer. Han JIANG, et al. Review of intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer based on machine learning 299 FCMRG was used to segment the mammographic images. FCMRG is composed of the cascading FCM, morphological operations, and region-growing methods. In the feature extraction phase, LAP-GLCM and local phase quantization (LPQ) were adopted to extract the features. In the feature selection phase, the features are selected using the mRMR algorithm, which eliminates irrelevant features and guarantees better classifi- cation. In the classification phase, KNN, SVM, and other techniques were adopted to classify the selected features. To avoid overfitting, the K-fold method was used for cross-validation. An accuracy of 0.958 was obtained for the DDSM dataset using the KNN classifier applied to LPQ features, whereas an accuracy of 0.982 was obtained for the MIAS dataset using Decision Tree on hybrid features. This method applies multiple machine learning methods on different features or hybrid features, suggesting that different low-level feature extraction methods can result in different accuracies for different datasets. Thus, more robust feature ex- traction methods are required. In 2020, Sadad et al. proposed a method comprising four phases to identify breast malignancies[31]. First, preprocessing using the Hilbert Transform was performed to rebuild the B-mode images (a two-dimensional image containing bright dots) from the raw data. Second, a region-based segmentation method called Wa- tershed Transformation[32] was adopted to segment the lesion. To overcome oversegmentation, automatic markers are introduced by dedicating the transformation only to the basins related to each marker. Third, both the texture and shape features were extracted to represent the segments. Finally, the KNN, ensemble classifier, and DT were applied with different parameters to attain promising accuracy. This method achieved a state-of- the-art performance in 2020. In 2020, Asif et al. constructed a diagnosis model of thyroid disease by using several commonly used machine learning algorithms[33], including KNN[34], SVM[35], adaptive boost algorithm (AdaBoost)[36], XGBoost algorithm (XGB)[37], Gaussian process classifier (GPC)[38], gradient boost classifier (GBC)[39], and multi-layer perceptron classifier (MLPC)[40], among others. Table 3 presents the results of the study. The classification accuracy of the MLPC is the highest, reaching 99.70%. In 2021, Masuda et al. proposed a detection method for thyroid lymph node metastasis based on SVM[41]. This study compared the accuracy of the model with image texture and morphological features as the analysis indexes. The image texture features referred to 96 texture features calculated by a computer based on the methods of wavelet filtering, grey co-occurrence matrix, and grey area size matrix, and the analysis of texture features adopted an SVM classifier. Morphological features referred to the four attributes of major axis, minor axis, volume, and sphericity, which were analyzed using a univariate logistic regression classifier. The experimental results (Figure 5) show that the SVM classifier based on 96 texture features performed better than the univariate logistic regression classifier based on the morphological method. The area under the curve (AUC) value of the former was as high as 0.96, whereas that of the latter was less than 0.70. However, with the rapid development of deep learning techniques over the past five years, researchers have gradually become aware that deep learning has greatly simplified the feature extraction process from datasets and the learning process of an algorithm model. Deep learning techniques can be adap- ted to various circumstances related to computer vision and thus perfectly fit in the detection and diagnosis of gland cancer from a mass of images. Considering the merits of deep learning, researchers have switched their focus from traditional machine- learning methods to deep learning methods. 3.2 Diagnosis method of gland cancer based on the combination of traditional machine learning and deep learning algorithms Deep learning networks have mainly evolved from convolutional neural network (CNN) frameworks, including AlexNet, VGG, and ResNet. These net- works have laid a solid foundation for the proposal of state-of-the-art object detection methods, such as R-CNN, Feature Pyramid Network (FPN), Fast R-CNN, Faster R-CNN, Mask R-CNN. Over the last five years, researchers have made significant progress in utilizing various object detection techniques to spot and locate gland tumors in clinical images. This section summarizes the novel approaches for the diagnosis of gland cancer based on deep learning techniques. This section is broadly divided into two parts. First, we introduce CNN-based methods because CNN are regarded as the most fundamental component of deep learning and the basis of object detection techniques. Second, several methods based on systematic object detection models, including FPN, Fast R-CNN and Faster R-CNN, are illustrated. In 2018, Mohamed et al. developed a novel medical imaging application based on deep learning for the two categories that are most difficult to be distinguished in clinical breast density assessment, which are â€³dispersed densityâ€³ and â€³heterogeneous densityâ€³[42]. In this system, a Bi-RADS-based breast density classification computerized reader was constructed using CNN with a large digital mammography dataset to distinguish the most difficult dual radiation density categories mentioned previously. Experiments showed that when CNN models were trained from scratch on their mammography images, the AUC was 0.9421, and the accuracy gradually improved with an increase in the training sample scale. Using the pretrained model and fine-tuning only 500 mammogram images yielded an AUC of 0.9265. After removing potentially inaccurate labeled images, the AUC increased to 0.9882 and 0.9857, which were significantly higher than the AUC with the complete imaging dataset. In 2019, Lee et al. extracted the features of thyroid ultrasound images based on various pretrained CNN networks, including AlexNet32, OverFeat-accurate, VGG-F, VGG-19, ResNet-50, and Inception-v3, classi- fied them on the feature set through SVM and Random Forest, and integrated the classification results of the two to obtain the final results[43], as shown in Figure 6. The innovative aspect of this study can be illustrated as combining features from various CNNs (feature concatenation) and combining the results from different classifiers (classifier ensemble), which achieved an accuracy of 94.7%. In 2019, Khan et al. proposed a CAD system based on multiview feature fusion (MVFF) to classify mammograms using four-view feature fusion technology[44]. The system consists of three phases. The first phase classified mammograms as abnormal or normal; the second phase classified lumps or calcifications; and the last phase classified mammograms as malignant or benign. Experiments on publicly available datasets, such as Curated Breast Imaging Subset of DDSM (CBRIS-DDSM) and the small MIAS mammography database, show that the system has achieved an AUC higher than all single-view based systems, with 0.932 for lumps and calcifications and 0.84 for malignancies and benign. The AUC for the normal and abnormal classifications was 0.93. In 2019, Shi et al.[45] proposed GANet, inspired by PCANet[46], which is an unsupervised deep learning network that extracts features without labeled data. GANet adopts a network structure similar to PCANet to inherit its ability to extract features effectively with fewer parameters. It also leverages Grassmann averages (GA) to solve the problem of PCANet being sensitive to noise and outliers and enhance robustness. GA can address this issue by averaging all the subspaces generated by the data on the Grassmann manifold to realize dimensionality reduction. To represent color images, quaternion algebra is adopted to learn effective feature representations containing color information. GANet achieved an average accuracy of approximately 0.81 on gray scale images from the ADL Kidney dataset, whereas quaternion-based GANet achieved an average accuracy of approximately 0.90. In 2019, Tabibu et al. proposed an SVM-DAG based diagnostic classification and survival prediction model for renal cell carcinoma (RCC)[47], as shown in Figure 7. The model extracts features from large-scale whole- slide images (WSI) of the kidneys using CNNs. The unique feature of this model is that it detects whether the images contain cancer cells and further classifies them into three subtypes: Clear Cell RCC or KIRC, Papillary RCC or KIRP, and Chromophobe RCC or KICH, reaching an accuracy of 93.39% for KIRC and 87.34% for KICH. Additionally, the model solves the problem of unbalanced database using two methods. The first method transforms an N-category decision problem into an N(-1)/2 categories dichotomy decision problem by constructing a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) decision graph, which reduces the complexity of each decision and improves the overall decision accuracy, as shown in Figure 8. The second method involves the data augmentation of small databases and weighted resampling techniques to train the CNN. In 2020, Zhu et al. proposed a ResNet-18-based renal cell carcinoma detection method[48], which achieved an average accuracy higher than 0.95 on TCGA databases. The unique feature of this method is that it can realize the fine-grained classification of cancer cells and accurately classify the images of renal cell carcinoma into four subtypes: renal oncocytoma, Chromophobe RCC, Clear Cell RCC and Papillary RCC. Moreover, this study is potentially useful for assisting pathologists because it enables the localization and visualization of renal cell carcinoma. The workflow and research results are shown in Figure 9. In 2020, Chandio et al. proposed a classification decision method for medullary thyroid cancer based on CNN[49]. The database used in this study contained approximately 100 high-resolution microscopic images of medullary thyroid cancer with 5601 nuclei, including the class label attributes marked by doctors and the physical attributes of each nucleus. Experiments on the mini-MIAS mammogram image dataset showed that the proposed MA-CNN is powerful in diagnosing breast cancer, with a total classification sensitivity of 96% and an AUC of 0.99. In 2020, Zhang et al. constructed a multiview feature fusion network model to classify mammograms from two perspectives and proposed a multiscale attention network as the backbone network for feature extraction[52]. The model consists of two independent branches used to extract features from two mammograms from different views. To effectively extract the features of the entire mammogram image, the team constructed a new multiscale convolution module and integrated it into DenseNet. Simultaneously, a new attention module that connects the channel attention and spatial attention modules in parallel is proposed, and the module is added to the multi-scale convolution module. Finally, the experimental results showed that the proposed model achieves good performance in both classification tasks. The accuracy, sensitivity, and AUC values for normal and abnormal mammography were 94.92%, 96.52% and 94.72%, respectively. The accuracy, sensi- tivity, and AUC for benign and malignant mammography were 95.24%, 96.11%, and 95.03%, respectively. In 2021, Naglah et al. proposed a novel CAD system based on multimodel magnetic resonance imaging (MMRI) to distinguish benign from malignant thyroid nodules[53]. This system is based on a novel texture- learning architecture using CNN. It is the first to combine T2-weighted MRI and apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) maps by using CNN to model thyroid cancer. In addition, the system learns independent texture features for each input, enabling it to simultaneously extract complex texture patterns from both patterns. In 2021, Naglah et al. proposed a novel CAD system based on multimodal MRI to detect thyroid cancer nodules using CNN[54]. The system was constructed using multiple inputs to perform the fusion of two MRI modes: the diffusion-weighted image (DWI) and apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) map. The system can perform independent convolution processing on DWI and ADC images, which improves the possibility of detecting deep texture patterns of thyroid nodules. Additionally, the system can add additional channels to each input with the possibility of integration with other MRI modes and imaging techniques. Experimental results indicated that the diagnostic accuracy, precision, and recall of the system were 0.88, 0.82, and 0.82, respectively. In 2022, Kavitha et al. presented a novel breast cancer diagnosis model based on optimal multilevel threshold segmentation with DL-enabled Capsule Network (OMLTS-DLCN)[55]. The adaptive fuzzy median filtering (AFF) technique was used as a preprocessing step to eliminate noise from the mammogram images. Furthermore, a multilevel threshold and shell game optimization (SGO) algorithm based on optimal Kapur (OKMT-SGO) was applied to breast cancer segmentation. To detect breast cancer, the proposed model involves a CapsNet-based feature extractor and Back-Propagation Neural Network (BPNN) classification model. Experiments on the benchmark MINI-MIAS and DDSM datasets showed that the proposed model performed better than the other methods, with an accuracy of 98.50% and 97.55%, respectively. In 2019, Liu et al. proposed a novel CAD system based on deep learning to automatically detect and classify nodules in ultrasound images under the guidance of task-specific prior knowledge[57]. The CAD system consists of two parts: (1) a multiscale region-based detection network for learning pyramid features to detect nodules of different feature scales. They are bound by prior knowledge of the size and shape of real nodules; and (2) a multibranch classification network for integrating features. Experimental evaluation confirmed that the proposed method achieved a higher diagnostic accuracy than the previous CAD method for thyroid nodule classification, and the accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity of the system were better than those of experienced radiologists. In 2020, Zhang et al. proposed a novel and efficient tumor detection framework for pancreatic cancer CT images using a network model combining FPN and Faster R-CNN[58], achieving an accuracy of 90.18%. The proposed method makes the following three main contributions: enhanced feature pyramid network, adaptive feature fusion, and dependency calculation module. The improved network diagram is shown in Figure 13. Because the information propagation path in FPN is extremely long, which slows the transmission of low- level accurate positioning information, this study inputted the preprocessed CT images into the trained ResNet-101 for feature extraction. The feature pyramid through upsampling and horizontal connection were then established. To improve the detection performance by enhancing the entire feature level, a bottom-up path was established in the model to make the dissemination of low-level positioning information more effective. The model used RPN to generate candidate regions at each level, and subsequently used self-adaptive feature fusion to amplify the corresponding ROI By doing this, the model can contain high-level and low-level features simultaneously to make the context information multidimensional. In addition, the study also im- plemented a dependency calculation module, which enlarges the weighted sum of the features of all locations in region R.
