According to this section, it is not difficult to draw the conclusion that CNNs are suitable for processing data with spatial structure because the attributes of CNN contain the position relationship of image pixels by default, which has enabled it to become the essence of object detection. The studies mentioned in this section aim to improve the accuracy and speed of CNN through the adjustment and cascade of the network structure or the optimization of image segmentation and feature extraction in the early stage to improve the comprehensive performance of the diagnostic system. 4 Diagnosis method of gland cancer based on weakly supervised learning In contrast to supervised learning, weakly supervised learning no longer requires cumbersome pixel-level slice labeling for pathological diagnosis models. It only requires coarse-grained labels at the image level, which can significantly reduce the workload of labeling and provide new possibilities for imaging diagnosis and analysis of gland cancer. Generally, weak supervision can be classified into three types. The first type is incomplete supervision, where only a (usually extremely small) subset of the training set is labeled, and the rest of the data are not labeled. For example, in the image classification task, truth tags are provided by human taggers. Although it is easy to obtain a large number of images from the Internet, only a small subset of images can be tagged, owing to the high labor cost of tagging. The second type is inexact supervision, in which the images have only coarse- grained labels. The third type is inaccurate supervision, where the labels provided by the model are not always true values[59]. In the image analysis of gland tumors, the lack of a complete and effective labeled database is an important factor restricting the development of deep learning. Therefore, incomplete supervision is more widely used than the other two methods. This study elaborates on the application of incomplete supervision in the diagnosis of gland tumors. Among numerous machine learning paradigms developed for incompletely supervised environments, active learning, semisupervised learning, and transfer learning are the three most popular paradigms. Review of intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer based on machine learning 307 4.1 Active learning The key idea of active learning is to assume that truth labels of unlabeled data can be queried by human experts, who can label the most valuable data points in the estimation model. Active learning requires selecting the most valuable unlabeled data to query human experts, of which the information amount and representa- tiveness are the two most widely used criteria. The amount of information measures the extent to which unlabeled data can reduce the uncertainty of a statistical model, whereas representativeness measures the extent to which a sample can represent the input distribution of a model. Researchers often combine these approaches to complement each other. In 2019, Lee et al. proposed a breast cancer detection method based on active learning[60]. First, only a small amount of data were labeled in the database. These labeled data were used to train the model and predict the unlabeled data, after which the newly labeled data were corrected by human experts and added to the training set to enhance the data and improve the accuracy of the model. The active learning framework is illustrated in Figure 14. The experiment shows that active learning provides better performance in the ensemble learning of six different machine learning models. Active learning can better deal with the lack of data; however, we must still look for stable methods that can fully utilize the information of the labeled data. 4.2 Semi-supervised learning Unlike active learning, semisupervised learning is a learning paradigm that analyzes and utilizes un- labeled data without the participation of human experts. In reality, although unlabeled samples have no clear label information, their data distribution characteristics are often related to the distribution of labeled samples. Therefore, researchers can con- struct and analyze models based on these statistical properties. In semisupervised learning, there are two main hypotheses regarding data distribution: clus- tering and manifold hypotheses. Virtual Reality & Intelligent Hardware August (2023) Vol. 5 No. 4308 tection method based on semisupervised learning[61]. The WDBC database was used in the study, with half of the data in the training set labeled and half unlabeled. First, the labeled data were used for semisupervised learning. The trained model was then used to generate labels for the unlabeled data using the KNN algorithm. Subsequently, the database was k-folded, where one fold of which was taken each time as the test set, the other k-1 fold was taken as the training set. The model was trained repeatedly. Experimental results showed that this method (AISl) has higher classification accuracy than other traditional machine learning methods. Without decreasing the accuracy, semisupervised learning requires only half the time required by supervised learning methods. However, semisupervised learning methods are based on the assumption of a balanced dataset. In the imaging diagnosis of glandular nodules, it is difficult to ensure the balance of marker data in different classes. Considering an unbalanced dataset, Sun et al.[62] in 2017 proposed a semisupervised learning method with a data-weighing module based on the DROP3 instance selection method[63] and assigned different weights to different data using the weighing function. They also compared the effects of different weighing formulas, such as exponential, Gaussian, and Laplacian functions. The experiment showed that the exponential function had the most satisfactory performance in terms of labeling accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity. Inspired by the idea of the prototype in deep learning, utilizing a vector to represent a class, Alirezazadeh et al. proposed a new representation-learning-based unsupervised domain adaptation method in 2018 to over- come the problems of a large gap between the source and target domains and the great similarity between images of benign and malignant tumors[64]. This method utilizes handcraft features, including local binary patterns (LBP), LQP, and PFTAS, and subsequently learns a projection matrix to map the features of training and test images into the same invariant feature space, resulting in correct classification of both the training and test images. This method achieved an average accuracy of 0.885 on the BreaKHis dataset. In 2018, Koundal et al. proposed a computer-aided thyroid nodule detection system using medical ultra- sound images without any DCNN[65]. This system consists of three modules including a speckle reduction module to reduce speckle noise and preserve the diagnostic feature, a ROI auto-generating module to identify suspicious regions, and an auto-segmentation module to segment the nodule in processed ROI images. This method is fully automatic and requires no training, resulting in low accuracy and performance; however, it is an early study for us to consult. We observed that the existing weighing function can measure the importance of a single data based on its accuracy. Future studies should focus on dealing with unbalanced datasets and finding more suitable weighting formulas for the diagnosis of glandular nodules. 4.3 Transfer learning Transfer learning primarily uses the idea of analogy to improve the utilization rate of data. The goal of transfer learning is to use the knowledge in the source domain to solve the prediction function in the target domain under the condition that the source and target domains are different or the tasks in these domains are different[66]. In 2017, Liu et al. conducted transfer learning by applying the VGG-F model trained using ImageNet, a kind of CNN whose network structure is shown in Figure 14[67], and proposed a thyroid cancer detection method based on ultrasound images. The main contribution of this study is the proposal of an effective method for feature extraction and fusion. It fuses low-level features with high-level features extracted from the CNN network model to obtain a model with a higher classification accuracy. Low-level features include histogram of oriented gradient (HOG), scale- invariant feature transform (SIFT), and local binary patterns (LBP). High-level features include those ex- tracted from pool3, fc1, and fc2 layers in the VGGmodel. The experiment used an SVM classifier for training, and the experimental results showed that the classification results obtained by fusing the low-level features with the high-level features extracted from the pool3 layer of VGG (the fused feature set was pool3 +) had the highest accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity. In addition, some researchers have also attempted to conduct transfer learning based on AlexNet (a kind of CNN) model to identify and diagnose gland tumors. In 2019, Reda et al. proposed a prostate cancer diagnosis method based on AlexNet[68]. To reduce the cost of database annotation, the method of transfer learning was adopted. Researchers utilized a CNN pretrained by millions of images to transform its output layer, and subsequently used a small part of the data in this problem for fine-tuning, so it can effectively capture the features that require attention. This model can locate the prostate gland based on its appearance, prior shape, and spatial voxel relations. The researchers compared the classification results of the CNN and traditional machine learning classifiers (SVM, RF, and RT). The results showed that the AUC values of CNN, SVM, RF, and RT based on AlexNet were 0.93, 0.83, 0.87, and 0.50, respectively. It can be observed that the CNNmodel based on AlexNet has the best accuracy in terms of the localization and detection of prostate cancer, which also confirms the superiority of CNN in image processing and feature extraction. In 2019, Hussein et al. proposed an unsupervised method to classify lung and pancreatic pathological images, as shown in Figure 17[69]. First, clustering appearance features were adopted to estimate an initial set of labels. Second, the label proportions of each class were calculated. Finally, the initial cluster assignments and label proportions were used to train the proportion-SVM. The proposed method combining clustering with Î±SVMoutperforms other approaches in terms of accuracy and sensitivity. In addition to utilizing CNN to classify pathological images, some researchers have utilized generative adversarial networks (GAN), a deep learning structure based on CNN, to achieve style transfer. Pathological images were captured in various scenarios, such as different illuminations and fields of view, resulting in large uncertainties in cell shape, resolution, and color. Therefore, it is significant to narrow the gap between the source and target domains, while GAN shows a way. In 2021, Wang et al. proposed a method called prototype transfer generative adversarial network (PTGAN), which can reduce the feature distribution difference be- tween the labeled source domain and unlabeled target domain, learn the category prototype in the source domain, and transfer the classification capability to the target domain[70]. This method contains two sub- modules, TBGAN and PTA, which are described in Figure 18. TBGAN refers to a target-biased generative Virtual Reality & Intelligent Hardware August (2023) Vol. 5 No. 4310 adversarial network that realizes style transfer between the source and target domains through GAN and projects the extracted features to the cross-domain. PTA refers to the prototype transfer algorithm that further transfers the features through cross-domain feature adaption loss in feature-level, with TBGAN performing the same in style-level. The results on the BreakHis dataset showed that the PTGAN achieved a high accuracy of 0.87. Transfer learning can fully utilize the general features of a task, improving the accuracy and avoiding repetitive work. However, the accuracy of the transfer learning model relies significantly on the reliability of the source domain and is not flexible to apply a transfer learning model to a new disease type. Therefore, it is important to reduce the complexity of applying the transfer learning to various disease types. 5 Summary In recent years, researchers have made numerous remarkable achievements in the field of combining machine learning with traditional medical imaging, which provides a new technical approach for the diagnosis of gland Target bias loss Ta rg et So ur ce D G A N 1o ss Cross domain loss Prototype Transfer Module Figure 18 Framework of the Prototype transfer generative adversarial network (PTGAN)[70]. Review of intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer based on machine learning 311 cancer and significantly improves diagnostic accuracy and efficiency in practical applications. To achieve the ultimate goal of aiding and promoting the development of medicine, we propose a possible developmental direction for medical image-related technology based on three dimensions: dataset, method, and results. Data are crucial for the effectiveness of machine learning. First, the scale of most datasets is extremely small to cover the morphology of various cancers, resulting in uneven samples and affecting the accuracy of the model for practical applications. However, large datasets face the burden of data annotation. Accurate sample labeling requires professional physicians to spend several years, which is impossible for most researchers. In addition, the labeling of current datasets typically only distinguishes malignant and benign or labels different subtypes of cancer; however, it rarely provides annotations from the perspective of tumor characteristics and cancer diagnostic criteria. Moreover, most datasets do not contain healthy tissue sections. If a large and comprehensive dataset can be constructed, more fine-grained annotation can be made on pathological sections, and even prognostic and survival data can be provided. Although this work is time-consuming, it has a huge significance for disease diagnosis and understanding cancer development. Having adequate data is ideal, and in most cases, the cost of collecting and labeling data is unacceptable. Therefore, improving the performance of a model with limited data is an extremely critical problem. The application of semisupervised learning and weakly supervised learning reduces the dependence on the data- base size to a certain extent and has achieved some results. In addition, the applications of data enhancement, transfer learning, and small-sample learning can be combined with knowledge graphs to solve the problem of insufficient data. Another concern with these methods is the interpretability of the model. Deep learning is a black box model that involves unexplainable parameters. However, in clinical settings, the diagnosis of diseases typically requires strict medical explanations; however, machine learning alone cannot reasonably explain the results. To address this problem, a reverse analysis should be performed based on these results. Step-by-step learning methods are more frequently used in CAD than end-to-end methods. The former provides good support for interpreting the diagnosis results. Possible methods for improving interpretability include extracting common patterns from the learned representations and exploring their mathematical meanings. Regarding the output of the models, the current research focuses on distinguishing between benign and malignant samples or classifying different subtypes of cancer. However, cancer treatment is not limited to yes or no questions. Histopathological examination is a qualitative diagnosis, after which the diagnosis oncologists must quantitatively detect the extent of the tumor, existence of the metastasis, size of the lesion, damage to the function of the corresponding organ, and so on. These subsequent diagnoses are important steps in tumor staging and the determination of treatment strategies and means. Currently, only a few CAD methods are aimed at distinguishing or predicting the different stages of cancer, with this information being critical for cancer treatment. Some researchers have suggested three types of diagnoses: existing cancer, non-existing cancer, and disagreement about whether cancer exists[71]. This method not only improves the diagnostic efficiency but also avoids the occurrence of misdiagnosis and missed diagnosis so that doctors can focus on sections with unclear histological characteristics and promote further study of intermediate types of lesions. This problem ultimately points to the dataset; there is a vacancy for detailed annotation, which includes pixel- level labeling and a healthy tissue section. Many possibilities can be explored if a completely annotated dataset becomes available. Declaration of competing interest We declare that we have no conflict of interest. Review of intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer based on machine learning Han Jiang ∗ Wenjia Sun Hanfei Guo Jiayuan Zeng Xin Xue Shuai Li State key Laboratoty of Virtual Reality Technogy and Systems, Beihang University, Beijing 100083, China State key Laboratoty of Virtual Reality Technogy and Systems Beihang University Beijing 100083 China State key Laboratoty of Virtual Reality Technogy and Systems, Beihang University, Beijing 100083, China ∗ Corresponding author. Gland cancer is a high-incidence disease that endangers human health, and its early detection and treatment require efficient, accurate, and objective intelligent diagnosis methods. In recent years, the advent of machine learning techniques has yielded satisfactory results in intelligent gland cancer diagnosis based on clinical images, significantly improving the accuracy and efficiency of medical image interpretation while reducing the workload of doctors. The focus of this study is to review, classify, and analyze intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer based on machine learning and deep learning. This paper briefly introduces some basic imaging principles of multimodal medical images, such as the commonly used computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), ultrasound (US), positron emission tomography (PET), and pathology. In addition, the intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer were further classified into supervised learning and weakly supervised learning. Supervised learning consists of traditional machine learning methods, such as Knearest neighbor algorithm (KNN), support vector machine (SVM), and multilayer perceptron, and deep learning methods evolving from convolutional neural network (CNN). By contrast, weakly supervised learning can be further categorized into active learning, semisupervised learning, and transfer learning. State-of-the-art methods are illustrated with implementation details, including image segmentation, feature extraction, and optimization of classifiers. Their performances are evaluated through indicators, such as accuracy, precision, and sensitivity. In conclusion, the challenges and development trends of intelligent diagnosis methods for imaging gland cancer were addressed and discussed.
